list.item: DRAYMAN HENSCHEL ( Fuhrmann Henschel ) Translated by the Editor .
ROSE BERND ( Rose Bernd ) Translated by the Editor .
THE RATS ( Die Ratten ) Translated by the Editor .

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: The first volume of the present edition of Hauptmann 's Dramatic Works is identical in content with the corresponding volume of the German edition . In the second volume The Rats has been substituted for two early prose tales which lie outside of the scope of our undertaking . Hence these two volumes include that entire group of dramas which Hauptmann himself specifically calls social . This term must not , of course , be pressed too rigidly . Only in Before Dawn and in The Weavers can the dramatic situation be said to arise wholly from social conditions rather than from the fate of the individual . It is true , however , that in the seven plays thus far presented all characters are viewed primarily as , in a large measure , the results of their social environment . This environment is , in all cases , proportionately stressed . To exhibit it fully Hauptmann uses , beyond any other dramatist , passages which , though always dramatic in form , are narrative and , above all , descriptive in intention . The silent burden of these plays , the ceaseless implication of their fables , is the injustice and inhumanity of the social order .

Hauptmann , however , has very little of the narrow and acrid temper of the special pleader . He is content to show humanity . It is quite conceivable that the future , forgetful of the special social problems and the humanitarian cult of to-day , may view these plays as simply bodying forth the passions and events that are timeless and constant in the inevitable march of human life . The tragedies of Drayman Henschel and of Rose Bernd , at all events , stand in no need of the label of any decade . They move us by their breadth and energy and fundamental tenderness .

No plays of Hauptmann produce more surely the impression of having been dipped from the fullness of life . One does not feel that these men and women — Hanne Schael and Siebenhaar , old Bernd and the Flamms — are called into a brief existence as foils or props of the protagonists . They led their lives before the plays began : they continue to live in the imagination long after Henschel and Rose have succumbed . How does Christopher Flamm , that excellent fellow and most breathing picture of the average man , adjust his affairs ? He is fine enough to be permanently stirred by the tragedy he has earned , yet coarse enough to fall back into a merely sensuous life of meaningless pleasures . But at his side sits that exquisite monitor — his wife . The stream of their lives must flow on . And one asks how and whither ? To apply such almost inevitable questions to Hauptmann 's characters is to be struck at once by the exactness and largeness of his vision of men . Few other dramatists impress one with an equal sense of life 's fullness and continuity ,
“ The flowing , flowing , flowing of the world . ”

The last play in this volume , The Rats , appeared in 1911 , thirteen years after Drayman Henschel , nine years after Rose Bernd . A first reading of the book is apt to provoke disappointment and confusion . Upon a closer view , however , the play is seen to be both powerful in itself and important as a document in criticism and Kulturgeschichte . It stands alone among Hauptmann 's works in its inclusion of two separate actions or plots — the tragedy of Mrs. John and the comedy of the Hassenreuter group . Nor can the actions be said to be firmly interwoven : they appear , at first sight , merely juxtaposed . Hauptmann would undoubtedly assert that , in modern society , the various social classes live in just such juxtaposition and have contacts of just the kind here chronicled . His real purpose in combining the two fables is more significant . Following the great example , though not the precise method , of Moliere , who produced La Critique de l'Ecole des Femmes on the boards of his theater five months after the hostile reception of L'Ecole des Femmes , Hauptmann gives us a naturalistic tragedy and , at the same time , its criticism and defense . His tenacity to the ideals of his youth is impressively illustrated here . In his own work he has created a new idealism . But let it not be thought that his understanding of tragedy and his sense of human values have changed . The charwoman may , in very truth , be a Muse of tragedy , all grief is of an equal sacredness , and even the incomparable Hassenreuter — wind-bag , chauvinist and consistent Goetheaner — is forced by the essential soundness of his heart to blurt out an admission of the basic principle of naturalistic dramaturgy .

The group of characters in The Rats is unusually large and varied . The phantastic note is somewhat strained perhaps in Quaquaro and Mrs. Knobbe . But the convincingness and earth-rooted humanity of the others is once more beyond cavil or dispute . The Hassenreuter family , Alice Ruetterbusch , the Spittas , Paul John and Bruno Mechelke , Mrs. Kielbacke and even the policeman Schierke — all are superbly alive , vigorous and racy in speech and action .

The language of the plays in this volume is again almost wholly dialectic . The linguistic difficulties are especially great in The Rats where the members of the Berlin populace speak an extraordinarily degraded jargon . In the translation I have sought , so far as possible , to differentiate the savour and quaintness of the Silesian dialect from the coarseness of that of Berlin . But all such attempts must , from their very nature , achieve only a partial success . The succeeding volumes of this edition , presenting the plays written in normal literary German , will offer a fairer if not more fascinating field of interpretation .

set.p: Time : Toward the end of the eighteen sixties . Scene : The “ Gray Swan ” hotel in a Silesian watering place .

div.head: THE FIRST ACT

stage.stage: A room , furnished peasant fashion , in the basement of the “ Grey Swan ” hotel . Through two windows set high in the left wall , the gloomy light of a late winter afternoon sickers in . Under the windows there stands a bed of soft wood , varnished yellow , in which MRS. HENSCHEL is lying ill. She is about thirty-six years of age . Near the bed her little six-months-old daughter lies in her cradle . A second bed stands against the back wall which , like the other walls , is painted blue with a dark , plain border near the ceiling . In front , toward the right , stands a great tile-oven surrounded by a bench . A plentiful supply of small split kindling wood is piled up in the roomy bin . The wall to the right has a door leading to a smaller room . HANNE SCHAeL , a vigorous , young maid servant is very busy in the room . She has put her wooden pattens aside and walks about in her thick , blue stockings . She takes from the oven an iron pot in which food is cooking and puts it back again . Cooking spoons , a twirling stick and a strainer lie on the bench ; also a large , thick earthenware jug with a thin , firmly corked neck . Beneath the bench stands the water pitcher . HANNE 'S skirts are gathered up in a thick pad ; her bodice is dark grey ; her muscular arms are bare . Around the top of the oven is fastened a square wooden rod , on which long hunting stockings are hung up to dry , as well as swaddling clothes , leathern breeches and a pair of tall , water-tight boots . To the right of the oven stand a clothes press and a chest of drawers — old fashioned , gaily coloured , Silesian pieces of furniture . Through the open door in the rear wall one looks out upon a dark , broad , underground corridor which ends in a glass door with manicoloured panes . Behind this door wooden steps lead upward . These stairs are always illuminated by a jet of gas so that the panes of the door shine brightly . It is in the middle of February ; the weather without is stormy .

sp.speaker: FRANZ , a young fellow in sober coachman 's livery , ready to drive
sp.p: out , looks in .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Hanne !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Eh ?

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Is the missis asleep ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: What d'you suppose ? Do n't make so much noise !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: There 's doors enough slammin ’ in this house . If that do n't wake her up —! I 'm goin ’ to drive the carriage to Waldenburg .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Who 's goin ’ ?

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: The madam . She 's goin ’ to buy birthday presents .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Whose birthday is it ?

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Little Karl 's .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Great goin 's on — those . To hitch up the horses on account o ’ that fool of a kid an ’ travel to Waldenburg in such weather !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Well , I has my fur coat !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Those people do n't know no more how to get rid o ’ their money ! We got to slave instead ! In the passage appears , slowly feeling his may , the veterinarian GRUNERT . He is a small man in a coat of black sheep 's fur , cap and tall boots . He taps with the handle of his whip against the door post in order to call attention to his presence .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: Is n't Henschel at home yet ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: What 's wanted of him ?

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: I 've come to look at the gelding .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: So you 're the doctor from Freiburg , eh ? Henschel , he 's not at home . He went to Freiburg carryin ’ freight ; seems to me you must ha ’ met him .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: In which stall do you keep the gelding ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: ‘ Tis the chestnut horse with the white star on his face , I believe they put him in the spare stall .To FRANZ .You might go along an ’ show him the way .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Just go straight across the yard , ‘ s far as you can , under the big hall , right into the coachman 's room . Then you c'n ask Frederic ; he 'll tell you !

div.stage: Exit GRUNERT .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Well , go along with him .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Have n't you got a few pennies change for me ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I s'pose you want me to sell my skin on your account ?

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Tickling her .I 'd buy it right off .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Franz ! Do n't you —! D'you want the woman to wake up ? You do n't feel reel well , do you , if you can n't wring a few farthings out o ’ me ! I 'm fair cleaned out .Rummaging for the money .Here !She presses something into his hand .Now get out !

div.stage: The bell rings .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Frightened .That 's the master . Good-bye .

div.stage: He goes hastily .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Has waked up and says weakly .Girl ! Girl ! Do n't you hear nothin ’ ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Roughly .What d'you want ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I want you to listen when a body calls you !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I hear all right ! But if you do n't talk louder I can n't hear . I got only just two ears .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Are you goin ’ to cut up rough again ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Surly .Ah , what do I —!

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Is that right , eh ? Is it right o ’ you to talk rough like that to a sick woman ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Who starts it , I 'd like to know ! You do n't hardly wake up but what you begin to torment me . Nothin 's done right , no matter how you do it !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's because you do n't mind me !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You better be doin ’ your work yourself . I slaves away all day an ’ half o ’ the night ! But if things is that way — I 'd rather go about my business !

div.stage: She lets her skirts fall and runs out .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Girl ! Girl !— Do n't do that to me ! What is it I said that was so bad ? O Lord , O Lord ! What 'll happen when the men folks comes home ? They wants to eat ! No , girl ... girl !She sinks back exhausted , moans softly , and begins to rock her baby 's cradle by means of a cord which is within her reach .Through the glass door in the rear KARLCHEN squeezes himself in with some difficulty . He carries a dish full of soup and moves carefully and timidly toward MRS. HENSCHEL 'S bed . There he sets down the dish on a wooden chair .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Eh , Karlchen , is that you ! Do tell me what you 're bringin ’ me there ?

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: Soup ! Mother sends her regards and hopes you 'll soon feel better and that you 'll like the soup , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Eh , little lad , you 're the best of ‘ em all . Chicken soup ! ‘ Tis not possible . Well , tell your mother I thank her most kindly . D'you hear ? Do n't go an ’ forget that ! Now I 'll tell you somethin ’ , Karlchen ! You c'n do me a favour , will you ? See that rag over there ? Get on this bench , will you , an ’ pull the pot out a bit . The girl 's gone off an ’ she put it too far in .

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: After he has found the rag mounts the bench cheerfully and looks into the oven . He asks :The black pot or the blue one , Mrs. Henschel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What 's in the blue pot ?

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: Sauerkraut .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Agitated .Pull it out ! That 'll be boilin ’ to nothin ’ !— Eh , what a girl , what a girl !

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: Has pulled the pot in question forward .Is this right ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You c'n let it stand that way ! Come here a bit now an ’ I 'll give you a piece o ’ whip cord .She takes the cord from the window-sill and gives it to him .An ’ how is your mother ?

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: She 's well . She 's gone to Waldenburg to buy things for my birthday .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm not well , myself . I think I 'm goin ’ to die !

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: Oh , no , Mrs. Henschel !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , yes , you c'n believe me ; I 'm goin ’ to die . For all I care you can say so to your mother .

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: I 'm goin ’ to get a Bashly cap , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , yes , you c'n believe me . Come over here a bit . Keep reel still an ’ listen . D'you hear how it ticks ? D'you hear how it ticks in the rotten wood ?

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN
sp.p: Whose wrist she holds in her fevered grasp .I 'm afraid , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , never mind . We all has to die ! D'you hear how it ticks ? Do you ? What is that ? ‘ Tis the deathwatch that ticks .She falls back .One ... two ... one ...— Oh , what a girl , what a girl !

sp.speaker: KARLCHEN , released from her grasp , withdraws timidly toward the
sp.p: door . When his hand is on the knob of the glass door a sudden terror overtakes him . He tears the door open and slams it behind him with such force that the panes rattle . Immediately thereupon a vigorous cracking of whips is heard without . Hearing this noise MRS. HENSCHEL starts up violently .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's father comin ’ !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Out in the hallway and yet unseen .Doctor , what are we goin ’ to do with the beast ?

div.stage: He and the veterinarian are visible through the doorway .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: He wo n't let you come near him . We 'll have to put the twitch on him , I think .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: He is a man of athletic build , about forty-five years old . He wears a fur cap , a jacket of sheep 's fur under which his blue carter 's blouse is visible , tall boots , green hunting stockings . He carries a whip and a burning lantern .I do n't know no more what 's wrong with that beast . I carted some hard coal from the mine yesterday . I came home an ’ unhitched , an ’ put the horses in the stable , an ’ — that very minute — the beast throws hisself down an ’ begins to kick .

div.stage: He puts his long whip in a corner and hangs up his cap .

sp.speaker: HANNE returns and takes up her work again , although visibly
sp.p: enraged .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Girl , get a light !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: One thing after another !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Puts out the light in the lantern and hangs it up .Heaven only knows what all this is comin ’ to . First my wife gets sick ! Then this here horse drops down ! It looks as if somethin ’ or somebody had it in for me ! I bought that gelding Christmas time from Walther . Two weeks after an ’ the beast 's lame . I 'll show him . Two hundred crowns I paid .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Is it rainin ’ outside ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In passing .Yes , yes , mother ; it 's rainin ’ .— An ’ it 's a man 's own brother-in-law that takes him in that way .

div.stage: He sits down on the bench .

sp.speaker: HANNE has lit a tallow candle and puts it into a candle stick of
sp.p: tin , which she sets on the table .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're too good , father . That 's what it is . You do n't think no evil o ’ people .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: Sitting down at the table and writing a prescription .I 'll write down something for you to get from the chemist .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: No , I tell you , if that chestnut dies on top o ’ everythin ’ else —! I do n't believe God 's meanin ’ to let that happen !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Holding out his leg to HANNE .Come , pull off my boots for me ! That was a wind that blew down here on the road from Freiburg . People tell me it unroofed the church in the lower village more'n half ,To HANNE .Just keep on tuggin ’ ! Ca n't you get it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: To HANNE .I do n't know ! You do n't seem to learn nothin ’ !

div.stage: HANNE succeeds in pulling off one boot . She puts it aside and starts on the other .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Keep still , mother ! You do n't do it any better !

lg.stage: Pulls off the second boot and puts it aside . Then in a surly voice to HENSCHEL .
lg.l: Did you bring me my apron from Kramsta ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: All the things I 'm axed to keep in my head ! I 'm content if I c'n keep my own bit of business straight an ’ get my boxes safe to the railroad . What do I care about women or their apron-strings ?

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: No , you 're not famous for caring about them .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ it 'd be a bad thing if he was !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Slips on wooden pattens and rises . To HANNE .Hurry now ! Hurry ! We got to get our dinner . This very day we still has to go down to the smithy .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: Has finished writing his prescription , which he leaves lying on the table . He slips his note book and pencil back into his pocket and says as he is about to go :You 'll hurry this to the chemist 's . I 'll look in early in the morning .

div.stage: HENSCHEL sits down at the table .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE comes in slowly . He has wooden pattens on and leathern
sp.p: breeches and also carries a lighted lantern .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: That 's dirty weather for you again !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: How 's it goin ’ in the stable ?

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: He 's goin ’ to end by knockin ’ down the whole stall .

div.stage: He blows out the light in the lantern and hangs it up next to HENSCHEL 'S .

sp.speaker: GRUNERT
sp.p: Good night to all of you . All we can do is to wait . We doctors are only human too .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: To be sure . We know that without your telling us ! Good night ; I hope you wo n't overturn .GRUNERT goes .Now tell me , mother , how is it with you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh . I 've been worritin ’ so much again !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What is it that worries you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Because for all I c'n do , I 'm not able to lend a hand even .

sp.speaker: HANNE places a disk of dumplings and one of sauerkraut on the table ;
sp.p: she takes forks from the table drawer and puts them on the table .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: The girl 's here to do the work !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: A girl like her is that thoughtless !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , we gets enough to eat an ’ everythin ’ seems to go smoothly .— If you had n't got up out o ’ bed too soon the first time , you might be dancin ’ this day !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: O Lord , me an ’ dancin ’ . What an idea !

sp.speaker: HANNE has prepared three plates , putting a small piece of pork on
sp.p: each . She now draws up a stool for herself and sits down at the table .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: There 's not much left o ’ the oats , neither .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I bought some yesterday ; thirty sacks . Saturday a load o ’ hay 'll come too . The feed gets dearer all the time .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: If the beasts is to work they has to eat .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: But people thinks they live on air , an ’ so everybody wants to cut down the carting charges .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: He said somethin ’ like that to me too .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who said that — the inspector ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who else but him ? But this time he met the wrong man .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , well , I 'm not sayin ’ , but that 's the end of everythin ’ ! What 's to become of us these hard times ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: The inspector of roads was here . He wants you to send him teams for the big steam roller , I believe . They 're in Hinterhartau now . Behind the glass door MR. SIEBENHAAR is seen descending the stairs . He is little over forty . Most carefully dressed ; black broadcloth coat , white waist-coat , light-coloured , English trousers — an elegance of attire derived from the style of the ‘ sixties . His hair , already grey , leaves the top of his head bald ; his moustache , on the contrary , is thick and dark blond . SIEBENHAAR wears gold-rimmed spectacles . When he desires to see anything with exactness , he must use , in addition , a pair of eye-glasses which he slips in behind the lenses of his spectacles . He represents an intelligent type .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Approaches the open door of the room . In his right hand he holds a candle-stick of tin with an unlit candle in it and a bunch of keys ; with his left hand he shades his sensitive eyes .Has Henschel come back yet ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Siebenhaar .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: But you 're just at your dinner . I have something to do in the cellar . We can talk that matter over later .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: No , no ; you need n't put nothin ’ off on my account . I 'm through !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: In that case you 'd better come up to see me .He enters the room and lights his candle by the one which is burning on the table .I 'll only get a light here now . We 're more undisturbed in my office .— How are you , Mrs. Henschel ? How did you like the chicken-soup ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , goodness , gracious ! I clean forgot about it !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Is that so , indeed ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Discovering the dish of chicken soup .That 's true ; there it stands .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's the way that woman is ! She 'd like to get well an ’ she forgets to eat and to drink .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: As a violent gust of wind is felt even indoors .Do tell me : what do you think of it ? My wife 's driven over to Waldenburg , and the weather is getting wilder and wilder . I 'm really beginning to get worried . What 's your opinion ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I s'pose it sounds worse than it is .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , well , one should n't take such risks . Did n't you hear that rattling ? The wind broke one of the large windows in the dining-hall looking out over the verandah . You know . It 's a tremendous storm !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who 'd ha ’ thought it !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 'll be costin ’ you a good bit again !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Leaving the room by way of the passage to the left .There 's nothing inexpensive except death .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: He 's got his bunch o ’ troubles like the rest of us .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What do you think he wants o ’ you again , father ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Nothin ’ ! How c'n I tell ? I 'll hear what he says .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do hope he wo n't be askin ’ for money again .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Do n't begin talkin ’ nonsense , mother .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: But if them people is as hard up as all that , why does the woman has to have a twenty shillin ’ hat ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You hold your tongue ! No one asked you ! You poke your nose over your kneadin ’ board an ’ not into other folks ’ affairs ! It takes somethin ’ to keep a hotel like this goin ’ . Two months in the year he makes money . The rest o ’ the time he has to do the best he can .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: An ’ he had to go an ’ build atop o ’ that !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ ‘ twas that as got him in worse'n ever . He should ha ’ let it be .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Women do n't understand nothin ’ o ’ such affairs . He had to build ; he could n't do no different . We gets more an ’ more people who come here for their health nowadays ; there was n't half so many formerly . But in those times they had money ; now they wants everythin ’ for nothin ’ . Get the bottle . I 'd like to drink a nip o ’ whiskey .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Slowly clasping his knife and getting ready to rise .Forty rooms , three big halls , an ’ nothin ’ in ‘ em excep ’ rats an ’ mice . How 's he goin ’ to raise the interest ?

div.stage: He rises .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA WERMELSKIRCH peeps in . She is a pretty , lively girl of
sp.p: sixteen . She wears her long , dark hair open . Her costume is slightly eccentric : the skirts white and short , the bodice cut in triangular shape at the neck , the sash long and gay . Her arms are bare above the elbows . Around her neck she wears a coloured ribbon from which a crucifix hangs down .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Very vivaciously .Was n't Mr. Siebenhaar here just now ? I wish you a pleasant meal , ladies and gentlemen ! I merely took the liberty of asking whether Mr. Siebenhaar had n't been here just now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Gruffly .We do n't know nothin ’ . He was n't with us !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: No ? I thought he was !

div.stage: She puts her foot coquettishly on the bench and ties her shoe strings .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Mr. Siebenhaar here an ’ Mr. Siebenhaar there ! What are you always wantin ’ of the man ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I ? nothing ! But he 's so fond of gooseliver . Mama happens to have some and so papa sent me to tell him so .— By the way , Mr. Henschel , do you know that you might drop in to see us again , too !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You just let father bide where he is ! That 'd be a fine way ! He 's not thinkin ’ about runnin ’ into taverns these days .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: We 're broaching a new keg to-day , though .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: While HAUFFE grins and HANNE laughs .Mother , you stick to your own affairs . If I should want to go an ’ drink a glass o ’ beer I would n't be askin ’ nobody 's consent , you c'n be sure .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: — How are you anyhow , Mrs. Henschel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , to-morrow I 'll be gettin ’ me a sash too an ’ take to rope-dancin ’ .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I 'll join you . I can do that splendidly . I always practice on the carriage shafts .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: So that 's the reason why all the shafts are bent !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Do you see , this is the way it 's done ; this is the way to balance oneself .Imitating the movements of a tight rope dancer , she prances out by the door .Right leg ! Left leg ! Au revoir !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Taking down his lantern .She 'll go off her head pretty soon if she do n't get no husband .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If she had to lend a hand an ’ work good an ’ hard , she 'd get over that foolishness .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: She 's not allowed to come upstairs . Mrs. Siebenhaar wo n't have her .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ she 's right there . I would n't bear it neither .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: She 's always chasin ’ an ’ sniffin ’ around Mr. Siebenhaar . I 'm willin ’ people should please theirselves . But she 's goin ’ it hard .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: The Siebenhaars ought to put them people out . The goin 's on with the men an ’ the wenches .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Aw , what are you talkin ’ about , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , in the tap room .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , they has to live same as anybody . D'you want to see ‘ em put in the streets ? Wermelskirch 's not a bad fellow at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: But the woman 's an old witch .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: If he pays his rent nothin ’ wo n't happen to him on that account . An ’ not on account o ’ the girl by a long way .He has arisen and bends over the cradle .We 've got a little thing like that here too , an ’ nobody 's goin ’ to put us out for that !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Eh , that would be ...! She 's asleep all the time ; she do n't seem to want to wake up !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: There 's not much strength in her .— Mother , sure you 're not goin ’ to die !—Taking his cap from the nail .Hanne , I was just foolin ’ you a while ago . Your apron is lyin ’ out there in the waggon .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Eagerly .Where is it ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In the basket . Go an ’ look for it !

div.stage: HENSCHEL leaves by way of the middle door ; HANNE disappears into the small adjacent room .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: So he brought her the apron after all !

sp.speaker: HANNE runs quickly through the room again and goes out by the middle
sp.p: door .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ he brought her the apron after all !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR enters carefully , carrying his candle and keys as before
sp.p: and , in addition , two bottles of claret .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: All alone , Mrs. Henschel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ he brought the apron ...

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: It 's me , Mrs. Henschel . Did you think it was a stranger ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't hardly believe ...

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I hope I did n't wake you up . It 's me — Siebenhaar .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: To be sure . Yes . To be sure .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: And I 'm bringing you a little wine which you are to drink . It will do you good .— Is it possible you do n't recognize me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , now , that 'd be queer . You are , sure — you are our Mr. Siebenhaar . Things has n't come to such a pass with me yet . I recognise you all right !— I do n't know : has I been dreamin ’ or what ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: You may have been . How are you otherwise ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: But sure enough you 're Siebenhaar .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Perhaps you thought I was your husband !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't know ... I reely can n't say ... I was feelin ’ so queer ...

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Seems to me you 're not lying comfortably . Let me straighten your pillows a bit . Does the doctor see you regularly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: With tearful excitement .I do n't know how it is — they just leaves me alone . No , no , you 're Mr. Siebenhaar , I know that . An ’ I know more'n that : you was always good to me an ’ you has a good heart , even if sometimes you made an angry face . I can tell you : I 'm that afraid ! I 'm always thinkin ': it do n't go quick enough for him .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: What does n't go quick enough ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Bursting into tears .I 'm livin ’ too long for him —! But what 's to become o ’ Gustel ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: But , my dear Mrs. Henschel , what kind of talk is that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Sobbing softly to herself .What 's to become o ’ Gustel if I die ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Mrs. Henschel , you 're a sensible woman ! And so do listen to me ! If one has to lie quietly in bed , you see , the way you have had to do unfortunately — week after week — why then one naturally has all kinds of foolish thoughts come into one 's head . One has all sorts of sickly fancies . But one must resist all that resolutely , Mrs. Henschel ! Why , that would be a fine state of affairs , if that —! Such stuff ! Put it out of your mind , Mrs. Henschel ! it 's folly !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Dear me , I did n't want to believe it : I know what I says !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: That 's just what you do n't know . That 's just what , unfortunately , you do n't know at present . You will simply laugh when you look back upon , it later . Simply laugh !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Breaking out passionately .Did n't he go an ’ see her where she sleeps !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Utterly astonished but thoroughly incredulous .Who went to see whom ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Henschel ! The girl !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Your husband ? And Hanne ? Now look here ; whoever persuaded you of that is a rascally liar .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ when I 'm dead he 'll marry her anyhow !

lg.l: SIEBENHAAR
You 're suffering from hallucinations , Mrs. Henschel !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In good-natured astonishment .What 's the matter , Malchen ? Why are you cryin ’ so ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , you must n't leave your wife alone !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Approaches the bed in kindly fashion .Who 's doin ’ anythin ’ to you ?

lg.stage: Throws herself in sullen rage on her other side , turning her back to HENSCHEL and facing the wall .
lg.l: Aw , leave me in peace !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What 's the meanin ’ o ’ this ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Snarling at him through her sobs .Oh , go away from me !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL , visibly taken aback , looks questioningly at SIEBENHAAR ,
sp.p: who polishes his glasses and shakes his head .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Softly .I would n't bother her just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: As before .You 're wishin ’ me into my grave !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: To HENSCHEL , who is about to fly into a rage .Sh ! Do me the favour to keep still !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: A body has eyes . A body 's not blind ! You do n't has to let me know everythin ’ . I 'm no good for nothin ’ no more ; I c'n go !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Controlling himself .What do you mean by that , Malchen ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's right ! Go on pretendin ’ !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Perplexed in the extreme .Now do tell me — anybody ...!

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Things c'n go any way they wants to ... I wo n't be deceived , an ’ you c'n all sneak aroun ’ all you want to ! I c'n see through a stone wall ! I c'n see you for all — yes — for all ! You thinks : a woman like that is easy to deceive . Rot , says I ! One thing I tell you now — If I dies , Gustel dies along with me ! I 'll take her with me ! I 'll strangle her before I 'd leave her to a damned wench like that !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: But mother , what 's come over you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're wishin ’ me into my grave !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hold on , now , hold on ! Or I 'll be gettin ’ wild !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Warning him softly .Be calm , Henschel . The woman is ill .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who has overheard .Ill ? An ’ who was it made me ill ? You two — you an ’ your wench !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Now I 'd like to know who in the world put notions like that into your head ? The girl an ’ I ! I do n't understand the whole blasted thing ! I 'm supposed to have dealin 's with her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Do n't you fetch aprons an ’ ribands for her ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: With renewed perplexity .Aprons and ribands ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , aprons and ribands .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , that 's the queerest thing —!

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Do n't you think everythin ’ she does right an ’ fine ? D'you ever give her a angry word ? She 's like the missis of the house this very day .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Mother , keep still : I 'm advisin ’ you !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis you that has to keep still , ‘ cause there 's nothin ’ you c'n say !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Standing by the bed .Mrs. Henschel , you must collect yourself ! All this you 're saying is the merest fancy !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're no better'n he ; you do n't do no different ! An ’ the poor women — they dies of it !Dissolved in self-pitying tears .Well , let ‘ em die !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR gives a short laugh with an undertone of seriousness ,
sp.p: steps up to the table and opens one of the bottles of wine resignedly .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Sitting on the edge of the bed speaks soothinglyMother , mother — you turn over now an ’ I 'll say a word to you in kindness .He turns her over with kindly violence .Look at it this way , mother : You 've been havin ’ a dream . You dreamed — that 's it ! Our little dog , he dreams queer things too now an ’ then . You c'n see it . But now wake up , mother ! Y'understan ’ ? The stuff you been talkin ’ — if a man wanted to make a load o ’ that the strongest freight waggon 'd break down . My head 's fair spinnin ’ with it .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Having looked for and found a glass which he now fills .And then you raked me over the coals too !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Do n't take no offence , sir . A woman like that ! A man has his troubles with her .— Now you hurry up , mother , an ’ get well , or some fine day you 'll be tellin ’ me I been to Bolkenhain an ’ stole horses .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Here , drink your wine and try to gain some strength .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If only a body could be sure !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR supports her while she drinks

lg.l: HENSCHEL
What 's wrong now again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: After she has drunk .Could you give me a promise ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'll give you any promise you wants .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If I dies , would you go an ’ marry her ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Do n't ask such fool questions .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes or no !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Marry Hanne ?Jestingly .O ’ course I would !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I mean it — serious ...!

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Now I just wish you 'd listen to this , Mr. Siebenhaar ! What 's a man to say ? You 're not goin ’ to die !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: But if I does ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I wo n't marry her anyhow ! Now you see ? An ’ now you know it ! We can make an end o ’ this business .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Can you promise it ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Promise what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That you would n't go an ’ marry the girl !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'll promise , too ; I 'm willin ’ to .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ you 'll give me your hand in token ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm tellin ’ you : Yes .He puts his hand into hers .But now it 's all right . Now do n't worry me no more with such stuff .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE SECOND ACT A beautiful forenoon in May . The same room as in the first act . The bed , in which MRS. HENSCHEL lay , is no longer there . The window which it covered is wide open . HANNE , her face toward the window , her sleeves turned up above her elbows , is busy at the washtub .

sp.speaker: FRANZ , his shirt-sleeves and trousers also rolled up , his bare feet
sp.p: in wooden pattens , comes in carrying a pail . He has been washing waggons .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: With awkward merriment .Hanne , I 'm comin ’ to see you ! Lord A'mighty ! Has you got such a thing as some warm water ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Angrily throwing the piece of linen which she has on the washboard back into the tub and going over to the oven .You come in here a sight too often !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Is that so ? What 's wrong , eh ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Pouring hot water into the pail .Do n't stop to ask questions . I got no time .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: I 'm washin ’ waggons ; I 'm not idlin ’ neither .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Violently .You 're to leave me alone ! That 's what you 're to do ! I 've told you that more'n once !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: What am I doin ’ to you ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You 're not to keep runnin ’ after me !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: You 've forgotten , maybe , how it is with us ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: How ‘ tis with us ? No ways ; nothin ’ ! You go you way an ’ I goes mine , an ’ that 's how it is !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: That 's somethin ’ bran ’ new !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: It 's mighty old to me !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: That 's how it seems .— Hanne , what 's come between us !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Nothin ’ , nothin ’ ! Only just leave me alone !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Has you anythin ’ to complain of ? I been true to you !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Oh , for all I care ! That 's none o ’ my business ! Carry on with anybody you want to ! I got nothin ’ against it !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Since when has you been feelin ’ that way ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Since the beginnin ’ o ’ time !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Moved and tearful .Aw , you 're just lyin ’ , Hanne !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You do n't need to start that way at me . ‘ Two n't do you no good with me ! I do n't let a feller like you tell me I 'm lyin ’ ! An ’ now I just want you to know how things is . If your skin 's that thick that you can n't be made to notice nothin ’ I 'll tell you right out to your face : It 's all over between us !

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: D'you really mean that , Hanne ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: All over — an ’ I want you to remember that .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: I 'll remember it all right !More and more excited and finally weeping more than speaking .You do n't need to think I 'm such a fool ; I noticed it long before to-day . But I kept thinkin ’ you 'd come to your senses .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: That 's just what I 've done .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: It 's all the way you look at it . I 'm a poor devil — that 's certain ; an ’ Henschel — he 's got a chest full o ’ money . There 's one way , come to think of it , in which maybe you has come to your senses .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You start at me with such talk an ’ it just makes things worse an ’ worse . That 's all .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: It 's not true , eh ? You 're not schemin ’ right on to be Mrs. Henschel ? I 'm not right , eh ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: That 's my business . That do n't concern you . We all has to look out for ourselves .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Well , now , supposin ’ I was to look out for myself , an ’ goes to Henschel an ’ says : Hanne , she promised to marry me ; we was agreed , an ’ so ....

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Try it , that 's all I says .

sp.speaker: FRANZ
sp.p: Almost weeping with pain and rage .An ’ I will try it , too ! You take care o ’ yourself an ’ I 'll take care o ’ myself . If that 's the way you 're goin ’ to act , I c'n do the same !With a sudden change of front .But I do n't want to have nothin ’ more to do with you ! You c'n throw yourself at his head for all I cares ! A crittur like you is n't good enough for me !

div.stage: Exit hastily .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: So it worked at last . An ’ that 's all right . While HANNE continues busy at her washing , WERMELSKIRCH appears in the passage at the rear . He is a man in the fifties ; the former actor is unmistakable in him . He wears a thread-bare dressing-gown , embroidered slippers , and smokes a very long pipe .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Having looked in for a while without being noticed by HANNE .Did you hear him cough ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Why , a guest — a patient — has arrived upstairs .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: ‘ Tis time they began to come . We 're in the middle of May .

lg.stage: Slowly crosses the threshold and hums throatily .
lg.l: A pulmonary subject I ,
Tra la la la la , bum bum !
It can n't last long until I die ,
Tra la la la la , bum bum !

div.stage: HANNE laughs over her washing . ] Things like that really do one good . They show that the summer is coming .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: One swallow do n't make no summer , though !

lg.stage: Clears a space for himself on the bench and sits down .
lg.l: Where is
Henschel ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Why he went down , to the cemetery to-day .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: To be sure , it 's his wife 's birthday .Pause .It was a deuce of a blow to him , that 's certain .— Tell me , when is he coming back ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I do n't know why he had to go an ’ drive there at all . We needs the horses like anything an ’ he took the new coachman with him too .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: I tell you , Hanne , anger spoils one 's appetite .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Well , I can n't help bein ’ angry ! He leaves everythin ’ in a mess . The ‘ bus is to leave on time ! An ’ the one-horse carriage sticks in the mud out there an ’ Hauffe can n't budge it ! The old fellow is as stiff as a goat !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Yes , things are beginning to look busy . The chef upstairs starts in to-day . It 's beginning to look up in the tap-room too .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: With a short derisive laugh .You do n't look , though , as if you had much to do !

lg.stage: Taking no offence .
lg.l: Oh , that comes later , at eleven o'clock . But then
I 'm like a locomotive engine !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I believe you . There 'll be a lot o ’ smoke . You wo n't let your pipe get cold whatever happens .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Smiling a little .You 're pleased to be pointed in your remarks — pointed as a needle .— We 've got to-day , for our table music , wait now , let me think —: First of all , a bass violin ; secondly , two cellos ; thirdly , two first violins and two second violins . Three first , two second , three second , two first : I 'm getting mixed up now . At all events we have ten men from the public orchestra . What are you laughing at ? Do you think I 'm fooling you ? You 'll see for yourself . The bass violin alone will eat enough for ten . There 'll be work enough to do !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Laughing heartily .Of course : the cook 'll have a lot to do !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Simply .My wife , my daughter , the whole of my family — we have to work honestly and hard .— And when the summer is over we 've worked ourselves to the bone — for nothing !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I do n't see what you has to complain of . You 've got the best business in the house . Your taproom do n't get empty , if it 's summer or winter . If I was Siebenhaar upstairs , you 'd have to whistle a different tune for me . You would n't be gettin ’ off with no three hundred crowns o ’ rent . There would n't be no use comin ’ around me with less'n a thousand . An ’ then you 'd be doin ’ well enough for yourself !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Has arisen and walks about whistling .Would you like anything else ? You frighten me so that my pipe goes out !

sp.speaker: GEORGE , a young , alert , neat waiter comes very rapidly down the
sp.p: stairs behind the glass door , carrying a tray with breakfast service . While still behind the door he stops short , opens the door , however , and gazes up and down the passage way .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Confound it all ! What 's this place here ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Laughing over her tub .You 've lost your way ! You has to go back !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It 's enough , God knows , to make a feller dizzy , No horse could n't find his way about this place .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You 've just taken service here , eh ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well o ’ course ! I came yesterday . But tell me , ladies an ’ gentlemen ! Nothin ’ like this has ever happened to me before . I 've been in a good many houses but here you has to take along a kind o ’ mountain guide to find your way .

lg.stage: Exaggerating the waiter 's Saxonian accent .
lg.l: Tell me , are you from
Dresden , maybe ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Meissen is my native city .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: As before .Good Lord A'mighty , is that so indeed ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: How do I get out of here , tell me that !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Alert , mobile , and coquettish in her way in the waiter 's presence .You has to go back up the stairs . We has no use down here for your swallow tails .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: This is the first story , eh ? Best part o ’ the house ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You mean the kennels or somethin ’ like that ? We 'll show you — that we will ! The very best people live down here !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Intimately and flirtatiously .Young woman , do you know what ? You come along an ’ show me the way ? With you I would n't be a bit afraid , no matter where you lead me to . I 'd go into the cellar with you or up into the hay loft either .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You stay out o ’ here ! You 're the right kind you are ! We 've got enough of your sort without you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Young woman , do you want me to help with the washin ’ ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: No ! But if you 're aimin ’ at it exackly , I c'n help you to get along !Half drawing a piece of linen out of the suds .Then you 'd be lookin ’ to see where your starched shirt-front went to !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: O dear ! You 're not goin ’ to mess me up that way , are you ? Well , well , that would n't do ! We 'd have to have a talk about that first ! That so , young woman ? Well , o ’ course ! We 'll talk about it — when I has time , later .

div.stage: He mounts the stairs and disappears .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: He wo n't lose his way very often after this ! Siebenhaar will see to it that he gets to know the way from the dining hall to the kitchen .— Hanne , when is Henschel coming back ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: About noon , I s'pose ! D'you want me to give him a message ?

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Tell him — do n't forget , now — tell him that I — send him my regards .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Such foolishness . I might ha ’ thought ...!

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Passing her with a slight bow .Thoughts are free ... I wish you a good morning .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Alone , washing vigorously .If only Henschel was n't such a fool ! Above the cellar , outside , the pedlar FABIG , kneeling down , looks in at the window .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , young woman ! How are you ? How 's everythin ’ ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Who are you anyhow ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Why — Fabig , from Quolsdorf . Do n't you know me no more ? I 'm bringin ’ you a greetin ’ from your father . An ’ he wants me to tell you ... Or maybe you 'd want me to come in ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Aw , I know . I believe you . He wants money again . Well , I has none myself .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: I told him that myself . He would n't believe me . Are you all alone , young woman ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Why d'you ax ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Lowering his voice .Well now you see , there 's more'n one thing I has on my heart . An ’ , through the window , people might be hearin ’ it .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Oh well , I do n't care . You c'n come in !FABIG disappears from the window .That that feller had to be comin ’ to-day ...!

div.stage: She dries her hands .

sp.speaker: FABIG enters . He is a poorly clad , strangely agile , droll pedlar ,
sp.p: with a sparse beard , about thirty-six years old .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: A good mornin ’ to you , young woman .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Fiercely .First of all , I 'm no young woman but a girl .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: With cunning .Maybe so . But from all I hears you 'll be married soon .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: That 's nothin ’ but a pack o ’ mean lies — that 's what it is .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Well , that 's what I heard . It 's no fault o ’ mine . People is sayin ’ it all over ; because Mrs. Henschel died ...

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Well , they can talk for all I care . I does my work . That 's all that concerns me .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: That 's the best way . I does that way myself . There 's little that folks has n't said about me some time ... In Altwasser they says I steals pigeons . A little dog ran after me ... o ’ course , they said I stole it .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Well now , if you got anythin ’ to say to me , go ahead an ’ do n't waste words .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Now you see , there you are . That 's what I always says too . People talks a good deal more'n they ought to . They has a few rags to sell an ’ they talks an ’ talks as if it was an estate . But I 'll say just as little as possible . What I wants to tell you about , young woman — now do n't fly up : the word just slipped out !— I meant to say : lass — what I wants to tell you about is your daughter .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Violently .I has no daughter , if you want to know it . The girl that father is takin ’ care of , is my sister 's child .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Well now , that 's different , that is . We 've all been thinkin ’ the girl was yours . Where is your sister ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Who knows where she is ? She 's not fool enough to tell us . She thinks , thinks she : they c'n have the trouble an ’ see how they gets along .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Well , well , well ! There you see again how folks is mistaken . I 'd ha ’ taken any oath ... an ’ not me , not me alone , but all the folks over in Quolsdorf , that you was the mother o ’ that child .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Yes , I knows right well who says that o ’ me . I could call ‘ em all by name ! They 'd all like to make a common wench o ’ me . But if ever I lays my hands on ‘ em I 'll give ‘ em somethin ’ to remember me by .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Well , it 's a bad business — all of it ! Because this is the way it is : the old man , your father , I need n't be tellin ’ you — things is as they is — he do n't hardly get sober . He just drinks in one streak . Well , now that your mother 's been dead these two years , he can n't leave the little thing — the girl I mean — at home no more . The bit o ’ house is empty . An ’ so he drags her around in the pubs , in all kinds o ’ holes , from one village taproom to the next . If you sees that — it 's enough to stir a dumb beast with pity .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: With fierce impatience .Is it my fault that he swills ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: By no means an ’ not at all . Nobody c'n keep your old man from doin ’ his way ! ‘ Tis only on account o ’ the child , an ’ it 's that makes a body feel sorry . But if that there little one can n't be taken away from him an ’ given in the care o ’ decent folks , she wo n't live no ten weeks after this .

lg.stage: Hardening herself .
lg.l: That do n't concern me . I can n't take her . I got all
I can do to get along !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: You 'd better come over to Quolsdorf some time an ’ look into it all . That 'd be best , too . The little girl ... ‘ tis a purty little thing , with bits o ’ hands an ’ feet like that much porcelain , so dainty an ’ delicate .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: She 's not my child an ’ she do n't concern me .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Well , you better come over an ’ see what 's to be done . It 's hard for people to see such things goin ’ on . If a man goes into an inn , in the middle of the night or some time like that — I got to do that , you see , in the way o ’ business — an ’ sees her sittin ’ there with the old man in the midst o ’ tobacco smoke — I tell you it hurts a body 's soul .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: The innkeepers ought n't to serve him nothin ’ . If they was to take a stick an ’ beat him out o ’ their places , maybe he 'd learn some sense .— A waggon 's just come into the yard . Here you got a sixpence . Now you get along an ’ I 'll be thinkin ’ it all over . I can n't do nothin ’ about it this minute . But if you goes aroun ’ here in the inns an ’ talks about it — then it 's all over between us .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: I 'll take good care , an ’ it do n't concern me . If it 's your child or your sister 's child — I 'm not goin ’ to poke my nose in the parish register , nor I 'm not goin ’ to say nothin ’ neither . But if you want a bit o ’ good advice ,' tis this : Tell Henschel straight out how ‘ tis . He wo n't tear your head off by a long way !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: With increasing excitement as HENSCHEL 'S voice grows more clearly audible .Oh this here jabberin ’ ! It 's enough to drive you crazy .

div.stage: Exit into the adjoining room .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL enters slowly and seriously . He wears a black suit , a top
sp.p: hat and white knitted gloves .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Remains standing and looks at FABIG with an expression of slow recollection . Simply and calmly .Who are you ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Alertly .I buy rags , waste paper , furniture , cast off clothes , anythin ’ that happens to be aroun ’ .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: After a long glance , good-naturedly but with decision .Out with the fellow !

sp.speaker: FABIG withdraws with an embarrassed smile
sp.p: HENSCHEL

div.stage: Takes off his top-hat and wipes his forehead and neck with a manicoloured handkerchief . Thereupon , he places his hat on the table and speaks toward the door of the next room :] Girl , where are you ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I 'm with Gustel here in the little room .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: All right . I c'n wait .He sits down with a sigh that is almost a groan .Yes , yes , O Lord — a man has his troubles .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Enters busily .The dinner 'll be ready this minute .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I can n't eat ; I 'm not hungry .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Eatin ’ and drinkin ’ keeps body an ’ soul together . I was once in service with a shepherd , an ’ he said to us more'n one time : If a body has a heartache or somethin ’ like that , even if he feels no hunger , ‘ tis best to eat .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , cook your dinner an ’ we 'll see .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You should n't give in to it . Not as much as all that . You got to resign yourself some time .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Was that man Horand , the bookbinder , here ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Everythin 's attended to . He made forty new billheads . There they are on the chest .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Then the work an ’ the worry begins again . Drivin ’ in to Freiburg mornin ’ after mornin ’ an ’ noon after noon haulin ’ sick people across the hills .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You 're doin ’ too much o ’ the work yourself . Old Hauffe is too slow by half . I can n't help it — if I was you I 'd get rid o ’ him .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Gets up and goes to the window .I 'm sick of it — of the whole haulin ’ business . It c'n stop for all I care . I got nothin ’ against it if it does . To-day or to-morrow ; it 's the same to me . All you got to do is to take the horses to the flayers , to chop up the waggons for kindlin ’ wood , an ’ to get a stout , strong bit o ’ rope for yourself .— I think I 'll go up an ’ see Siebenhaar .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I was wantin ’ to say somethin ’ to you when I got a chance .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , what is it , eh ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You see , it 's not easy for me . No , indeed .Elaborately tearful .But my brother — he needs me that bad .Weeping .I 'll have to leave — that 's sure .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In extreme consternation .You 're not right in your mind . Do n't start that kind o ’ business !

sp.speaker: HANNE , shedding crocodile tears , holds her apron to her eyes
sp.p: HENSCHEL Well now , look here , lass : you 're not goin ’ to play me that kind of a trick now ! That would be fine ! Who 's goin ’ to manage the house ? Summer 's almost with us now an ’ you want to leave me in the lurch ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: With the same gesture .‘ Tis the little one I feels sorry for !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: If you do n't take care of her , who 's goin ’ to ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: After a space collecting herself apparently by an effort of the will . Quietly :It can n't be done no different .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Everythin ’ c'n be done in this world . All you needs is to want to do it .— You never said nothin ’ about it before . An ’ now , suddenly , you talk about your brother !— Maybe I been offendin ’ you some way ? Do n't you feel suited with me no more ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: There 's no end to the gossip that 's goin ’ round .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What kind o ’ gossip ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know . I 'd rather be goin out o ’ the way of it .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'd like to know just what you mean !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I does my work an ’ I takes my pay ! An ’ I wo n't have nobody say such things o ’ me . When the wife was still alive I worked all day ; now that she 's dead , I do n't do no different . People c'n say all they wants to ; I 'm tryin ’ to make you think I 'm fine , an ’ I want dead people 's shoes . I 'd rather go into service some other place .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Relieved .You need n't say no more if that 's all it is !

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Takes up some piece of work as an excuse for leaving the room .No , no , I 'll go . I can n't never stay !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Talking after her .You c'n let people talk an ’ not say much yourself . All them tongues has to wag for an occupation .He takes off his black coat and hangs it up . Sighing .The pack o ’ troubles do n't get no smaller .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR comes in slowly . He carries a decanter full of water and
sp.p: a glass .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Good morning , Henschel .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Good mornin ’ Mr. Siebenhaar ,

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Am I disturbing you ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Not a bit ; not at all . You 're very welcome .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Placing the decanter and the glass on the table .I 've got to drink the medicinal spring water again . I 'm having that old trouble with my throat . Well , dear me , a man has to die of something !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You must just go ahead an ’ drink the waters . They 'll cure you .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Yes , that 's just what I 'm doing .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ not from the Mill Spring nor from the Upper Spring . Ours is the best .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well now , to change the subject .Half lost in thought he has been toying with a sprig of ivy . Now he observes this , starts slightly , runs his eyes over the top-hat and HENSCHEL himself and says suddenly :This was your wife 's birthday , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: She 'd ha ’ been thirty-six years old to-day .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Is it possible ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , yes , yes .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , I 'd better leave you alone now . But when it 's agreeable to you — to-morrow maybe , I 'd like to talk over some business with you .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'd rather you went ahead right now .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: It 's about the thousand crowns ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Before we says any more , Mr. Siebenhaar . You c'n just keep that money till winter . Why should I be lyin ’ to you ? You see ? I do n't need the money . I do n't care exackly when I gets it ; an ’ that it 's safe , I 'm satisfied o ’ that .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , Henschel , in that case I 'm very grateful to you . You 're doing me a great favour . During the summer I take in money ; you know that . Just now it would have been difficult for me .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , you see , so we c'n agree fine .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Walking to and fro .Yes , yes , I sometimes wonder over myself . I grew up in this house . And yet , to-day , if I could but make a decent closing out , I could leave it quite calmly .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I would n't like to go , I must say . I would n't hardly know where to go to .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Things have moved ahead with you , Henschel . But the same set of conditions that has counted in your favour , has been that against which I 've had to struggle to keep my head above water .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: The shoe pinches one man in this place an ’ another man in that . Who 's goin ’ to say which is worse off ? You see , I got a good , hard blow , too . An ’ if I 'm goin ’ to recover ... well , I do n't hardly feel like myself yet .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , there 's a time for everything ! You 'll have to conquer that now . You must go out among people , hear things , see things , drink a glass of beer once in a while , plunge into business , perhaps — somehow , put an end to this sad business . It can n't be helped , and so — forward !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis just as you say ! You 're quite right !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: To be sure , your wife was the best , most faithful woman . There 's only one opinion about that . But you are in the full current of life , Henschel ; you 're in your best years ; you still have a great deal to do in the world : who knows how much . You need n't forget your wife on that account ; on the contrary . And that 's entirely out of the question in the case of a man like you . But you must honour her memory in a saner way . This kind of brooding does no good . I 've been watching you for a good while and I determined , without saying anything , to make a really strong appeal to you one day . You 're letting yourself be actually downed .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: But what 's a man to do against it ? You 're right — that you are ; but times I hardly know what to do ! You say : Plunge into business . But there 's somethin ’ lackin ’ all around . Four eyes sees better'n two ; four hands — they c'n do a sight more . Now I got all these coaches here in the summer ! An ’ there 's no one to see to things at home ! ‘ Tis not easy , I c'n tell you that .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I thought that Hanne was quite a capable girl .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , you see , she 's given me notice , too .— ‘ Tis too hard for a man to get along without a wife . Yon can n't depend on no one . That 's just it ; that 's just what I says !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Why do n't you marry , Henschel ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Twould be best !— What c'n I do without a wife ? A man like me can n't get along without one . I was thinking in fact , of goin ’ upstairs an ’ askin ’ the missis if , maybe , she could give me some advice in that direction . She died an ’ left me alone in the midst of all these worries .— An ’ , also , to tell you the truth , this business of mine 's not what it used to be . How long is it goin ’ to be before the railroad comes here ? Well , you see , we 'd put by a little , an ’ we wanted to buy a small inn — maybe in two years or so . Well , that can n't be done without a woman neither .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: True . You wo n't be able to get along this way permanently . You can n't remain a widower the rest of your life . If for no other reason but for the child 's sake .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's what I always says .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Of course I have no right to interfere in your affairs . Still , we 're old friends . To wait , Henschel , just on account of what people will think — that 's sheer nonsense , no more , no less . If you are quite seriously thinking of marrying again , it would be better both for you and for the child if you did it soon . You need n't be overhasty ; assuredly not ! But if you 've quite made up your mind , then — go straight ahead ! Why should you hesitate ?After a pause during which HENSCHEL scratches his head .Have you any one particular in view ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — If I got some one in view ? That 's what you 'd like to know ? Maybe I has . Only I can n't marry her .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: But why not ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You know it yourself .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I ? I know it ? How 's that ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: All you got to do is a little thinkin ’ .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Shaking his head .I can n't say that I recall at this moment .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Did n't I have to go an ’ promise my wife ...

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: ———?— Oh , yes ! !— You mean the girl — Hanne ?—

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I been thinkin ’ an ’ thinkin ’ . There 's no use in denyin ’ it . When I wakes up during the night , I can n't sleep for a couple o ’ hours sometimes . I got to be thinkin ’ of it all the time . I can n't get over it any way !— The girl 's a good girl . She 's a bit young for an old fellow like me , but she c'n work enough for four men . An ’ she 's taken very kindly to Gustel ; no mother could do more'n she . An ’ the girl 's got a head on her , that 's sure , better'n mine . She c'n do sums better'n I can . She might go an ’ be a calculator . She knows a bit o ’ business to the last farthing , even if six weeks have come an ’ gone since . I believe she could make a fool o ’ two lawyers .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , if you 're so thoroughly convinced of all that ...!

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: There would n't be no better wife for me ! An ’ yet ... an ’ yet ! I can n't get over it .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I do remember quite dimly now what you mean . It was quite at the end of her life .— But I confess to you quite frankly : I did n't take that matter so very seriously . Your wife was in a very excited condition . And that was caused largely by her illness .— I can n't think that that is the main question . The real question must finally be whether Hanne is really suitable for you ! She has her advantageous qualities : no doubt about that . There are things about her that I like less . However : who has n't some faults . People say that she has a child .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That she has . I 've inquired . Well , even so . I do n't care nothin ’ about that . Was she to wait for me , eh ? She did n't know nothin ’ about me when that happened . She 's hot-blooded ; all right . That 'll come out somehow . When the pears is ripe , they falls to the ground . On that account — no , that do n't trouble me none .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , then ! The other matter is trivial . Perhaps not trivial exactly . I can well understand how it 's taken hold of you . Still , one must get free of it . To be bound by it , in spite of one 's saner thought — that 's clearly folly , Henschel .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 've said that to myself ten times over . You see , my wife she did n't never want anythin ’ but what was for my best good . I mean , in the days when she was well . She would n't want to stand in my way . Wherever she is , maybe , she 'd want to see me get along .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Assuredly .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , I went out to her grave to-day . The missis had a wreath put there too . I thought to myself I 'd better go there , that 's what I thought . Maybe she 'll be sendin ’ you some message . Mother , I said in my thoughts , give me a sign . Yes or no ! Anyway you answers , that way it 'll be ! An ’ I stood , there half an hour .— I prayed , too , an ’ I put it all to her — just to myself , o ’ course — about the child an ’ the inn an ’ that I do n't know what to do in my business — but she did n't give me no sign .

sp.speaker: HANNE enters throwing sidelong glances at the two men , but at once
sp.p: going energetically to work . She puts the washbench and tub aside and busies herself at the stove .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: To HENSCHEL .God give the dead peace and blessedness . You are a man ; you 're in the midst of life . Why should you need signs and miracles ? We can find our way in this world by depending with fair certainty on our reason . You simply go your way . You 're captain on your own ship . Overboard with all these fancies and sickly notions ! The more I think of your plan , the more rational it seems to me ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hanne , what do you say about it ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I do n't know . How c'n I tell what you 're talkin ’ about ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You just wait : I 'll tell you later .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , good morning , Henschel . I 'll see you later . Meanwhile — good luck !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'll hope I 'll have it .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I 'm not worried about you . You had a lucky way with you always .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yon should n't be sayin ’ it ! ‘ Tis bad luck .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: If you spits three times , it 'll take the curse off .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I can n't help thinkin ’ as you 're too good .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What makes you think so ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: People just robs you : that 's what I says .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Did you think he wanted somethin ’ of me ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Well , what else ? He ought to be ashamed to come beggin ’ o ’ poor people .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hanne , you do n't know what you 're sayin ’ .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: I knows well enough .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's what you do n't . An ’ you could n't know . But some day , later on , you 'll come to understand .— Now I 'll be goin ’ to the taproom an ’ buy me a mug o ’ beer . It 'll be the first time these eight weeks . After that we c'n eat , an ’ after the dinner then — listen to me — then we might say a word to each other . Then we c'n see how everythin ’ c'n be straightened out .— Or , maybe , you do n't care about it ?

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: You was sayin ’ yourself : We c'n see .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ that 's what I says now . We c'n wait .

div.stage: Exit .
Pause .

sp.speaker: HANNE
sp.p: Works on undisturbed . When HENSCHEL is out of hearing , she suddenly ceases , scarcely mastering her joyous excitement , she dries her hands and tears off her apron . In involuntary triumph :I 'll show you . Watch out !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE THIRD ACT The same room as tn the two preceding acts . It is evening toward the end of November . A fire is burning in the oven ; a lighted candle stands on the table . The middle door is closed . Muffled dance music penetrates into the room from the upper stories of the house .

sp.speaker: HANNE , now MRS. HENSCHEL , sits by the table and knits ; she is neatly
sp.p: and suitably clad in a dress of blue cotton , and wears a red kerchief across her breast .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT , the smith , enters . A small , sinewy person

lg.l: HILDEBRANT
Good evenin ’ , missis , where 's your husband ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Gone to Breslau . He 's fetchin ’ three new horses .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: Then I s'pose he wo n't be comin ’ home to-day , eh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Not before Monday .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: Well , this is Saturday .— We 've brought back the board waggon . It 's downstairs in the entry way . We had to renew all the four tires . Where 's Hauffe ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: He has n't been with us this long time .

lg.l: So he has n't . ‘ Tis nonsense I 'm talkin ’ . I mean the new servant . Is
Schwarzer here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: He 's gone along to Breslau .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: Fact is I knows all about Hauffe . He comes down to the smithy an ’ just stands aroun ’ . He 's got nothin ’ to do yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: People says he 's beginnin ’ to drink .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: I believes it . That 's the way it goes . ‘ Tis bad for an old fellow like that ; nobody wants him now .— What 's goin ’ on up there to-day ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Dancin ’ !

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: How 'd it be if we was to go up there too , missis . Why should n't we be joinin ’ in a little waltz too ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: They 'd open their eyes pretty wide up there if we did .— But what is it you want of Henschel ?

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: His honour , the judge , has a chestnut stallion that do n't want to let hisself be shoed . So we wanted to ax Henschel to step over . If he can n't get any beast to stand still , why then —! Well , good evenin ’ , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Good evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT withdraws
sp.p: MRS. HENSCHEL .

div.stage: Listens to a dragging noise out in the passage . ] What kind of a noise is that there ? [ She steps forward and opens the door . ] Who 's makin ’ all that racket out there ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Comes dancing in .Get out of the way , Mrs. Henschel ! I have no time .

div.stage: She whirls about in the room to the measure of the waltz heard from above .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , this is a fine way to act ! What 's the matter with you ? Did a mad dog bite you , maybe ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA dances on and hums the melody of the waltz
sp.p: MRS. HENSCHEL

div.stage: More and more amused . ] For heaven 's sake ! Somethin 's goin ’ to happen to you !— No , girl , you 're goin ’ clear out o ’ your mind !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Sinks exhausted into a chair as the music breaks off .Oh , Mrs. Henschel , I could dance myself to death !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Laughing .At this here rate I believes you ! It makes a body feel dizzy just to watch you .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Do n't you dance at all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Me ? If I dance ? To be sure I do . ‘ Twas n't once or twice only that I got a pair o ’ new shoes an ’ danced ‘ em to pieces in one night !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Come and dance with me then !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Why do n't you go upstairs an ’ dance with the folks there ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Oh , if only I might ! Do you know what I 'll do ? I 'll sneak up ! I 'll sneak into the gallery ! Have you ever been up there ? The bags of prunes stand up there . I go up there quite boldly and look down , and eat prunes . Why should n't I look down from there ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ maybe Siebenhaar 'll send for you to come down .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I just stare down as bold as you please . I do n't care a bit . And whenever a lady dances with Mr. Siebenhaar , I pelt her with plum pits .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're crazy about Siebenhaar — that 's certain !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Well , he 's a real swell — that 's what none of the others are .The music is heard again .Ah , they 're starting . That 's a polka !Dancing again .I 'd like to dance with Mr. Siebenhaar this minute . D'you know what I 'd do ? I 'd just kiss him before he knew what was happening .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Siebenhaar 'd be too old for me !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Your husband is just as old , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Look here , girl , I want you to know that my husband is a good five years younger .
