lg.l: Well , he looks much older anyhow . Why , he looks so old and wrinkled . No ,
I would n't care to kiss him .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You better see about getting out o ’ here , or I 'll take a broom an ’ help you along ! Do n't you abuse my husband ! An ’ where would I get a better one ? You wait till you 're a few years older an ’ you 'll see what it means in this world to have a husband !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I wo n't marry at all . I 'll wait till some fine , rich gentleman comes — some summer — for his health — a Russian , by preference — and then I 'll let him take me out into the world . I want to see the world — to wander far — I want to go to Paris . And then I 'll write you about myself , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do believe you 'll run off some day !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: You can wager anything that I will . Mr. Siebenhaar was in Paris , too , you know , during the revolution in ‘ forty-eight , and he can tell you the most interesting stories ! Oh , I 'd like to see a revolution like that some day too . They build barricades ...

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH 'S VOICE
sp.p: Franziska ! Franziska ! Where are you keeping yourself again ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Sh ! Do n't say anything !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH 'S VOICE
sp.p: Franziska ! Franziska !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Sh ! Keep still ! He wants me to serve at the bar . And that 's horrid and I wo n't do it !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH 'S VOICE
sp.p: Franziska !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: It 's papa 's or mama 's place to do that . Or they can hire a waiter . I wo n't be turned into a bar maid .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's not the worst kind o ’ thing !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Oh , if there were real gentlemen to serve ! But they 're just well — attendants , coachmen and miners . Much obliged for such company ! I do n't care about it !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If I was you , I 'd do that reel easy . An ’ I 'd be gettin ’ good tips . You could save a good many pennies an ’ put by a nice sum .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I wo n't accept pennies and farthings . And if some time Mr. Siebenhaar or the architect or Dr. Valentiner gives me a present , I spend it on sweetmeats right away .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Ah , that 's just it . You 're your father 's daughter . An ’ your mother was n't much different neither . You people do n't take care o ’ the business you has ! If you 'd ha ’ done so you 'd have money out at interest this day .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: We 're not as stingy as you , that 's all .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm not stingy . But you got to keep your substance together .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: People say you 're stingy , though !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: People c'n be —! An ’ you too ! Hurry now an ’ get out o ’ here ! I 'm sick o ’ your jabberin ’ now ! An ’ you do n't need to come back here neither ! I have n't been longin ’ for you , exackly ! ‘ Tis best not to see or hear anything o ’ the whole crowd o ’ you .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Turning once more at the door , with angry malice .Do you know what else people say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't want to know nothin ’ ! Get out o ’ here ! You look out that you do n't get to hear things about yourself ! Who knows what 's between you an ’ Siebenhaar ? You two knows it an ’ I knows it too . Otherwise you 'd ha ’ been kicked out twenty times over with your slovenly management ! Teach me to know Siebenhaar !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Fy , fy and fy again !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: The baggage ! The middle door has remained open . SIEBENHAAR and the waiter GEORGE , coming from different directions along the passage way , are seen to meet at the door . GEORGE affects the height of Vienna fashions — hat , cane , long overcoat , gay tie .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: What are you after here ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 'll forgive me but I have some business with Drayman Henschel .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel is not at home . You 've been told three times now that there is no place for you in my house . If you can n't remember that henceforth I shall be compelled to have your memory assisted by — the constable .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I beg your pardon very humbly , Mr. Siebenhaar , but I begs to submit that I do n't come to see you . These people lives in your house . An ’ you can n't prove nothin ’ as touchin ’ the question of my honour .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Very well . Only , if I should meet you again I 'll have the porter kick you out . So you had better act accordingly .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Enters the room cursing .I 'll take that there risk ! We 'll see about that later !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Closes the door , with difficulty mastering her rage toward SIEBENHAAR .We 're here , too , I 'd have him know . Just let him try it ! This here is our room , not his room , an ’ anybody that comes here comes to us an ’ not to him ! He 's got no right to say nothin ’ about it !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We 'll just wait an ’ see — that 's all I says . He might have to pay good an ’ dear for that . That kind o ’ thing takes a man to the pen . He got hisself into a nasty mess with Alphonse , who was here two years ago . But he 'd be gettin ’ into a worse mess with me . A hundred crowns o ’ damages 'd be too little for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ he has n't got no hundred crowns in his pocket — the damned bankrupt ! He 's been borrowing of everybody in the county . He 's got nothin ’ but debts ; you hear that on all sides . ‘ Two n't be long before there wo n't be nothin ’ left an ’ he 'll have to leave the house hisself instead o ’ puttin ’ other people out of it !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Has recovered his overcoat , hung up his hat , and is now picking off the little feathers from his coat and trousers .That 's right ! An ’ that 's no secret to nobody . Even the people that come here year in an ’ out says the same . An ’ nobody is sorry for him ; no , they 're willin ’ it should happen to him . My present boss , he can n't stand him neither . He gets reel venomous if you so much as mention Siebenhaar 's name .Takes a pocket-mirror and comb from his pocket and smooths his hair .Lord knows , he says , there 's more tricks to that man than a few .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I believes that ; I s'ppose he 's right there .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Now then , Hanne , has you got somethin ’ warm for me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Why did n't you come yesterday ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You thinks I c'n get off every day , do n't you ? ‘ Twas hard enough to get to come here to-day ! Yesterday I was busy till three o'clock in the mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What was it happened ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There was a meetin ’ o ’ the fire board . They bought a new engine , an ’ so they wanted to celebrate the purchase . That 's how they came to have a meetin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: All they wants is an excuse to swill . An ’ all that while I sat till late at night and waited . Once — I do n't know , but it must ha ’ been a bird flyin ’ against the window — I thought ‘ twas you , an ’ so I went to the window an ’ opened it . After that I was that mad , I could n't sleep half the night .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , pshaw ! What 's the use o ’ havin ’ things like that spoil one 's temper .He puts his arms around her .That 's nothin ’ ! Nothin ’ at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Frees herself from his embrace .Oh , I do n't know ! ‘ Tis true — I do n't know how it comes — but things seem to go contrary with a body . Henschel sits aroun ’ at home the whole week , an ’ now that he 's gone for a bit , we has to let the time slide away !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , we got plenty o ’ time to-day . He do n't come back till Monday , I thought .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who knows if it 's true !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know no reason why it should n't be true !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That man is bound to sit aroun ’ at home . ‘ Twas n't half as bad formerly . He used to go on trips weeks at a time ; nowadays he whines if he 's got to sleep away from home a single night . An ’ if he says : I 'll stay three days , he mostly comes back on the second — Listen ... I believe they 've come already ! Who else 'd be crackin ’ whips like that in the yard ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: After he has listened , in a restrained tone :The devil take ‘ em all — the whole damned crowd ! A man has n't had time to get warm a bit . I s'pose I 'll have to leave right off , eh ? I thought it 'd be mighty different , I must say !

div.stage: He slips his overcoat back on and takes up his hat .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Tears his hat from his head .You stay right here ! What d'you want to run off for ? D'you think I got to be scared o ’ Henschel . He 's got to come to my terms . I do n't has to think about him . If you 'd come yesterday !— I told you ...! Then nobody would n't ha ’ interrupted us , no Henschel an ’ no Siebenhaar . To-day the devil 's broke loose ! The horse dealer WALTHER enters — a handsome , vigorous fellow of forty . Bashly cap , fur jacket , hunting stockings and tall boots ; his mits are fastened by cords .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Missis , your husband is outside in the yard . I 'm just comin ’ in for a minute to bid you good evenin ’ . I got to ride off again straight way . He 's bought some fine Flemish horses . An ’ he 's brought along something else , for you too .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I thought he would n't be comin ’ back till Monday .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: An ’ that 's the way it would ha ’ been . But we could n't ride on horseback no farther'n Kanth . There we had to take the train with the horses or they 'd ha ’ broken their necks an ’ their limbs . Travellin ’ was that bad on account o ’ the sleet .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You makes better time with the train — that 's certain !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: What kind of a feller is that there ? Why , you 're tryin ’ to be invisible , eh ? Well , if that is n't little George — I do believe ! Why , you looks like a natural born baron !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: A man earns more over there in the “ Star ” hotel . I has a much more profitable position . Here I had to work till my clothes dropped from me in rags . I was most naked in the end ; now I 'm beginnin ’ to buy somethin ’ again .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Now guess , missis , what your husband has brought home for you !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , what is it ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I wager you 'll be mighty glad of that present !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: We 'll see . It depends on what it is .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Good luck to you then . I got to hurry or my wife 'll get ugly .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Good luck to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I might as well come along . Good night , Mrs. Henschel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Did n't you want to see Henschel about somethin ’ ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There 's plenty o ’ time for that . There 's no hurry .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: If you got somethin ’ to say to him you 'd better wait till to-morrow . He 's got different kinds o ’ things in his mind to-day . D'you know what he 's bringin ’ you , missis ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What should he be bringin ’ me ? Do n't talk so much nonsense .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Why , he 's bringin ’ you your daughter !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: — What 's that he 's bringin ’ ? I did n't hear right !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: We was in Quolsdorf and fetched her .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're drunk , the two o ’ ye , eh ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: No , no , I 'm tellin ’ you the truth .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who did you get ?

lg.l: He did n't tell me nothin ’ about it . All of a sudden we was in the pub at
Quolsdorf an ’ sat down there .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , an ’ what then ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: We was sittin ’ there an ’ then , after a little while , your father came in with the bit of a girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis no girl o ’ mine !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I do n't know nothin ’ about that ! I knows this much though : he 's got the child out there . He went up to your father an ’ he said : The child 's a pretty child .— Then he took her in his arms an ’ petted her . Shall I take you with me , he axes her , an ’ she was willin ’ right off .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , an ’ my father ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Well , your father did n't know who Henschel was !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Better an ’ better ! An ’ is that all ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Almost addressing GEORGE now .No , there was nothin ’ more . He just took the little one out an ’ said to your father : I 'll let the lass ride horseback . An ’ she kept cryin ’ out : Lemme ride ! Lemme ride ! Then Henschel mounted his great Flemish horse an ’ I had to hand the child up to him . After that he said : Good-bye , an ’ rode off .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ father just stood there an ’ looked on ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: What was he goin ’ to do about it ? The whole village might ha ’ turned out for all the good it would ha ’ done . When once Henschel lays his hands on somethin ’ — I would n't advise nobody to cross him ! An ’ there 's no one in the county that likes to pick a quarrel with him neither ! Your father , he did n't know what was goin ’ on . Then suddenly , o ’ course , he roared like fury an ’ cried out an ’ cursed more'n enough . But the people just laughed . They knew Henschel . An ’ he — Henschel — he just said reel quiet : Good luck to you , father Schael ; I 'm takin ’ her along . The mother is waitin ’ for her at home . Stop drinkin ’ ! he said , an ’ maybe there 'll be a place with us for you some day , too .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good-bye , I think I 'll maybe drop in to-morrow .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ so he thinks I 'm goin ’ to keep her here . I 'll never do that — never in the world . She 's no child o ’ mine ! How would I be lookin ’ before people ? First in Quolsdorf , then here ! Did n't I work an ’ worry enough ? Day an ’ night , you might say , I was busy with Gustel . An ’ now the weary trouble is to begin all over again . That 'd be fine , would n't it ? He 'd better take care !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL appears in the middle door . He is also clad in leathern
sp.p: breeches , fur jacket , tall boots , etc ., just as he has dismounted . He leads by the hand a little girl of six — ragged and unwashed .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Almost merrily referring to HANNE 'S last words , which he has overheard .Who 's to take care ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: — Oh , I do n't know !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Look , Hanne , look who comes here !To the child .Go ahead , Berthel , an ’ say good evenin ’ . Go on an ’ say it ! Say : Good evenin ’ , mama !

sp.speaker: BERTHEL leaving HENSCHEL unwillingly and walks , encouraged by
sp.p: friendly little shoves from him , diagonally across the room to where HANNE , assuming a disgruntled attitude , sits on the bench .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: To the child , who stands helplessly before her .What do you want here ?

sp.speaker: BERTHEL
sp.p: I rode on such a pitty horsie ?

lg.l: HENSCHEL
Well now we 'll keep her here . Hallo , Hanne ! Are you angry about anythin ’ ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You are sayin ’ you would n't be back till Monday . There 's not a bite for supper in the house now .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: There 'll be a bit o ’ bread an ’ bacon .

div.stage: He hangs up his cap .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Pulling ungently at BERTHEL 'S clothes .How 'd you get this way ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 'll soon have to buy her somethin ’ to put on ! She 's got hardly nothin ’ on her little body . ‘ Twas a good thing I had plenty o ’ blankets along , or she 'd ha ’ been half froze on the way .After he has removed his fur jacket and warmed his hands .Best thing would be to put her right straight in a tub .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Best thing would ha ’ been if you 'd ha ’ left her where she was .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What did you say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I thought you were sayin ’ somethin ’ .— Into the tub with her ! An ’ then to bed ! An ’ you might go over her head a bit ! I believe she 's got a little colony there .BERTHEL cries out .What 's the matter ? Do n't tug at her so rough !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , do n't cry , girl ! That 'd be the last straw !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You must be a bit friendly with her . The lass is thankful for every kind word . Be quiet , Berthel , be quiet !

sp.speaker: BERTHEL
sp.p: I want to go to father !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're with mother now ! Mother is good !— I 'm reel satisfied that we has her with us . ‘ Twas the highest time . A bit longer an ’ we might ha ’ had to look for her in the graveyard .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That was n't half as bad as you 're tryin ’ to make out .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In some consternation but still kindly .What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Well , good luck to you all . I 'll have to be goin ’ .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Wait a bit an ’ drink a glass o ’ toddy .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If there were only some rum in the house !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , you can fetch it from Wermelskirch 's !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't want to have nothin ’ to do with those people !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: No , no . I got to go home . I got no time . I got to be ridin ’ half an hour yet .To HANNE .I do n't want to be a bother to you .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who mentioned such a thing ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Humorously .Nothin ’ ! I did n't say nothin ’ at all . God forbid ! I wo n't let myself in for nothin ’ . You 're a hard customer . Good-bye an ’ good luck !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Good-bye , an ’ do n't forget a greetin ’ to the wife !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Already from outside .All right ! Good night ! I wo n't forget nothin ’ .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , did n't I do the right thing this time ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What is I to say to people ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — You 're not goin ’ to be ashamed o ’ your own daughter !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who 's sayin ’ I is , eh ? ‘ Tis all the same to me ! You 're willin ’ to have ‘ em say evil o ’ me . You force ‘ em to it !Harshly to the child .Here , drink this milk ! An ’ then off to bed with you !BERTHEL drinks .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Are you goin ’ to go on this way ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Go on how ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: With the child !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm not goin ’ to bite her ; there 's no fear !

div.stage: She takes the still weeping child into the little room to bed .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Speaking after her .She 's not here to be bitten . I need n't ha ’ brought her , you know !

div.stage: A brief pause , after which HANNE returns .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: A man can n't never know how to please you . There 's no gettin ’ along with women folks . You always acted as if ....

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: With tears of rage .That 's a lie if you want to know it !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What 's a lie !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: As above .I never bothered you about Berthel . I never so much as mentioned her to you !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I did n't say you had . Why d'you howl so ? On that account , because you did n't say nothin ’ , I wanted to help you in spite o ’ your silence .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: But could n't you ha ’ asked ? A man ought to say somethin ’ before he does a thing like that !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well now , I 'll tell you somethin ': This is Saturday night . I hurried all I could so 's to be at home again . I thought you 'd meet me different ! But if it 's not to be , it can n't be helped . Only , leave me in peace ! You understand !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Nobody 's robbin ’ you o ’ your peace .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: D'you hear me ? I want my peace an ’ that 's all . You brought me to that point . I did n't think nothin ’ but what was good doin ’ this thing . Gustel is dead . She wo n't come back no more . Her mother took her to a better place . The bed is empty , an ’ we 're alone . Why should n't we take care o ’ the little lass ? That 's the way I thinks an ’ I 'm not her father ! You ought to think so all the more , ‘ cause you 're the child 's mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: There you are ! You 're beginnin ’ to throw it up to me this minute !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: If you do n't stop I 'll go to Wermelskirch an ’ not come back all night ! D'you want to drive me out o ’ the house ?— I 'm always hopin ’ things 'll be different , but they gets worse ... worse ! I thought maybe if you had your child with you , you 'd learn a little sense . If these goin 's on do n't end soon ...

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: All I say is this : If she stays in the house an ’ if you tell people that she 's mine ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: They all know it ! I do n't have to tell ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Then you c'n take your oath on it — I 'll run away !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Run , run all you can — all you want to ! You ought to be ashamed o ’ yourself to the bottom o ’ your heart !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE FOURTH ACT The tap room in WERMELSKIRCH 'S public house . A flat , whitewashed room with a door leading to the inner rooms of the house on the left . The rear wall of this room is broken , toward its middle . The opening leads to a second , smaller , oblong room . On the right wall of this second room there is a glass door leading out into the open and , farther forward , a window . On the rear wall of the main room the bar is situated , filled with square whisky-bottles , glasses , etc . The beer is also on draught there . Highly varnished tables and chairs of cherry wood are scattered about the room . A red curtain divides the two rooms . In the oblong rear room are also chairs and tables and , in the extreme background , a billiard table . Lithographs , representing mainly hunting scenes , are hung on the walls .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH , in a dressing gown and smoking a long pipe , sits on
sp.p: the left , himself playing the piano . Three members of the voluntary fire-corps play billiards . In the foreground to the right HAUFFE sits brooding over a glass of whisky . He is noticeably shabby . MRS. WERMELSKIRCH , a gipsy-like , slovenly old woman , is rinsing glasses behind the bar . FRANZISKA is crouching on a window ledge at the right playing with a kitten . The waiter GEORGE is standing at the bar over a glass of beer . He has an elegant spring suit on , as well as patent-leather shoes , kid-gloves and a top-hat set far back on his head .

lg.stage: Plays and sings .
lg.l: “ When I was prince in realms Arcadian ,
I lived in splendour and in wealth . ”

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Who has accompanied the music by dancing gestures .Go on , go on with , that !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Coughing affectedly .Ca n't be done ! Quite hoarse ! Anyhow ... pshaw !... I 'll try again . “ When I was prince .... ”He coughs .“ When I was prince in realms Arcadian , I lived in splen ... I lived in splen ... “ ! The devil take it !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Aw , why do n't you go on ? That was quite right ! That was fine !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: I see myself trying ! It 's all over with me !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't understand you ! That 's the finest kind o ’ chamber music !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Laughing .Chamber music !

lg.l: Well , maybe not ! I do n't know the differences so well . Hallo , Miss
Franziska , what are you laughin ’ at ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: I 'm laughing at your beautiful patent-leather boots .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Go right ahead ! You do n't expect me to go barefoot . Give that man over there a glass of beer . How would you like a bit o ’ cordial , Miss Franziska ? You 're right , my boots is pretty fine ones . They cost me twenty crowns . Why not ? I c'n stand the expense ; I 'm able to do it ! In the “ Sword ” hotel a man c'n at least earn somethin ’ . To be sure , while I was at the “ Star ” I could n't ha ’ bought no boots like this .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: So you like it better at the “ Sword ” ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I should say so ! A boss like I got now , a reel good fellow — I never had before long 's I 've been in the business . We 're like old friends — like brothers . I could say most anythin ’ to him !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Well , that 's very different from Siebenhaar .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA laughs out
sp.p: GEORGE An ’ that just shows you : Pride goeth before a fall . Two or three weeks an ’ he 'll be under the hammer . Then I c'n buy myself his gold watch .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: You 'd better buy the whole house !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Not just now . You got to wait for the proper time to do a thing like that . An ’ anyhow , it 's sold . Your health , gentlemen !... Your health , gentlemen ! When you 're through , I 'll order more ! What 's the name o ’ the man that bought the house ? Exner ? Eh ? He 's goin ’ to bottle the spring water an ’ export it . He 's goin ’ to rent out the hotel .— I 'd rent it this minute if I had the money .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Why do n't you go to Henschel ? He 'll give it to you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: That would n't be as much out o ’ the question as you thinks .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: No , that a fac ’ ! You 're on pretty good terms with the wife !

div.stage: FRANZISKA laughs aloud .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , why should n't I be . That there woman 's not half bad . I tell you , a fellow that knows how , c'n make the women feed out o ’ his hand !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Well , if you know enough to make Mrs. Henschel feed out o ’ your hand , you must know your business pretty well . I 'll say that for you .

sp.speaker: FABIG enters , the cord of his pack around his shoulders . He sits
sp.p: down modestly in a corner .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , there you are ; that 's what I 'm tellin ’ you ! There 's pretty few that could come up to me that way . But a man has to be on the lookout , or he 'd get a good beatin ’ an ’ that 's all !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Well , you 're not through with it yet yourself .SIEBENHAAR enters from the left .Where Henschel strikes down the grass stops growing . Your servant , Mr. Siebenhaar !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Somewhat pale .Good morning !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I think I 'll play a game o ’ billiards .

div.stage: He takes up his glass and disappears behind the curtain in the rear .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Sitting down at a table near the piano .Were n't you just singing , Mr. Wermelskirch ? Do n't let me interrupt you , please .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: What ? I ? Singing ? That 's hardly possible ! You know how deeply this business affects me . But if you say so it must be true . Permit me to sit down by you . Bring me a glass of beer , too , Franziska !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: When one considers that you were completely hoarse three or four years ago , you must admit that you 've recuperated remarkably .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: You 're quite right . But what good does it do me ? I 've half way crawled out of the slough . But who knows what 'll happen now ?

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Places a glass of beer before SIEBENHAAR ; to WERMELSKIRCH :I 'll bring yours at once .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Having drunk .What do you mean by that , exactly ?

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: I do n't know that I can tell you very exactly what I do mean . But I feel something in my bones . I believe there 'll be a change in the weather . Jesting aside — I have all kinds of omens that are familiar to an old actor . When the waters here began to do me so much good , I knew certainly that ten horses could n't drag me away . And it was n't a month before my road company had gone to smash . Now I suppose I 'll have to wander on in the same old way again — who knows whither ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Who knows whither ? That 's the way of the world . As for me — I 'm not sorry !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Ah , but you 're a man in the prime of life . The world has a place for a man like you everywhere . It 's different with an old fellow like me . If I lose my means of making a living , I mean , if I 'm given notice , what is there left me , I 'd like to know ? I might actually get me a hurdy-gurdy and Franziska could go about and collect the pennies .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: That would n't embarrass me a bit , papa !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Not if it were to rain gold pieces !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: And , anyhow , papa , how you always talk ! You could go back on the stage !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Not even at a monkey-show , girlie !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Did Mr. Exner intimate anything to you ? According to what he told me he meant to leave everything pretty much as it is .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Well , I hardly belong to what could be summed up as “ everything . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Approaching the table in great excitement .I must say , Mr. Siebenhaar , I must say ... And you can take my word for it ! I 'm an old woman of fifty and I 've seen a good deal of the world , but the way we 've been treated here — that 's really — I do n't know what to call it — but it 's just vulgar malice , the lowest kind of scheming , pure meanness . You can take my word for that !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Oh , mother , are you starting in too ? You 'd better withdraw , if you do n't mind , and retire behind your barricade !

sp.speaker: MRS. WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: I 'd like to know what our little Fanny did to that woman !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Oh , never mind , mama !

sp.speaker: MRS. WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: On the contrary ! Are we to put up with everything ? Is n't one to offer any resistance if that woman robs us of our very bread — if she spreads slander about our daughter ?To SIEBENHAAR .Did the child ever offend you in any way ?

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Mama , mama ! Come along now , mama , and rest a while . So ! You spoke your part very well indeed . You can repeat it to-night .

div.stage: He leads her behind the bar where her sobbing is heard for some time after .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Having resumed his seat .She 's quite right at bottom . I 've heard all kinds of rumours too , to the effect that Henschel will rent the barroom . And , of course , his wife is behind that !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: An ’ who else 'd be back of it I 'd like to know ? If there 's anythin ’ low happenin ’ in the village nowadays , you do n't has to go an ax who 's back of it ! That Henschel woman 's got the devil in her !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: An ’ she 's had her eye on the barroom this long time .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: To HAUFFE .One hardly ever sees you any longer , Hauffe ? Where did you land ?

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Where d'you suppose ? In misery an ’ hunger ’ An ’ who gave me the shove ? That damned crittur of a woman ! Who else 'd do it , I 'd like to know ! I never had no trouble with Henschel !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: His wife has the breeches on — that 's all !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: I was n't quick enough for her no more . I 'm not as young as I was — that 's a fac ’ ! An ’ I do n't go hangin ’ aroun ’ no woman 's apron strings neither . An ’ that there is what she wants . That 's what you got to do with her ! She 's a hot one — you might say — she do n't never get enough .— But as for workin ': I c'n work ! Them young fellers that she hires — they 're that stinkin ’ lazy .... I could do as much as any three of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: One feels sorry for old Henschel .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: If he 's satisfied , I do n't care . But he ought to know why my bones is stiff ! They did n't get stiff with lazyin ’ aroun ’ , an ’ if that man has a chest full o ’ money to-day , he knows who it is that helped him earn a good lot of it !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I recall very well that you even worked for Wilhelm Henschel 's father .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Well , who else but me ! That 's the way it is ! An ’ I fed Wilhelm 's horses eighteen years an ’ more — hitched ‘ em up an ’ unhitched ‘ em — went on trips summer an ’ winter . I drove ‘ s far 's Freiburg an ’ ‘ s far 's Breslau : I had to drive ‘ way to Bromberg . Many a night I had to sleep in the waggon . I got my ears an ’ my hands frost bitten : I got chilblains on both feet big as pears . An ’ now he puts me out ! Now I c'n go !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: That 's all the woman 's doin 's : he 's a good man .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Why did he go an ’ load hisself with that wench ! Now he can look out for hisself ! An ’ he could n't hardly wait to do it decent . His first wife — she was n't hardly cold when he ran to get married to this one !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , no one knew her , of course .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: I knew her well enough . O Lord — that I did ! If he 'd ha ’ axed me , I could ha ’ told him ! If he wanted to send Gustel after her mother , there was n't no surer way for him to take : all he had to do was to make Hanne the child 's step-mother .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Ah yes , yes ... well , well ... I 'm not sayin ’ nothin ’ more . There 's many a one has shaken his head about that ! But that 'll be comin ’ home to him some day . First people just wondered ; now they 'd believe anythin ’ of him .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: That 's undoubtedly mere idle talk . The horse dealer WALTHER enters in riding boots , hunting jacket and cap . His whip is in his hand . He sits down at one of the tables and beckons FRANZISKA to bring him beer .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: You c'n say that . Maybe it 's true . But if the dead was to come back an ’ was to say their say — ‘ tis old Mrs. Henschel that could tell you a thing or two . She could n't live an ’ she did n't want to live ! An ’ what 's the main thing — she was n't to live !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Hauffe , you 'd better take care ! If Henschel were to get wind of that ...

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: I would n't have to take care if he did ! I 'd say that to anyone 's face . Old Mrs. Henschel — she was meant to die ! If they pisened her , I could n't say ; I was n't on the spot . But that thing did n't happen no natural way . She was a well woman ; she might ha ’ lived thirty years .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR drinks and rises
sp.p: WALTHER I c'n bear witness that she was well . She was my own sister an ’ I ought to know . She was in the way an ’ had to go .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR leaves quietly
sp.p: WERMELSKIRCH Would you like a little snuff , gentlemen ?Softly and confidentially .And do n't you think , gentlemen , that you 're going a little far ? It seems so to me . I wish you would watch the man . He sat here till quite late yesterday . The man sighed so pitifully — there was no one else here — that I really felt very sorry for him .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: ‘ Tis his bad conscience that 's botherin ’ him !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Do n't talk to me about Henschel ! I 'm sick o ’ hearin ’ about him . He an ’ me — we 're through with each other this long time .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: No , no , Mr. Siebenhaar is right . One ought to feel sorry for him .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: He c'n think about it what he pleases . I do n't care . But what I ought to think about Henschel — there 's nobody that need tell me nothin ’ about that !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL and the smith HILDEBRANT enter at the right . HENSCHEL is
sp.p: carrying little BERTHA , more neatly dressed than formerly , on his arm . A little pause of embarrassment falls upon the men .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Welcome , Mr. Henschel .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , all of ye .

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA
sp.p: Well , Berthel , how are you ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Say thank you ! Well , can n't you talk ?— We gets along . A body has to be satisfied . Good mornin ’ , brother .He stretches out his hand carelessly to WALTHER who takes it in the same fashion .How are you ? How 's everythin ’ ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I gets along as usual . ‘ Twould n't be bad if it was better ! You 're a reg'lar nurse girl nowadays !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: True , true ! ‘ Tis almost that !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: You 're hardly ever seen without the girl . Ca n't you leave her with her mother ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: She 's always scourin ’ an ’ workin ’ . The little thing is just in her way !He sits down on a bench along the wall near the bar , not far from his brother-in-law . He keeps the little girl on his lap . HILDEBRANT sits down opposite him .How is it , Hildebrant , what shall we have ? I think we 've earned a bumper o ’ beer ? Two of ‘ em , then , an two glasses o ’ brandy .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: That son of a — actually broke my skin !

lg.l: Nothin ’ but a foal neither an ’ has the strength o ’ —... Good mornin ’ ,
Hauffe .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: He 's a bit surly . Let 's not bother him .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Mr. Henschel , wo n't you buy something o ’ me ? A needle box for the wife , maybe , or a pretty little comb to stick in the hair !All laugh .George , the waiter , he bought one too .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Laughing good-naturedly with the others .Do n't you come botherin ’ me with your trash !To WERMELSKIRCH .Give him a measure o ’ beer !— ‘ Tis a quaint little chap he is . Who is it ?

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: ‘ Tis Fabig from Quolsdorf , I think — the most mischievous little scamp in the county .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , I got a little native from Quolsdorf here too .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: To BERTHA .We 're good old friends , eh ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: To FABIG .Why do n't you dive me some nuts ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Aha , she knows who I is ! I 'll look an ’ see if I c'n find some !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Outside in the waggon !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: No , they 're here in my pocket !He gives them to the child .You see , you do n't get out o ’ the pubs . Long ago your grandfather took you along ; now you got to go about with Henschel .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: To BERTHA .Tell him to attend to his bit o ’ trash ! Tell him you 're bein ’ looked out for ! Tell him that !

sp.speaker: GEORGE comes vivaciously out of the billiard room
sp.p: GEORGE

div.stage: Without noticing HENSCHEL . ] Well ,— I never saw the likes o ’ that ! That there feller c'n eat glass like anythin ’ . Put it down on the reckoning , Miss Franziska : a lot o ’ beer ! There 's five o ’ us !

lg.stage: Has taken BERTHA on her arm . She goes with the child behind the bar .
lg.l: Bertha wo n't permit it ; I can n't do it now !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good heavens , Mr. Henschel , there you are too !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Without noticing GEORGE , to HILDEBRANT .Your health , Hildebrant !

div.stage: They clink their glasses and drink .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: To GEORGE who , a little taken aback , lights his cigar at one of the tables .Tell me this , mister George , you 're a kind of a wizard , eh ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , I do declare ! What makes you think so ?

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: ‘ Cause a while ago , you was gone like a light that 's blown out .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , what 's the use o ’ huntin ’ for disagreeable things . Siebenhaar an ’ me — we can n't agree , that 's all .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: With the gesture of boxing another 's ears .People do say that somethin ’ happened .—Passing by , to HAUFFE .Did you win in the lottery ? eh ?

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: You damned vermin !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: Yes , that 's just what I am .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Is it true that you 're working down at Nentwich 's now ?

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: What business is it o ’ yours ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Laughing and quite even-tempered .Now look at that feller . He pricks like a weasel wherever you touches him .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I s'pose you 'll be our host here pretty soon now ?

lg.stage: After he has glanced at him in astonishment .
lg.l: That 's the first ever
I 've heard of it !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Oh , I thought ! I do n't know exackly who ‘ twas that told me .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Drinking : indifferently .Whoever told you that must ha ’ been dreamin ’ !

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: In this here house everythin ’ is bein ’ turned upside down now . An ’ what I says is this : You 'll be all sighin ’ to have Siebenhaar back some day .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: To HAUFFE .You might go over to Landeshut . I got two coach horses standin ’ there . You might ride them in for me .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: The hell I will — that 's what I 'll do for you .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Laughing and calmly .Well , now you c'n sit there till you gets blue in the face . I wo n't concern myself that much about you !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: You c'n keep busy sweepin ’ before your own door .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis well , ‘ tis well . We 'll let that there be .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: You got filth enough in your own house !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hauffe , I tell you right now : I would n't like to do it . But if you 're goin ’ to start trouble here — I tell you that — I 'll kick you out !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Peace , gentlemen ! I beg of you : peace !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: You 're not the host here an ’ you can n't kick nobody out ! You has no more right to say anythin ’ here than me ! I do n't let you nor nobody tell me to hold my tongue . No , not you an ’ not your wife , no matter how you scheme , you two ! That do n't scare me an ’ do n't bother me that much ! Without any show of anger , HENSCHEL grasps HAUFFE by the chest and pushes him , struggling in vain , toward the door . Just before reaching it he turns slightly , opens the door , puts HAUFFE out , and closes it again . During this scene the following colloquy takes place :

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Let go , I tell you ! I just warn you : let go !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Mr. Henschel , that wo n't do ; I can n't permit that !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I gave you fair warnin ’ ! There 's no help for you now .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE
sp.p: Are you goin ’ to choke me ? Let go , I tell you ! You 're not the host here !

lg.stage: From behind the bar .
lg.l: What 's the meaning of this ? That will never do ,
Ludwig ! You can n't permit yourself to be treated that way !

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: While HENSCHEL , holding HAUFFE , is rapidly approaching the door .You might as well let it be . There 's nothin ’ to be done . That there man — he 's like an athlete . He 'll bite his teeth into the edge of a table , and he 'll lift the table up for you so steady , you wo n't notice a glass on it shakin ’ . If he went an ’ took the notion , I tell you , we 'd all be flyin ’ out into the street different ways !

sp.speaker: HAUFFE has been put out , HENSCHEL returns
sp.p: HENSCHEL

div.stage: Resuming his seat amid a general silence . ] He would n't give no rest — he 's that stubborn .

sp.speaker: FIRST FIREMAN
sp.p: Who has come in out of the billiard room and drunk a glass of whisky at the bar .I 'd like to pay . A man had better go . In the end anybody might be flyin ’ out o ’ here , you know .

lg.l: Yon take another glass of beer . That would be the last straw . After all ,
I am still master here .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: If that 's the way you 're goin ’ to do , Henschel , when you stands behind the bar and runs this here place instead o ’ Wermelskirch — you wo n't keep many customers , I c'n tell you that !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Customers like that do n't matter .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: You wo n't be able to pick ‘ em out , though . Hauffe do n't pay with counterfeit money neither .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: He c'n pay anyway he wants to , for all I care . But I tell you again now : Do n't start that there business over again . I wo n't be takin ’ this place at all . If I was goin ’ to take it , I ought to know better than anybody else . Well , then : if I 'm ready to buy a pub some day — I 'll let you know ! Afterward you c'n give me your advice . An ’ if you do n't like the place an ’ do n't patronise it — well , then , Lord A'mighty , you do n't has to ! The FIREMAN goes out slamming the door angrily behind him .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I s'pose it 's just as well to go ....

div.stage: He prepares to pay his score .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Mr. Henschel , surely that is n't right of you . You drive my customers out .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , my goodness ! Now tell me : If that man runs out , what has I to do with it ? For my part he can stay here till mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Pocketing his money again .You got no right to put anybody out o ’ here . You 're not the host .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Anythin ’ else you know ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: People knows a good deal . Only they rather keep still . Wermelskirch knows that best of all !

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Why I exactly ? Now , look here , that 's ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Firmly and collectedly .What is't you know ? Out with it ! One o ’ you knows one thing an ’ another another , an ’ altogether you do n't know that much !

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: In a changed tone .If you were only the same man you used to be ! But God only knows what 's gotten into you ! In those days you had a standin ’ among men . People came from far an ’ wide to get your advice . An ’ what you said , that was — you might say — almost like the law o ’ the land . ‘ Twas like Amen in church . An ’ now there 's no gettin ’ along with you !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Go right ahead with your preachin ’ .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Very well , I s'pose you 're noticin ’ it all yourself . Formerly , you had nothin ’ but friends . Nowadays nobody comes to you no more ; an ’ even if they did want to come they stay away on account o ’ your wife . Twenty years Hauffe served you faithful . Then , suddenly , he do n't suit your wife , an ’ you take him by the scruff an ’ put him out . What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ! That woman has but to look at you an ’ you 're jumpin ’ at her beck , instead o ’ goin ’ an ’ takin ’ a stout rope an ’ knockin ’ the wickedness out o ’ her !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: If you do n't keep still this minute — I 'll take you by the scruff too .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: To HENSCHEL .Do n't forget yourself , whatever you do , Mr. Henschel ! That man do n't know no better , you see .

div.stage: Exit rapidly into the billiard room .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I believe , Henschel , if a man comes nowadays an ’ tells you the truth , you 're capable o ’ flingin ’ him against the wall . But a feller like that , a worthless windbag like George — he c'n lie to you day an ’ night . Your wife an ’ he — they c'n compete with each other makin ’ a fool o ’ you ! If you want to be cheated — all right ! But if you got a pair o ’ eyes left in your head , open ‘ em once an ’ look around you an ’ look at that there feller good an ’ hard . Them two deceive you in broad daylight !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: About to hurl himself upon WALTHER , masters his rage .What did you say — eh ? Nothin ’ ! Aw , it 's all right .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: FABIG
sp.p: It 's reg'lar April weather this day . Now the sun shines an ’ now it blows again .

sp.speaker: HAUFFE 'S VOICE
sp.p: From without .I 'll pay you back for this ! You watch out ! You c'n let it be now ! We 'll meet again : we 'll meet at court — that 's where .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Finishes his glass .Good-bye . I 'm meanin ’ well by you , Henschel .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Lays his hand about WALTHER 'S wrist .You stay here ! Y ’ understan ’ ?

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: What is I to do here ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 'll see for yourself . All I says is : You stay !To FRANZISKA .Go down an ’ tell my wife she 's to come up !

sp.speaker: FRANZISKA goes
sp.p: WERMELSKIRCH But , dear Mr. Henschel , I beg you , for heaven 's sake , do n't cause a scandal here ! The police will be coming at me next , and then ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: In an outburst of towering , withering rage — bluish-red of face .I 'll beat you all to death if Hanne do n't come here — now !! !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: In helpless perplexity .Wilhelm , Wilhelm , don ’ go an ’ commit some foolishness now ! I wish I had n't said nothin ’ . An ’ it did n't mean nothin ’ . You know yourself how people will talk !

sp.speaker: HILDEBRANT
sp.p: Wilhelm , you 're a good man . Come to your senses ! My God , how you look ! Think , man , think ! Why , you fairly roared ! What 's the matter with you ? That must ha ’ been heard all over the house !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Anybody c'n hear me now that wants to . But you stay here an ’ Hanne is to come here .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Why should I be stayin ’ here ? I do n't know what for ! Your affairs — they do n't concern me a bit . I do n't mingle in ‘ em an ’ I do n't want to !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Then you should ha ’ thought before you spoke !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: Everythin ’ else that 's between us 'll be settled in court . There we 'll see who 's in the right . I 'll get hold o ’ my money ; never fear ! Maybe you 're wife 'll think it over once or twice before she goes an ’ perjures herself . The rest do n't concern me . I tell you to let me go . I has no time . I has to go to Hartau , an ’ I can n't be kept waitin ’ here .

lg.l: SIEBENHAAR
What 's happened here ?

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Goodness , gracious , I do n't know ! I do n't know what Mr. Henschel wants !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who continues to imprison WALTHER 'S wrist .Hanne is to come here : that 's all .

sp.speaker: MRS. WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: To SIEBENHAAR .The men were drinking their beer quite peacefully . Suddenly Mr. Henschel came in and began a dispute as though he were master here .

lg.stage: With a deprecating gesture .
lg.l: All right ; all right .
lg.stage: To HENSCHEL .
lg.l: What 's happened to you , Henschel ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Mr. Siebenhaar , it 's no fault o ’ mine . I could n't help things comin ’ about this way . You may think what you please , Mr. Siebenhaar . I give you my word — ‘ twas n't my fault .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: You need n't excuse yourself to me , Henschel . I know you 're a man of peace .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes . I was in your father 's service long ago , an ’ even if it looks that way a thousand times over — it was n't my fault that this here has happened . I do n't know myself what I has done . I never was quarrelsome — that 's certain ! But now things has come about ...! They scratch an ’ they bite at me — all of ‘ em ! An ’ now this man here has said things o ’ my wife that he 's got to prove — prove ! !— or God help him !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Why do n't you let the people gossip ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Proofs ! Proofs ! Or God help him !

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I can prove it an ’ I will . There are not many people in this room that do n't know it as well as I . That there woman is on an evil way . ‘ Tis no fault o ’ mine , an ’ I would n't ha ’ mentioned it . But I 'm not goin ’ to let you strike me . I 'm no liar . I always speaks the truth ! Ask it of anybody ! Ask Mr. Siebenhaar here on his honour an ’ conscience ! The sparrows is twitterin ’ it on every roof — an ’ worse things ‘ n that !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Think over what you 're saying carefully , Walther .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: He forces me to it ! Why do n't he let me go ? Why is I to suffer for other people ? You know it all as well as I ? How did you used to stand with Henschel in other years when his first wife was alive ? D'you think people do n't know that ? An ’ now you do n't cross his threshold .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: The relations between us are our private affair . And I will not permit remark or interference .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: All right . But if first his wife dies , though she 's as well as anybody , an ’ when Gustel goes an ’ dies eight weeks later , then , I 'm thinkin ’ it 's more'n a private affair !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What ?— Hanne is to come !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL enters suddenly and quickly , just as she has come from
sp.p: her work and still drying her hands .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What 're you roarin ’ about so ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis well that you 're here .— This man here says —

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Makes a movement as if to go .Damned rot that it ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're to stay here !

lg.l: Are you all drunk together ? What 're you thinkin ’ of , anyhow ? D'you think
I 'm goin ’ to stay here an ’ play monkey tricks for you ?

div.stage: She is about to go .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hanne , I advise you ... This man here says ...

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Aw , he c'n say what he wants to , for all I cares !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: He says that you deceive me before my face an ’ behind my back !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What ? What ? What ? What ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's what he says ! Is he goin ’ to dare to say that ? An ’ that ... my wife ...

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Me ? Lies ! Damned lies !

div.stage: She throws her apron over her face and rushes out .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That I ... that my wife ... that we together ... that our Gustel ... ‘ Tis well ! ‘ Tis well !

div.stage: He releases WALTHER 'S hand and lets his head sink , moaning , on the table .

sp.speaker: WALTHER
sp.p: I wo n't be made out a liar here .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE FIFTH ACT The same room as in the first three acts . It is night , but the moonlight throws a moderate brightness into the room . It is empty . Several days have passed since the occurrences in the fourth act . A candle is lit in the small adjoining room ; at the end of a few seconds HENSCHEL enters , carrying the candle in a candlestick of tin . He wears leathern breeches but his feet are cased in bedroom slippers . Slowly he approaches the table , gazes hesitatingly first backward , then toward the window , finally puts the candlestick on the table and sits down by the window . He leans his chin on his hand and stares at the moon .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Invisible , from the adjoining chamber , calls :Husband ! Husband ! What are you doin ’ out there ?— the same mortal foolishness all the time ! —She looks in , but half-clad .Where are you ? Come ‘ n go to bed ! ‘ Tis time to sleep ! To-morrow you wo n't be able to go out again ! You 'll be lyin ’ like a sack o ’ meal and everythin ’ ‘ ll go upside down in the yard .She comes out , half-clad as she is , and approaches HENSCHEL hesitatingly and fearfully .What are you doin ’ , eh ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Why are you sittin ’ there an ’ not sayin ’ a word ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm lookin ’ at the clouds .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , no , my goodness ; it 's enough to confuse a person 's head ! What 's to be seen up there , I 'd like to know ! The same worry , night after night . There 's no rest in the world for nobody no more . What are you starin ’ at ? Say somethin ’ , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Up there !... That 's where they are !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're dreaming , eh ? You , Wilhelm , wake up ! Lay down in your bed an ’ go to sleep . There 's nothin ’ but clouds up there !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Anybody that has eyes c'n see what there is !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ anybody that gets confused in his mind goes crazy .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm not confused .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL I 'm not sayin ’ that you are ! But if you go on actin ’ this
sp.p: way , you will be !

div.stage: She shivers , pulls on a jacket , and stirs the ashes in the oven with a poker .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What time is it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: A quarter of two .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 've got a watch hangin ’ to you ; it used to hang behind the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What fancies is you goin ’ to have next ? ‘ Tis hangin ’ where it always did .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Rising .I think I 'll go over to the stables a bit .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I tells you to go to bed , or I 'll raise an alarm . You got nothin ’ to do in the stable now ! ‘ Tis night , an ’ in bed is where you belong !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Remains standing quietly and looking at HANNE .Where 's Gustel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What are you botherin ’ for ? She 's lyin ’ in bed asleep ! What are you always worritin ’ over the girl for ? She do n't lack for nothin ’ ! I do n't do nothin ’ to her !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: She do n't lack for nothin ’ . She 's gone to bed . She 's gone to sleep betimes — Gustel has . I do n't mean Berthel .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Wailing , stuffs her apron into her mouth .I 'll run away ! I wo n't stay here !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — Go to bed , go ! I 'll come too . Your cryin ’ can n't help no more now . ‘ Tis our Lord alone knows whose fault it is . You can n't help it ; you do n't need to cry .— Our Lord an ’ me — we two , we knows .He turns the key in the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Hastily turning it back again .Why d'you lock the door ? I wo n't stand bein ’ locked in .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't rightly know why I turned the key .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Them people has gone an ’ addled your brains for you ! They 'll have to answer some day for the things they 've put into your head ! I took as good care o ’ your girl as I did o ’ my own . She would n't ha ’ died o ’ that ! But I can n't wake the dead . If a body is to die , she dies — in this world . There 's no holdin ’ people like that ; they has to go . There never was much strength in Gustel — you know that as well as I . Why do you go axin ’ me an ’ lookin ’ at me as if I done God knows what to her !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Suspiciously .Maybe you did somethin ’ . ‘ Tis not impossible .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Beside herself .Oh , if somebody 'd foretold this — I 'd ha ’ gone beggin ’ my bread first . No , no , O my goodness , if I 'd ha ’ known that ! To have to listen to things like that ! Did n't I want to go ? An ’ who kept me back ? Who held me fast in the house here ? I could ha ’ made my livin ’ any time ! I was n't afraid ; I could always work . But you did n't let up . Now I got my reward . Now I got to suffer for it !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis true , maybe , that you has to suffer for it . Things comes as they come . What c'n a body do ?

div.stage: He locks the door again .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're to leave the door open , Wilhelm , or I 'll cry for help !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — Sh ! Keep still ! Did you hear ? There 's somethin ’ runnin ’ along the passage . D'you hear ? Now it goes to the washstand . D'you hear the splashin ’ ? She 's standin ’ there an ’ washin ’ herself !

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You ! Wilhelm ! You 're dreamin ’ ! The wash-stand is in here !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's just it ! I know very well ! They can n't deceive me . I know what I know ,Hurriedly .That 's all I say .— Come , come , let 's go to bed . Time 'll show .

div.stage: While he approaches the door of the next room , Mrs. HENSCHEL softly unlocks the door to the hall and slips out .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Taking down a whip from the frame of the door .Why , that 's my old Triest whip ! Where does that old thing come from ? I have n't seen it for over a year . That was bought in mother 's time .He listens .What d'you say ? Eh ?— O ’ course ... Certainly .— Nothin ’ !— Well , s'posin ’ ! An ’ why not ? ‘ Tis well !— I know what I has to do !— I wo n't be stubborn .— You let that be too .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR enters by the door which is slightly ajar . By means of
sp.p: gestures he signifies to WERMELSKIRCH , who follows him , that the latter is to remain behind , also to MRS. HENSCHEL . He is fully clad except that he wears a silk kerchief instead of a collar . WERMELSKIRCH is in his dressing-gown .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Good evening , Mr. Henschel ! What ? Are you still up ? You 're not well , eh ? What 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: After he has , for several seconds , regarded him with perplexity ; simply :I just can n't sleep . I do n't get sleepy at all ! I 'd like to take some medicine , if I knew any . I do n't know how it comes . God knows !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I 'll tell you somethin ’ , old friend : You go quietly to bed now , and to-morrow , real early , I 'll send the doctor in . You must really take some serious step now .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: No doctor wo n't be able to help me .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: You must n't say that ; we 'll see about that ! Doctor Richter knows his business . My wife could n't sleep for weeks ; her head ached as if it would burst . Last Monday she took a powder , and now she sleeps all night like the dead .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , yes ... well , well ... ‘ Tis possible ! I 'd like it well enough if I could sleep .— Is the madam reel sick ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Oh , we 're all a little under the weather . When once Monday is past , everything will straighten out again .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I s'pose you has to turn over the property on Monday .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Yes , I hope it will be possible to arrange it by Monday . In the meantime the work is heaping up so — what with writing and making the inventory — that I scarcely get out of my clothes . But come now , Henschel , and go to bed . One man has one trouble and another has another . Life is no joke and we must all see how we can best fight our way through . And even if many strange thoughts pass through your head — do n't take them to heart so !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Thank you many times , Mr. Siebenhaar . Do n't take anythin ’ in ill part , please . An ’ good luck to you an ’ your wife !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: We 'll see each other again to-morrow , Henschel . You owe me no thanks for anything . We 've done each other many a service in the years that we 've lived together here . And those services compensate for each other . We were good friends and , surely , we will remain such .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Silently takes a few steps toward the window and looks out .— Ah , them 's queer things here . Time do n't stand still in this world . Little Karl , he never came to see us no more ... I can n't make no objection . Maybe you was right . The lad could n't ha ’ learned nothin ’ good here . ‘ Twas different — once !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , I do n't know what you mean now !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ you did n't cross my threshold neither . ‘ Tis nine months since you did .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: I had too much to worry me ; that 's all .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Those were the very times you used to come before . No , no , I know . You were right . An ’ the people are right too — all of ‘ em . I can n't take no pride in myself no more .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , you must take some rest now .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: No , no ; we c'n talk about it a bit . You see , I know ‘ tis all my fault — I know that , an ’ with that we can let it be . But before I went an ’ took this woman — Hanne , I mean — before that it all began ... slowly it began , slowly — but downhill right along . First thing , a good bonehandled whip broke . After that , I remember it right well , I drove over my dog an ’ he died . ‘ Twas the best little dog I had . Then , one right after another , three o ’ my horses died ; an ’ one of ‘ em was the fine stallion that cost me five hundred crowns . An ’ then , last of all ... my wife died . I noticed it well enough in my own thoughts that fate was against me . But when my wife went away from me , I had a minute in my own mind when I thought to myself : Now it 's enough . There 's not much else that c'n be taken from me . But you see , there was somethin ’ else .— I do n't want to talk about Gustel . A man loses first his wife an ’ then a child — that 's common . But no : a snare was laid for me an ’ I stepped into it .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Who laid a snare for you ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Maybe the devil ; maybe , too , somebody else . It 's throttlin ’ me — that 's certain .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: That 's a most unhappy notion of yours ...

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ I 'm denyin ’ nothin ’ . A bad man I 've come to be , only it 's no fault o ’ mine . I just , somehow , stumbled into it all . Maybe it 's my fault too . You c'n say so if you want to . Who knows ? I should ha ’ kept a better watch . But the devil is more cunnin ’ than me . I just kept on straight ahead .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , you 're just your own worst enemy . You 're fighting phantoms which have no existence at any time or place . The devil has done nothing to you , nor have you stepped into any snare . And no one is throttling you either . That is all nonsense . And such fancies are dangerous .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: We 'll see ; we c'n wait an ’ see .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , tell me something definite . You wo n't be able to do it , however you try . You are neither bad , as you say , nor are you burdened by any guilt .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Ah , I know better .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Well , what is your guilt ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Here stood the bed . An ’ she was lyin ’ in it . An ’ here I gave her my promise . I gave her my promise an ’ I 've broken it !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: What promise was that ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You know well enough !— I broke it an ’ when I did that , I was lost . I was done for . The game was up .— An ’ you see : now she can n't find no rest .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Are you speaking of your dead wife ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis of her , of her exackly that I 'm speakin ’ . She can n't find no rest in the grave . She comes an ’ she goes an ’ she finds no rest .— I curry the horses ; there she stands . I take a sieve from the feed-bin , an ’ I see her sittin ’ behind the door . I mean to go to bed in the little room ; ‘ tis she that 's lyin ’ in the bed an ’ lookin ’ at me .— She 's hung a watch aroun ’ my neck ; she knocks at the wall ; she scratches on the panes .— She puts her finger on my breast an ’ I 'm that smothered , I has to gasp for air . No , no , I know best . You got to go through a thing like that before you know what it is . You can n't tell about It . I 've gone through a deal — you c'n believe me .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , this is my last word to you : Gather all the strength you have in you ; plant yourself firmly on both legs . Go and consult a physician . Tell yourself that you are ill , very ill , but drive these phantoms away . They are mere cobwebs of the brain , mere fancies .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's what you said that there time , too . Just so or somethin ’ like it you said .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Very likely , and I 'm willing to stand by it now . What you did in the matter of your marriage , it was your entire right to do . There was no question of any sin or guilt .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH steps forward
sp.p: WERMELSKIRCH Henschel , come over to me . We 'll light the gas and play cards . We 'll drink beer or whatever you want to and smoke a pipe with it ; then the ghosts can come if they want to . In two hours it will be bright daylight . Then we can drink some coffee and take a walk . The devil is in this if you can n't be made to be your old self again .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Maybe so ; we c'n try it all right .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Well then , come along .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I wo n't go to your place no more .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: On account of that little nonsense the other day ? That was only a misunderstanding . And all that has been cleared up . I simply wo n't let Hauffe come in any more . The fellow is always drunk ; that 's a fact . Things are often said in heat that simply enter at one ear and pass out at the other . And that 's the way to treat such incidents , I always do .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: An ’ that 'd be best too . You 're quite right . But no — I wo n't be comin ’ into the barroom no more . I 'm goin ’ to travel about a good bit , I think . Maybe they wo n't follow me all roun ’ . An ’ now sleep well . I 'm feelin ’ sleepy too .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: How would it be , Henschel , if you came up with me ? There 's light upstairs and my office is heated . There we can all three play a little game . I would n't lie down to-night anyhow .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , yes ; we could be doin ’ that together . ‘ Tis long since I 've touched a card .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's right . Go on up . You would n't be able to sleep nohow .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm not goin ’ ! Y ’ understand me now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Well , if you 're goin ’ to stay , then I wo n't . God knows what you 'll be up to this night . You 'll begin to be playin ’ aroun ’ with knives again . Yes , that 's what he did yesterday . A body 's not sure o ’ her life no more .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: You wo n't see me goin ’ up there . He advised me to do what I did , an ’ then he was the first one to despise me for doin ’ it .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , I never despised you . You 're an honourable fellow , through and through ; do n't talk nonsense now . There are certain fates that come upon men . And what one has to bear is not easy . You have grown ill , but you have remained a good man . And for that truth I 'll put my hand in the fire !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Maybe that 's true too , Mr . Siebenhaar .— Let it be ; we 'll talk about somethin ’ else . ‘ Tis n't your fault ; I always said that . An ’ I can n't blame my brother-in law neither . He knows where he gets all that from , ‘ Tis she herself goes roun ’ to people an ’ tells ‘ em . She 's everywhere — now here an ’ now there . I s'pose she was with her brother too .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Who is it that goes about among people ? Not a soul is thinking of that affair of the other night , That 's quite forgotten by this time .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: It sticks to me — it does — turn it any way you please . She knows how to go about it . She 's everywhere , an ’ she 'll persuade folks . An ’ even , if people was goin ’ to be silent for my sake an ’ was n't after me like so many dogs — nothin ’ c'n do any good . It 'll stick to me .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Henschel , we wo n't go away until you 've put that , out of your mind . You must calm , yourself entirely .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Oh , I 'm sensible now an ’ quiet , reel quiet .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Very well . In that case we can talk quite frankly . You see for yourself how your wife repents . That waiter fellow is gone ; he 's far away by this time and you 'll never set your eyes on him again . Anyone may fall into sin — no matter who it is . And so take each other 's hands . Bury that matter , hide it out of sight and be at peace .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: I do n't has to make no peace with her .To HANNE .I c'n give you my hand ! I do n't mind . That you 've gone an ’ made a mistake — the Lord c'n judge that in this world . I wo n't condemn you on that account .— If only ... about Gustel ... if only we could know somethin ’ ... about that ... for certain !

lg.l: You c'n both kill me this minute . May I drop dead if I did any harm to
Gustel ! !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: That 's what I 've been sayin ': It 'll stick to me .— Well , we c'n talk it over again to-morrow . Before we get through talkin ’ about that , many a drop o ’ water 'll have time to run into the sea , I 'm thinkin ’ .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Why do n't you build a comfortable fire and cook a cup of hot coffee . After rain comes the sunshine . That 's the way it is between married people . There will be storms in every marriage . But after the storm everything grows greener . The main thing is : Bye , baby , bye —He imitates the gesture of one rocking a child in his arms .— That 's the right way . That 's the thing that you two must get for yourselves .Jovially patting HENSCHEL 'S shoulder .That 's what the old man likes . You two must get together and buy a toy like that . Confound it , Henschel ! It would be queer if that were n't easy . A giant of a man like you ! Good night all .

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Everything changes . One must have courage .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Just keep cool and dress warmly — that 's it !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR and WERMELSKIRCH withdraw . HENSCHEL goes slowly to the
sp.p: door and is about to lock it again .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're to leave that open !

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: All right ; I do n't mind .— What are you doin ’ there ?

lg.stage: Who has been bending down before the oven , draws herself up quickly .
lg.l: I 'm makin ’ a fire . Do n't you see that ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Sitting down , heavily by the table .For my part you c'n light the lamp too .

div.stage: He pulls out the drawer of the table .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: What are you lookin ’ for ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Nothin ’ .

lg.l: Then you c'n push it back in .
lg.stage: She steps forward and shuts the drawer .
lg.l: I s'ppose you want to wake Berthel up ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Monday he 's goin ’ . Then we 'll be alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who 's goin ’ on Monday ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Siebenhaar . The Lord knows how we 'll get along with the new owner .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: He 's a rich man . He wo n't borrow money of you at least .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: — Hanne , one of us two 'll have to go . One of us two . Yes , yes ,' tis true . You c'n look at me . That can n't be changed .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I 'm to go away ? You want to drive me away ?

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: We 'll see about that later — who has to go ! Maybe ‘ twill be me , an ’ maybe ‘ twill be you . If I was to go ... I know this for sure — you would n't be scared about yourself . You 're able to look after the business like a man .— But ‘ s I said : it do n't matter about me .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: If one of us has to go — I 'll go . I 'm still strong enough . I 'll leave an ’ nobody need n't see me no more . The horses an ’ the waggons — they 're all yours . You got the business from your father an ’ you can n't go an ’ leave it . I 'll go an ’ then the trouble 'll be over .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: ‘ Tis easy sayin ’ that . We got to consider one thing at a time .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: There 's no use in drawin ’ it out . What 's over and done with is over .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Rising heavily and going toward the adjoining room .An ’ Berthel ? What 's to become o ’ the lass ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: She 'll have to go to father , over in Quolsdorf .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: At the door of the bedroom .Let it be . To-morrow is another day . Everythin ’ changes , as Siebenhaar says . To-morrow , maybe , everythin ’ ‘ ll look different .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Invisible in the next room .Berthel is sweating all over again .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: That wo n't do her no harm to be sweatin ’ a bit . The drops are runnin ’ down my neck too . Oh , what a life —She opens a window .— a body 'd rather be dead .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: What are you talkin ’ about ? I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Lie down on your side an ’ leave me alone .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Are you comin ’ too ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: It 's most day now .

div.stage: She winds the clock .

sp.speaker: HENSCHEL
sp.p: Who 's windin ’ the clock ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: You 're to keep still now . If Berthel was to wake up it 'd be a fine to do . She 'd howl for half an hour .She sits down at the table and leans both elbows upon it .‘ Twould be best if a body got up an ’ went away ,

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR peers in
sp.p: SIEBENHAAR I 'm lookin ’ in once more . Is your husband calmer now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Yes , yes , he lay down to sleep .She calls .Husband ! Wilhelm !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Sh ! You 'd better be grateful . Hurry and go to bed yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: There 's nothin ’ else left to do . I 'll go an ’ try .She goes to the door of the bedroom , stands still as if spellbound and listens .Wilhelm ! You might answer .—Louder and more frightened .Wilhelm ! You 're not to frighten me this way ! Maybe you think I do n't know that you 're still awake ! !—In growing terror .— Wilhelm , I tell you !...BERTHEL has waked up and wails .Berthel , you look out an ’ keep still ! Keep still or I do n't know what 'll happen !— Wilhelm ! Wilhelm !

div.stage: She almost shrieks .

lg.l: SIEBENHAAR
What 's the matter , Mrs. Henschel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: I call an ’ call an ’ he do n't answer !

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Are you crazy ? Why do you do that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: — ‘ Tis so still ... Somethin 's happened .

lg.l: What ?—
lg.stage: He takes up the candle and goes toward the bedroom door .
lg.l: Henschel , have you fallen asleep ?

div.stage: He enters the bedroom .
Pause .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Not daring to follow him .What is it ? What is it ? What 's goin ’ on ?

lg.l: WERMELSKIRCH
Who 's in there ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Mr . Siebenhaar .— ‘ Tis so still . Nobody do n't answer .—

lg.stage: Very pale and holding BERTHEL on his arm hurries out of the bedroom .
lg.l: Mrs. Henschel , take your child and go up to my wife .

sp.speaker: MRS. HENSCHEL
sp.p: Already with the child in her arms .For God 's sake , what has happened ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: You 'll find that out all too soon .

lg.stage: With a voice that is first repressed and at last rises to a scream .
lg.l: O
God , he 's done hisself some harm !
lg.stage: She runs out with the child .

sp.speaker: WERMELSKIRCH
sp.p: Shall I call the doctor ?

sp.speaker: SIEBENHAAR
sp.p: Too late ! He could give no help here .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: ROSE BERND

sp.speaker: LIST OF PERSONS
sp.p: BERND .

sp.speaker: ROSE BERND
sp.p: MARTHEL .

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER FLAMM
sp.p: MRS. FLAMM .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR STRECKMANN
sp.p: AUGUST KEIL .
