sp.speaker: HAHN . HEINZEL . GOLISCH . KLEINERT . Field Labourers
sp.p: OLD MRS. GOLISCH .

sp.speaker: THE HEAD MAID SERVANT
sp.p: THE ASSISTANT MAID SERVANT .

sp.speaker: A CONSTABLE
sp.p: THE FIRST ACT A level , fertile landscape . It is a clear , warm , sunny morning in May . Diagonally from the middle to the foreground extends a path . The fields on either side are raised slightly above it . In the immediate foreground a small potato patch on which the green shoots are already visible . A shallow ditch , covered with field flowers , separates the path from the fields . To the left of the path on a slope about six feet in height an old cherry tree , to the right hazelnut and whitethorn bushes . Nearly parallel with this path , but at some distance in the background , the course of a brook is marked by willows and alder trees . Solitary groves of ancient trees add a park-like appearance to the landscape . In the background , left , from among bushes and tree-tops arise the gables and the church steeple of the village . A crucifix stands by the wayside in the foreground , right . It is Sunday .

sp.speaker: ROSE BERND , a beautiful , vigorous peasant girl of twenty-two
sp.p: emerges , excited and blushing , from the bushes at the left and sits down on the slope , after having peered shyly and eagerly in all directions . Her skirt is caught up , her feet are bare , as are her arms and neck . She is busily braiding one of her long , blonde tresses . Shortly after her appearance a man comes stealthily from the bushes on the other side . It is the landowner and magistrate , CHRISTOPHER FLAMM . He , too , gives the impression of being embarrassed but at the same time amused . His personality is not undignified ; his dress betrays something of the sportsman , nothing of the dandy — laced boots , hunter 's hose , a leather bottle slung by a strap across his shoulder . Altogether FLAMM is robust , unspoiled , vivid and broad-shouldered and creates a thoroughly pleasant impression . He sits down on the slope at a carefully considered distance from ROSE . They look at each other silently and then break out into inextinguishable laughter .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: With rising boldness and delight sings ever louder and more heartily , beating time like a conductor .“ In heath and under greenwood tree , There is the joy I choose for me ! I am a huntsman bold I am a huntsman bold ! ”

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Is at first frightened by his singing ; then , more and more amused , her embarrassment gives way to laughter .Oh , but Mr. Flamm ...

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: With a touch of jaunty boldness .Sing with me , Rosie !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , but I can n't sing , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Ah , that is n't true , Rosie . Do n't I hear you often and often singing out on the farm : “ A huntsman from the Rhineland ... ” Well ! “ Rides through the forest green . ”

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But I do n't know that song a bit , Mr. Flamm .

lg.l: You 're not to say Mr. Flamm ! Come now !
“ Girlie , come and move
Here to my favourite si-i-ide ! ”

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Anxiously .The people will be comin ’ from church in a minute , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Let ‘ em come !He gets up and takes his rifle from the hollow cherry tree to the left .I 'd better hang it around again anyhow . So .— And now my hat and my pipe ! Good . They can come whenever they please .He has slung his gun across his shoulder , straightened his hat which is ornamented with a cock 's feather , taken a short pipe out of his pocket and put it between his lips .Look at the wild cherries . They 're thick .He picks up a handful of them and shows them to ROSE . With heartfelt conviction :Rosie , I wish you were my wife !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Goodness , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: I do , so help me !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Nervously trying to restrain himOh no , no !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Rosie , give me your dear , good , faithful little paw .He holds her hand and sits down .By heaven , Rosie ! Look here , I 'm a deucedly queer fellow ! I 'm damned fond of my dear old woman ; that 's as true as ...

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Hiding her face in her arm .You make me want to die o ’ shame .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Damned fond of her I tell you ... but —His patience snaps .— this does n't concern her a bit !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Again tempted to laugh against her will .Oh , but how you talk , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Filled with hearty admiration of her .Oh , you 're a lovely woman ! You are lovely ! You see : my wife and I ... that 's a queer bit of business , that is . Not the kind of thing that can be straightened out in a minute . You know Henrietta ... She 's sick . Nine solid years she 's been bedridden ; at most she creeps around in a wheel chair .— Confound it all , what good is that sort o ’ thing to me ?

div.stage: He grasps her head and kisses her passionately .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Frightened under his kisses .The people are comin ’ from church !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: They 're not thinking of it ! Why are you so worried about the people in church to-day ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Because August 's in church too .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: That long-faced gentry is always in church ! Where else should they be ? But , Rosie , it is n't even half past ten yet ; and when the service is over the bells ring . No , and you need n't be worried about my wife either .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , Christopher , she keeps lookin ’ at a body sometimes , so you want to die o ’ shame .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You do n't know my old lady ; that 's it . She 's bright ; she can look through three board walls ! But on that account ...! She 's mild and good as a lamb ... even if she knew what there is between us ; she would n't take our heads off .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , no ! For heaven 's sake , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Nonsense , Rosie ! Have a pinch , eh ?He takes snuff .I tell you once more : I do n't care about anything !Indignantly .What is a man like me to do ? What , I ask you ? No , do n't misunderstand me ! Surely you know how seriously I think of our affair . Let me talk ahead once in a while .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Mr. Christie , you 're so good to me ...!With a sudden ebullition of tenderness , tears in her eyes , she kisses FLAMM 'S hand .So good ... but ...

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Moved and surprised .Good to you ? No wonder ! Deuce take me , Rosie . That 's very little , being good to you . If I were free , I 'd marry you . You see , I 've lost the ordinary way in life ! Not to speak of past affairs ! I 'm fit for ... well , I wonder what I am fit for ! I might have been a royal chief forester to-day ! And yet , when the governor died , I went straight home and threw over my career . I was n't born for the higher functions of society . All this even is too civilised for me . A block house , a rifle , bear 's ham for supper and a load of lead sent into the breeches of the first comer — that would be ...!

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But that can n't be had , Mr. Flamm ! And ... things has got to end sometime .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Half to himself .Confound it all to everlasting perdition ! Is n't there time enough left for that spindle-shanked hypocrite ? Wo n't there be far too much left for that fellow anyway ? No > girlie , I 'd send him about his business .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , but I 've kept him danglin ’ long enough . Two years an ’ more he 's been waitin ’ . Now he 's urgent ; he wo n't wait any longer . An ’ things can n't go on this way no more .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Enraged .That 's all nonsense ; you understand . First you worked yourself to the bone for your father . You have n't the slightest notion of what life is , and now you want to be that bookbinder 's pack horse . I do n't see how people can be so vulgar and heartless as to make capital out of another human being in that way ! If that 's all you 're looking forward to , surely there 's time enough .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , Christie ... It 's easy to talk that way , Mr. Flamm ! But if you was put into such circumstances , you 'd be thinkin ’ different too .— I know how shaky father 's gettin ’ ! An ’ the landlord has given us notice too . A new tenant is to move in , I believe ! An ’ then it 's father 's dearest wish that everythin 's straightened out .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Then let your father marry August Keil , if he 's so crazy about the fellow . Why , he 's positively obsessed . It 's madness the way he 's taken with that man !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: You 're unjust , Mr. Flamm ; that 's all .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Say rather ... Well , what ? What was I going to say ?... I can n't bear that sanctimonious phiz ! My gorge rises at the sight of him . God forgive me , Rosie , and forgive you especially ! Why should n't I be open with you ? It may be that he has his merits . They say , too , that he 's saved up a few shillings . But that 's no reason why you should go and drown yourself in his paste-pot !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , Christopher ! Do n't talk that way ! I mus n't listen to such talk , the dear Lord knows !— August , he 's been through a lot !— His sickness an ’ his misfortunes — that goes right to a person 's soul ...

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: A man can never understand you women folks . You 're an intelligent and determined girl , and suddenly , on one point , your stupidity is simply astonishing — goose-like , silly ! It goes straight to your soul , does it ? From that point of view you might as well marry an ex-convict , if pity or stupidity are reasons . You ought to raise a bit of a row with your father for once ! What 's hurting August ? He grew up in the orphan house and succeeded in making his way for all that . If you wo n't have him , his brethren in the Lord will find him another . They 're expert enough at that !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: With decision .No , that wo n't do . And — it has got to be , Mr . Flamm .— I 'm not sorry for what 's happened , though I 've had my share o ’ sufferin ’ in quiet . All to myself , I mean . But never mind . An ’ nothin ’ can change that now . But it 's got to come to an end some day — it can n't never an ’ never go on this way .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Ca n't go on ? What do you mean by that exactly ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Just ... because things is no different in this world . I can n't put him off no longer ; an ’ father would n't bear with it . An ’ he 's quite right in that matter . Dear Lord ha ’ mercy ! ‘ Tis no easier on that account ! But when it 'll all be off a body 's soul ... I do n't know —She touches her breast .they calls it , I believe , strain o ’ the heart , Oh , times are when I has real pains in my heart ... An ’ a person can n't feel that way all the time .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Well , then there 's nothing more to be done just now . It 's time for me to be getting home .He gets up and throws the rifle across his shoulder .Another time then , Rosie . Good-bye !

sp.speaker: ROSE stares straight in front of her without answering

lg.l: FLAMM
What 's the matter , Rosie ? Wo n't there be another time ?
FLAMM
What , have I hurt you , Rosie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: There 'll never be another time — like this — Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: With despairing passion .Girl , I do n't care if it costs me everything ...

div.stage: He embraces her and kisses her again and again .

lg.stage: Suddenly in extreme terror .
lg.l: For the love o ’ ... some one 's comin ’ ,
Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM in consternation , jumps up and disappears behind a bush
sp.p: ROSE gets up hastily , straightens her hair and her dress and looks anxiously about her . As no one appears she takes up the hoe and begins to weed the potato patch . After a while there approaches , unnoticed by her , the machinist ARTHUR STRECKMANN dressed in his Sunday coat . He is what would generally be called a handsome man — large , broad-shouldered , his whole demeanour full of self-importance . He has a blond beard that extends far down his chest . His garments , from his jauntily worn huntsman 's hat to his highly polished boots , his walking coat and his embroidered waistcoat , are faultless and serve to show , in connection with his carriage , that STRECKMANN not only thinks very well of himself but is scrupulously careful of his person and quite conscious of his unusual good looks .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: As though but now becoming conscious of ROSE 'S presence , in an affectedly well-modulated voice .Good day , Rosie .

lg.stage: Turns frightened .
lg.l: Good day , Streckmann .
lg.stage: In an uncertain voice
lg.l: Why , where did you come from ? From church ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I went away a bit early .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Excitedly and reproachfully .What for ? Could n't you put up with the sermon ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Boldly .Oh , it 's such beautiful weather out . An ’ that 's why ! I left my wife in the church too . A feller has got to be by himself once in a while .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'd rather be in church .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That 's where the women folks belongs .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I should n't wonder if you had your little bundle o ’ sins . You might ha ’ been prayin ’ a bit .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I 'm on pretty good terms with the Lord . He do n't keep such very particular accounts o ’ my sins .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Well , well !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: No , he do n't bother with me much .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: A vain , fool — that 's what you is !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN laughs in a deep and affected tone
sp.p: ROSE If you was a real man , you would n't have to go an ’ beat your wife at home .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: With a gleam in his eyes .That shows that I 'm a real man ! That shows it ! That 's proper ! A man 's got to show you women that he 's the master .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Do n't be fancyin ’ such foolishness .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That 's so , for all you say . Right is right . An ’ I never failed to get what I was wantin ’ that way .

lg.l: STRECKMANN
People says you 're goin ’ to leave Flamm 's service .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'm not in Flamm 's service at all . You see now that I 'm doin ’ other things .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: You were helpin ’ at Flamm 's no later'n yesterday .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Maybe so ! Maybe I was or maybe I was n't ! Look after your own affairs .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Is it true that your father has moved ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Where to ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: With August over into Lachmann 's house .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: August has n't even bought the house yet . Those people — they knows more than I .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: An ’ they says too that you 'll be celebratin ’ your weddin ’ soon .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: They can be talkin ’ for all I care .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: After a brief silence approaches her and stands before her with legs wide apart .Right you are ! You can marry him any time . A fine girl like you do n't need to hurry so ; she can have a real good time first ! I laughed right in his face when he told me . There 's no one believes him .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Quickly .Who 's been sayin ’ it ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: August Keil .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: August himself ? An ’ this is what he gets from his silly talkin ’ .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: After a silence .August he 's such a peevish kind ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I do n't want to hear nothing . Leave me alone ! Your quarrels do n't concern me ! One o ’ you is no better'n another .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well , in some things — when it comes to bein ’ bold .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , heavens ! That boldness o ’ yours . We knows that . Go about an ’ asks the women folks a bit . No , August is n't that kind .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Laughs with lascivious boastfulness .I 'm not denyin ’ that .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ you could n't .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Looking at her sharply through half-closed lids .It 's not comfortable to make a fool o ’ me . What I wants of a woman — I gets .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Jeeringly .Oho !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes , oho ! What would you wager , Rosie ! You been makin ’ eyes at me many a time .

div.stage: He has approached and offered to put his arms around her .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Do n't be foolish , Streckmann ! Keep your hands off o ’ me !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: If it was ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Thrusts him away .Streckmann ! I 've been tellin ’ you ! I do n't want to have nothin ’ to do with you men . Go your own way .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: What am I doin ’ to you ?—After a silence with a smile that is half malicious , half embarrassed .You wait ! You 'll be comin ’ to me one o ’ these days ! I 'm tellin ’ you : you 'll be comin ’ to me yourself some day ! You can act as much like a saint as you wants to .— D'you see that cross ? D'you see that tree ? Confound it ! There 's all kinds o ’ things ! I 've been no kind o ’ a saint myself ! But ... right under a cross ... you might be sayin ’ just that ... I 'm not so very partic'lar , but I 'd take shame at that . What would your father be sayin ’ or August ? Now , just f'r instance : this pear tree is hollow . Well an ’ good . There was a rifle in there .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Has been listening more and more intently in the course of her work . Deadly pale and quivering she bursts out involuntarily :What are you sayin ’ ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Nothin ’ !— I 'm sayin ’ nothin ’ more .— But when a feller has n't no notion of nothin ’ an ’ is thinkin ’ no ill , a wench like you acts as high an ’ mighty !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Losing self-control and leaping in front of him in her terror .What is't you say ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Calmly returning her terrible gaze .I said : A wench like you .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ what 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That 's got no special meanin ’ .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Clenches her fists and pierces him with her eyes in an intense passion of rage , hate , terror and consternation until in the consciousness of her powerlessness she drops her arms and utters almost whiningly the words :I 'll know how to get my good right about this !

div.stage: Holding her right arm before her weeping eyes and wiping her face with the left , she returns , sobbing brokenly , to her work .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Looks after her with his old expression of malicious coldness and determination . Gradually he is seized with a desire to laugh and finally bursts out :That 's the way things go ! Do n't worry a bit .— What do you take me for anyhow , Rose ? What 's the row about ? This kind o ’ thing do n't do no harm ! Why should n't a person fool her neighbours ? Why not ? Who made ‘ em so stupid ? Them as can do it are the finest women in the world ! Of course , a man like me knows how things are ! You can believe me — I 've always known about you .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Beside herself .Streckmann ! I 'll do myself some harm ! Do you hear ? Or else go away from our bit o ’ patch ! Go ... I ... something awful will happen , I tell you !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Sits down and claps his flat hands over his knees .For goodness ’ sake ! Do n't carry on so ! D'you think I 'll be goin ’ about everywhere an ’ tellin ’ what I know an ’ rakin ’ you over the coals ? How does it concern me , I 'd like to know , what your goin 's on are ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'll go home an ’ hang myself on a beam ! That 's what Mary Schubert did too .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That was a different thing with her ! That girl had different things on her conscience ! An ’ I did n't have nothin ’ to do with her .— But if every woman was to go an ’ hang herself on account o ’ what you 've done — there would n't be no more women in this world . That sort o ’ thing happens wherever you look — everywhere — that 's the way things is . O ’ course , I have to laugh . That father o ’ yours , he carries himself so high ! The way he stares at a feller that 's gone a bit off the narrow way . It 's enough to make you want to go an ’ hide your face . Well — people ought to begin at home ...

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Trembling in the terror of her heart .O dear Lord , have mercy !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Can you deny that I 'm right ? You people stick in piety up to the very eyes — your father an ’ August Keil an ’ you too ! A feller like me can n't compete with you there .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: With a new outburst of despair .It 's a lie ... a lie ! You saw nothing !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: No ? Saw nothing ? Well , I 'll be ...! Then I must ha ’ been dreamin ’ . That 's what it must ha ’ been ! If that was n't Squire Flamm from Diessdorf ! I have n't had a drop o ’ anythin ’ to-day . Did n't he play at drivin ’ you by the braids o ’ your hair ? Did n't he throw you into the grass ?With uncontrollable , hard laughter .He had a good hold on you !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Streckmann , I 'll beat your head in with my hoe !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Still laughing .Listen to that ! What now ? You 're not goin ’ to cut up so rough ! Why should n't you ha ’ done it ? I do n't blame you . First come , first served : that 's the way o ’ the world .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Weeping and moaning in her helpless grief and yet working convulsively .A feller like that , presumes to ...!

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Enraged and brutally .It 's you that presumes ! ‘ Tis n't me that does ! Not that I 'd mind presumin ’ a good deal . If Flamm 's good enough , it 's certain that I am !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Sobbing and crying out in her despair .I 've been a decent girl all my life long ! Let anybody come an ’ say somethin ’ against me if he can ! I took care o ’ three little brothers an ’ sisters ! Three o'clock in the mornin ’ I 've gotten up , an ’ not so much as taken a drop o ’ milk ! An ’ people knows that ! Every child knows it !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well , you need n't make such a noise about it ! The bells is ringin ’ and the people is comin ’ from church . You might be a bit sociable with a feller . You people are just burstin ’ with pride . Maybe it 's true ... things look as if it was . I 'm not sayin ’ but what you 're a good worker an ’ a good saver . But otherwise you 're no better'n other folks .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Gazing into the distance ; in extreme fear .Is n't that August that 's comin ’ there ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Looks in the same direction toward the village . Contemptuously :Where ? Oh , yes , that 's him ! There they both are ! They 're just walkin ’ around the parson 's garden . Well , what about it ? You think I ought to be gettin ’ away ? I 'm not afeard o ’ them psalm-singin ’ donkeys .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: In quivering fear .Streckmann , I 've saved up twelve crowns ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Rosie , you know you 've saved more than that .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: All right , I 'll give you all my bit o ’ savin 's ! I do n't care for the money ... I 'll bring it to you , to the last farthing . Streckmann , only have pity ...

div.stage: She seeks to grasp his hands beseechingly , but he draws them away .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I takes no money .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Streckmann ! For the sake o ’ all good things in the world ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well now , I can n't see why you do n't act sensible .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: If one person in the village finds that out ....

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: It depends on you ! Nobody need n't know . All you need to do is not to force it on ‘ em ...With sudden passion .What 's at the bottom of it ?— I 'm crazy about you ...

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Where 's the woman or girl you 're not crazy about !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Maybe it 's so . I can n't change things . A man like me who has to go the round o ’ all the estates in the country with his threshin ’ machine — he do n't have worry because he 's not talked about . I know best how it is with me . Before ever Flamm came — I 'm not mentionin ’ August — I 'd thrown an eye on you . An ’ nobody knows what it 's cost me .With iron stubbornness .But the devil fetch me now ! Come what may , Rosie ! There 's no more use tryin ’ to joke with me ! I happened to come upon somethin ’ to-day !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ what is it ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: You 'll see soon enough .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL , ROSE 'S younger sister , comes skipping along the field-path
sp.p: She is neatly dressed in her Sunday garments and is still pronouncedly child-like .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Calls out .Rose , is that you ? What are you doin ’ here ?

lg.l: I 've got to finish hoein ’ the patch . Why did n't you stop to finish it o ’
Saturday ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Oh , dearie me , Rosie , if father sees you !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: If there 's a bit o ’ profit in it , he wo n't do nothing very bad . You let old Bernd alone for that !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Who is that , Rosie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , do n't ask me ! Old BERND and AUGUST KEIL are approaching along the field-path from the village . The old , white-haired man , as well as the other who is about thirty-five years old , is dressed in his Sunday coat and each carries a hymn book . Old BERND has a white beard ; his voice has a certain softness as though he had had and been cured of a severe pulmonary affection . One might imagine him to be a dignified retired family coachman . AUGUST KEIL , who is a bookbinder , has a pale face , thin , dark moustache and pointed beard . His hair is growing notably thin and he suffers from occasional nervous twitching . He is lean , narrow-chested ; his whole appearance betrays the man of sedentary employment .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Is n't that Rosie ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes , father Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You can n't nowise make the girl stop that . When the fit takes her , she 's got to go an ’ toil — if it 's weekday or holiday .He is quite near her by this time .Is there not time enough o ’ weekdays ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You do too much , Rosie ! There 's no need o ’ that !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: If our good pastor saw that , it 'd hurt him to the very soul . He would n't trust his own eyes .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: An ’ he 's been askin ’ for you again .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Suggestively .They say , too , as he wants her to be his housekeeper .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Noticing him for the first time .Why , that 's Streckmann !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes , here I am , life-size . That girl , she 's as busy as an ant or a bee ! She 'll be workin ’ if her sides crack . She 's got no time to be sleepin ’ in the church .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: It 's little sleepin ’ we does there , I tell you . You might better say that them as are out here do the sleepin ’ an ’ do n't want no awakenin ’ . The Bridegroom is at hand ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: An ’ that 's certainly true ! But the bride , meantime , runs off !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You 're in a merry mood this day .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes , that I am . I could hug a curbstone ... or the handle o ’ your collection bag . I do feel most uncommonly jolly . I could laugh myself sick .

lg.stage: To ROSE .
lg.l: Put up your things an ’ we 'll go home ! Not that way ! That way
I 'm not goin ’ home with you ! Put your hoe in the hollow of the tree !
Carryin ’ that o ’ Sunday would give offence .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: There 's them that even gads about with guns .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: An ’ devils that take no shame carryin ’ a whisky-bottle .

div.stage: He pulls his bottle out of his pocket .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Each man does those things on his own responsibility .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: True . An ’ at his own expense ! Come , take courage an ’ have a drink with me for once .

div.stage: He holds out the bottle to AUGUST who pays no attention to him .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You know well enough that August drinks no spirits !— Whereabouts is your threshin ’ machine now ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: But you , father Bernd ; you can n't go an ’ refuse to take a drop with me ! You 've been a distiller yourself ! My machine is on the great estate down below .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Takes the bottle hesitatingly .Just because it 's you , Streckmann , otherwise I would n't be touchin ’ it . When I was manager of the estate , I had to do a good many things ! But I never liked to distil the drink an ’ I did n't touch it in them days at all .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: To AUGUST who has placed a spade in the hollow of the cherry tree .You just look at that tree ! Piff , paff ! All you got to do is to take your aim and let it fly .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: There 's people that goes hunting o ’ Sundays .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Squire Flamm .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Just so . We ha ’ met him . ‘ Tis bad . I 'm sorry for them folks .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN throws cock-chafers at ROSE
sp.p: ROSE

div.stage: Trembling . ] Streckmann !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What 's wrong ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Nothin ’ ! We 've got a little private quarrel !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You can have your little quarrels . But it 'd be better if you had ‘ em without her .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: With malicious hostility .You take care , August ! Watch out !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Peace ! Do n't be quarrelsome ! In God 's name !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: The dam ’ carrion always spits at me !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Carrion is a dead beast ...!

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: August , let 's be at peace . Father Bernd is right ; people ought to like each other ! An ’ it is n't Christian the way you act sour like ! Come on now ! Have a drink ! You 're not good-lookin ’ , your worst enemy 'd have to admit that , but you 're fine when it comes to readin ’ an ’ writin ’ an ’ you 've got your affairs pretty well arranged ! Well , then , here 's to your weddin ’ — an early one an ’ a merry one !

sp.speaker: BERND takes the bottle and drinks since AUGUST remains quite
sp.p: unresponsive .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I take that real kind o ’ you , father Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: When it comes to drinkin ’ to a happy weddin ’ , I makes an exception !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Exactly ! That 's proper ! That 's right !— It is n't as if I was a horse-boy to-day as in the old times on the estate when you had the whip hand o ’ me . I 've gotten to be a reputable kind o ’ feller . Anybody that 's got a head on his shoulders makes his way .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: God bestows his favours on them he wants to .—To AUGUST .Drink to a happy weddin ’ .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Takes the bottle .May God grant it ! We do n't have to drink to it .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Slapping his thigh .An ’ may he give plenty o ’ little Augusts , so that the grandfather can be glad . An ’ the oldest of ‘ em all must grow up to be a squire !— But now you ought to let Rosie have a drink too .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You 're weepin ’ , Rosie . What 's troublin ’ you ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: The tears keep runnin ’ out o ’ her eyes all the time .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: To ROSE .Drink a drop , so 's to let him have his will .

sp.speaker: ROSE takes the bottle , overcoming her repugnance by a violent
sp.p: effort .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Right down with it now ! Let 's be jolly !

sp.speaker: ROSE drinks trembling and hands back the bottle to AUGUST with
sp.p: undisguised disgust .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Softly in his paternal pride to STRECKMANN .There 's a girl for you ! He 'd better keep a good hold o ’ her .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE SECOND ACT The large living room in FLAMM 'S house . The large , low room which is on a level with the ground has a door at the right leading to the outer hall . A second door in the rear hall leads into a smaller chamber , filled with hunting implements , etc ., which FLAMM calls his den . When this door is open , garments and rifles and stuffed bird heads are to be seen covering the walls of the smaller room . In it stands , also , the chest of drawers in which FLAMM stores the documents kept by him as magistrate . The large room with its three windows on the left side , its dark beams and its furnishings creates an impression of home-likeness and comfort . In the left corner stands a large sofa covered with material of an old-fashioned , flowery pattern . Before it stands an extension table of oak . Above the door of the den hangs a glass case containing a group of stuffed partridges . Immediately to the right of this door a key-rack with keys . Not far from this stands a bookcase with glass doors which is filled with books . Upon this bookcase stands a stuffed owl and next to it hangs a cuckoo clock . A great tile oven of dappled blue occupies the right corner of the room . In all the three windows of the left wall are potted plants in bloom . The window beside the table is open as well as the one farther forward . In front of the latter MRS. FLAMM is sitting in an invalid 's chair . All the windows have mull curtains . Not far from the window nearest to the spectator there is an old chest of drawers covered by a lace scarf upon which are to be seen glasses , bric-a-brac and family mementos of various kinds . On the wall above hang family photographs . Between the oven and the door that leads to the outer hall stands an old-fashioned grand piano and an embroidered piano-stool . The keyboard of the instrument is turned toward the tile oven . Above the piano there are glass cases containing a collection of butterflies . In the foreground , to the right , a brightly polished roller-top desk of oak with a simple chair . Several such chairs are set against the mall near the desk . Between the windows an old armchair covered with brown leather . Above the table a large brass lamp of English manufacture is suspended . Above the desk hangs the large photograph of a handsome little boy of five . The picture is in a simple wooden frame wreathed in fresh field flowers . On top of the desk a large globe of glass covers a dish of forget-me-nots . It is eleven o'clock in the forenoon on a magnificent day of late spring .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM is an attractive , matronly woman of forty . She wears a
sp.p: smooth , black alpaca dress with a bodice of old-fashioned cut , a small cap of white lace on her head , a lace collar and soft lace cuffs which all but cover her emaciated , sensitive hands . A book and a handkerchief of delicate material lie in her lap . MRS. FLAMM 'S features are not without magnanimity and impressiveness . Her eyes are light blue and piercing , her forehead high , her temples broad . Her hair , already gray and thin is plainly parted in the middle . From time to time she strokes it gently with her finger tips . The expression of her face betrays kindliness and seriousness without severity . About her eyes , her nose and her mouth there is a flicker of archness .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Looks thoughtfully out into the open , sighs , becomes absorbed in her book for a moment , then listens and closes her book after inserting a bookmark . Finally she turns toward the door and speaks in a slightly raised , sympathetic voice .Whoever is out there ... come in !A tap is heard , the door to the hall is slightly opened and the head of old BERND is seen .Well , who is it ? Ah , that 's father Bernd , our deacon and trustee . Come right in ! I 'm not going to bite you .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: We was wantin ’ to speak to the squire .

div.stage: He enters , followed by AUGUST KEIL . Both are once more in their best clothes .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , well , you do look solemn .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , Missis .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Good day to you , father Bernd .— My husband was in his den there a minute ago .Referring to AUGUST .And there is your future son-in-law too .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes , by God 's help , Mrs. Flamm .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , then , do take a seat . I suppose you want to make official announcement of the marriage ? It 's to be at last .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes , thanks be to God ; everythin ’ is in readiness now .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I 'm glad o ’ that . This waiting leads to very little . If something is to be , then ‘ tis better to have it done ! So the girl has made up her mind to it at last ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes . An ’ it 's like takin ’ a stone off my heart . She has kept us all hangin ’ about this long time . Now she wants to hurry of her own free will . She 'd rather have the weddin ’ to-day than to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I 'm very glad of that , Mr. Keil ! Very glad , indeed , Bernd . Christie ! I think my husband will be here presently ! So this matter has been adjusted at last ! Well , father Bernd , I think you ought to feel that you 're lucky ! You must be well content .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: An ’ so I am ! You 're right indeed , Mrs. Flamm ! Day before yesterday we talked it all over . An ’ God has given us an especial blessin ’ too . For August went to see the lady of Gnadau an ’ she was so extraordinar ’ kind-hearted as to loan him a thousand crowns . An ’ with that he can go an ’ buy the Lachmann house now .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Is that true ? Is that possible ? Now there you see again how life is , father Bernd . When your master let you go without a bit o ’ pension or anything for your old age , you were quite desperate and hopeless . An ’ ‘ twas an unfeeling thing to do ! But now God has turned everything to good .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: So it is ! But men has too little faith !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , then ! Now you 're well off ! In the first place the house is right opposite the church , an ’ then it has a good bit o ’ land that goes with it ! And Rose , well , I 'm sure she knows how to manage . Yes , you can really be satisfied .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: The blessin 's that a lady like that can spread ! Next to God ... it 's to her we owe the most . If I 'd been in her service an ’ had ruined my health as I did workin ’ for my master , I would n't ha ’ had to complain .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You have nothing more to complain of now , Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: My goodness , no ! In one way not !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You can n't count on gratitude in this world . My father was chief forester for forty years an ’ when he died my mother knew want for all that .— You have an excellent son-in-law . You can live in a pleasant house and you 'll even have your own land to work on . And that everything goes from better to better — well , you can let your children see to that .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: An ’ that 's what I hope for too . No , I have n't no doubt o ’ that at all . A man who has worked himself up in the world that way by carryin ’ tracts ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Were n't you thinking once of being a missionary ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Unfortunately my health was too bad for that .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: An ’ learned readin ’ an ’ writin ’ an ’ his trade too the while , an ’ is so upright an ’ Christian — well , I feel that I can lay down my head in peace if it is to lay it down to my last sleep .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Do you know , by the way , father Bernd , that my husband is giving up his office as magistrate ? He 'll hardly marry your girl .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: They 're in a hurry ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I know , I know . Rose is helpin ’ along too . She was in to see me this morning . If you would n't mind , going to look ... right behind the yard ... Christie !... There he is ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Not yet visible , calls :Presently ! In a moment !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: It 's official business .

sp.speaker: FLAMM , without coat or waistcoat , appears in the door of his den
sp.p: His gleaming white shirt is open in front . He is busy cleaning the barrels of a shotgun .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Here I am . The machinist Streckmann was here just now . I 'd like to have my threshing done at once , but the machine is down there on the estate and they 're far from being done ... Dear me ! Surely that 's father Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Flamm , we have come here . We were wantin ’ to ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: One thing after another ! Patience !He examines the barrels of the gun carefully .If you have official business for the magistrate , you 'd better wait a little while . Steckel will be my successor and he will take these matters a deal more solemnly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Holding her crocheting needle to her chin and observing her husband attentively .Christie , what silly stuff are you talking ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Who , pale from the first , has grown paler at the mention of STRECKMANN 'S name , now arises solemnly and excitedly .Your honour , we want to announce a marriage .— I am ready , by God 's help , to enter into the holy state of matrimony .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Stops looking at the gun . Lightly .Is it possible ? And are you in such a hurry about it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Banteringly .How does that concern you , Christie ? Dear me , let the good folks marry in peace ! You 're a reg'lar preacher , you are ! If that man had his will , father Bernd , there would n't be hardly anything but single men and women .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Well , marriage is a risky business ,— You 're the bookbinder August Keil .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: At your service .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You live over in Wandriss ? And you 've bought the Lachmann house ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Exactly .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And you want to open a book-shop ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: A book and stationery shop . Yes . Probably ,

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: He thinks o ’ sellin ’ mostly devotional books .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: There 's some land that belongs to the Lachmann house , is n't there ? It must be there by the big pear tree ?

sp.speaker: BERND and AUGUST
sp.p: At the same time .Yes .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Why then our properties adjoin !He lays down the barrels of the gun , searches in his pockets for a bunch of keys and then calls out through the door :Minna ! Come and wheel your mistress out !

div.stage: Resignedly though unable to control his disquiet , he sits down at the desk .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: A very chivalrous man ! But he 's in the right ! I 'm in the way just now !To the neat maid who has come in and stepped behind her .Come , my girl , wheel me into the den . An ’ you might well pin up your hair more smoothly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM and the MAID disappear in the den
sp.p: FLAMM I 'm really sorry for the Lachmanns .To KEIL .You invested your savings in a mortgage on that property , did n't you ?AUGUST coughs excitedly and in embarrassment .Well , that 's all the same in the end ! Whoever owns that property , though , has cause to congratulate himself .— So you want to marry ? Well , all that 's wanting is the lady ! How is that ? Is the lady stubborn ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Very much wrought up and quite determined .We 're at one entirely , so far as I know .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I 'll go an ’ fetch her , Mr. Flamm .

div.stage: Exit rapidly .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Who has opened the desk in obvious absentmindedness , observes BERND 'S departure too late .Nonsense , there 's no such terrible hurry .For a few moments he gazes in some consternation at the door through which BERND has disappeared . Then he shrugs his shoulders .Do as you please ! Exactly as you please ! I can light a pipe in the meanwhile .He gets up , takes a tobacco pouch from the bookcase and a pipe from a rack on the wall , fills the pipe and lights it . To AUGUST .Do you smoke ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Nor take snuff ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And you drink no whisky , no beer , no wine ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Nothing except the wine in the sacrament .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Iron principles , I must say ! Quite exemplary !— Come in ! I thought someone was knocking . Or was n't there ? Those confounded ...! You practise a bit of quackery now and then as a diversion , do n't you ?AUGUST shakes his head .I thought you healed by prayer ? Seems to me I heard something like that .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: That would be somethin ’ very different from quackery .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: In what respect ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Faith can move mountains . And whatever is asked in the right spirit ... there the Father is still almighty to-day .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Come in ! Surely someone 's been knocking again ! Come in ! Come in ! Confound it all !Old BERND , very pale himself , urges ROSE to enter . She is pale and resists him . She and FLAMM look steadfastly into each other 's eyes for a moment . Thereupon FLAMM continues :Very well ! Just wait one little minute .He goes into the den as though to search for something .The following colloquy of BERND , ROSE and AUGUST is carried on in eager whispers .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What was Streckmann sayin ’ to you ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Who ? But , father ...

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Streckmann was out there , talkin ’ an ’ talkin ’ to her !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Well , what should he ha ’ been talkin ’ to me about ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: That 's what I 'm askin ’ you .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ I know about nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You ought to have no dealin 's with such a scamp !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Can I help it if he talks to me ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You see , you must confess that he 's been talkin ’ to you !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ if he has ! I did n't listen to him —

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I 'll have to be givin ’ notice about that feller Streckmann . I 'll have to get the help o ’ the law against him . We was walkin ’ past there a while ago where they 're workin ’ with that threshin ’ machine . You hear ? They 're beginnin ’ again !From afar the humming and rumbling of the machine is heard .An ’ then he called out somethin ’ after us . I could n't just rightly hear what it was .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: If a girl talks as much as two words to that man , her good repute is almost ruined .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Well , go an ’ get yourself a better girl .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Re-enters . He has put on a collar and a hunting coat . His demeanour is firm and dignified .Good morning , everybody . Now what can I do for you ? When is this wedding to take place ? What 's the trouble ? You do n't seem to be in agreement . Well , wo n't you please say something ? Well , my good people , it does n't look as though you were really ready . Suppose you take my advice : go home and think it all over once more . And when you 've quite made up your minds come in again .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Dictatorially .The matter 'll be adjusted now .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: I have surely nothing against it , Keil .About to make the necessary notes with a pencil .When is the ceremony to take place ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: As soon as ever it 's possible , we was thinkin ’ .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes ; in four or five weeks if it could be done .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: In four or five weeks ? So soon as that ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Then I must beg you to name the exact date . It 's very difficult to make such arrangements so rapidly and ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Involuntarily from the depth of her painful excitement .An ’ it might well wait a bit longer'n that .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What do you mean , Rosie ? I should say Miss Bernd . We 've known , each other all our lives . But one should n't — be so familiar with a girl who 's betrothed . However , it seems , then , that you are not in agreement ....

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Who has started violently at ROSE 'S words , has stared at her uninterruptedly since . Now he fights down his emotion and says with unnatural calm :Very well then . Good-bye and good luck to you , father Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Stay right where you are , August , I tell you !To ROSE .An ’ as for you ! I 'm tellin ’ you now that you must make up your mind one way or t'other ! D'you understand ? Long enough has I had patience with you , an ’ August too , more than was need . We went an ’ took your foolishness upon ourselves . We was thinkin ': Patience , patience ! The Almighty will bring the lass to her senses . But things gets worse an ’ worse with you . Three days ago you give me your sacred promise an ’ plighted your troth to August , an ’ you yourself was hard put to it to wait . An ’ to-day comes an ’ you want to be shirkin ’ . What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ? What do you think o ’ yourself ? D'you think you can dare anything because you 've been a good , decent lass ? Because you 've had self-respect an ’ been industrious , an ’ no man can say evil o ’ you ? Is that the reason ? Ah , you 're not the only one o ’ that kind . That 's no more'n our dooty ! An ’ we 're not permitted to think anything of ourselves on that account ! There 's others as do n't go gaddin ’ to the dance ! There 's others as has taken care o ’ her brothers an ’ sisters an ’ kept house for an old father ! They 're not all slovens an ’ gadabouts even though you 're a pious , decent lass ! An ’ how would things ha ’ been if you had been different ? The street would ha ’ been your home ! No girl like that could be a daughter o ’ mine ! This man here , August , he has no need o ’ you ! A man like that has but to stretch out his hand ... an ’ he can have any girl he wants , even if her people are of the best . He might be havin ’ a very different wife from yourself ! Truly , a man 's patience can n't bear everything ! It 'll snap sometime ! Pride , arrogance , recklessness — that 's what it is in you ! Either you keep your promise , or ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Now , now , father Bernd ! You must be gentle !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Your honour , you do n't know how it 's been ! A girl that leads on and makes a fool of an honest man that way — she can n't be no daughter o ’ mine !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Nearly weeping .What have you got to reproach me with , Rose ? Why are you so hard toward me ? ‘ Tis true , I never had no confidence in my good fortune ? An ’ why should I have ? I 'm made for misfortune ! An ’ that 's what I 've always told you , father Bernd , in spite of it all I 've taken thought an ’ I 've worked an ’ God has given his blessin ’ so that I 've not fallen by the wayside . But I can weep ; these things are n't for me ! That would ha ’ been too much of a blessin ’ . I grew up in an orphan house ! I never knew what it was to have a home ! I had no brother an ’ no sister ... well , a man can still hold fast to his Saviour .— It may be I 'm not much to look at , lass ! But I asked you an ’ you said yes . ‘ Tis the inner man that counts ! God looks upon the heart ... You 'll be bitter sorry some day !

div.stage: He tries to go but BERND holds him back .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Once more ! Here you stay , August !— D'you understand , Rosie ! I means these words : This man here ... or ... no , I can n't permit that ! That man here was my friend an ’ support long before he asked you to be his wife . When I was down with the sickness an ’ could n't earn nothin ’ , an ’ no one was good to us — he shared his bit o ’ bread with us !AUGUST , unable to master his emotion any longer , takes his hat and goes out .He was like an angel o ’ the Lord to us !— August !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'm willin ’ . Ca n't you give me a little time ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: He 's given you three years ! The good pastor has tried to persuade you ... Now August is tired out ! Who 's to blame him for't ? Everything must end somewhere ! He 's in the right ! But now you can look after yourself an ’ see what becomes o ’ you ... I can n't take no more pride in such a daughter .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: FLAMM Well , well , well , well ! This is the damnedest ...!
sp.p: ROSE has become alternately red and deathly pale . It is clear that she is struggling with emotions so violent that she can scarcely hold them in check . After BERND has gone out the girl seems to fall into a state of desperate numbness .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Closing the public registration book and finding courage to look at ROSE .Rose ! Wake up ! What 's the matter with you ? Surely you 're not going to worry about all that ranting ?A fever seems to shake her and her great eyes are full of tears .Rose ! Be sensible ! What 's the ...?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I know what I want — and — maybe — I 'll be able to put it through ! An ’ — if not — it do n't matter — neither !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Walks up and down excitedly , stopping to listen at the door .Naturally . And why not ?Apparently absorbed in the key-rack from which he takes several keys , whispers in feverish haste .Rose ! Listen ! Rose , do you hear me ? We must meet behind the outbuildings ! I must talk it all over with you once more . Ssh ! Mother 's in there in the den . It 's not possible here !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Uttering her words with difficulty but with an iron energy .Never an ’ never , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: I suppose you want to drive us all mad ? The devil has gotten into you ! I 've been running around after you for the better part of a month , trying to say a sensible word to you and you avoid me as if I were a leper ! What 's the result ? Things of this kind !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: As before .An ’ if everythin ’ gets ten times worse'n it is — no ! You can all beat down on me ; I do n't deserve no better ! Go on an ’ wipe your boots on me , but ...

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Who is standing by the table , turns suddenly with indignant astonishment toward ROSE . He strives to master his rage . Suddenly however he brings down his fist on the table top with resounding violence .I will be damned to all ...!

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: For heaven 's sake ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM , wheeled by a maid servant , appears at the door of the
sp.p: den .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: What is the trouble , Christopher ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM who has turned deadly pale , pulls himself together
sp.p: energetically , takes his hat and cane from the wall and goes out through the door at the right .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Looks at her husband in consternation , shakes her head at his abrupt departure and then turns questioningly to ROSE .What has happened ? What 's the matter with him ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Overwhelmed by her profound wretchedness .Oh , dear Mrs. Flamm , I 'm that unhappy !

div.stage: She sinks down before MRS. FLAMM and buries her head in the latter 's lap .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Now do tell me !... For pity 's sake , lass ... what 's come over you ! What is it ? You 're like a different creature . I can n't never understand that !To the maid who has wheeled her in .I do n't need you now ; you can come back later ! Get everything ready in the kitchen .The maid leaves the room .Now then ! What is the trouble ? What has happened ? Tell me everything ! It 'll ease you ! What ? What is't you say ? Do n't you want to marry that pasty August ? Or maybe you 're carryin ’ some other fellow around in your thoughts ? Dear me ! one o ’ them is about as good as another , an ’ no man is worth a great deal .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Controlling herself and rising .I know what I wants and that 's the end o't !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Is that true ? You see , I was afraid you did n't know ! Sometimes a woman do n't know , especially a young one like you . An ’ then , maybe , an older woman can help a bit . But if you know what you want ,' tis well ! You 'll be findin ’ your own way out o ’ your trouble .Putting on her spectacles , with a keen glance .Rosie , are you ill maybe ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Frightened and confused .Ill ? How ...?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Why , do n't people get ill ? You used to be so different formerly .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But I 'm not ill !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I 'm not sayin ’ it . I just ask . I ask because I want to know ! But we must understand each other rightly ! ‘ Tis true ! Do n't let 's talk round about the thing we want to know , or play hide an ’ seek .— You 're not afraid that I do n't mean well ?ROSE shakes her head vigorously .An ‘ twould be strange if you did . That 's settled then . You used to play with my little Kurt . You two grew up together until it pleased God to take my only child .— An ’ that very time your mother died too an ’ I remember — she was lyin ’ on her deathbed — that she was askin ’ me that I might , if possible , look after you a bit .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Staring straight before her .The best thing for me would be to jump into the river ! If things is that way ... God forgive me the sin !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: If things are that way ? How ? I do n't understand you ! You might well speak a bit more clearly .— In the first place , I 'm a woman myself , an ’ it wo n't astonish me . An ’ then — I 've been a mother myself , even if I have no children now . Lass , who knows what 's wrong with you ? I 've been watchin ’ you for weeks an ’ weeks ; maybe you did n't notice anything , but now I want you to come out with the truth .— Wheel me over to that chest o ’ drawers .ROSE obeys her .So ! Here in these drawers are old things — a child 's clothes an ’ toys . They were Kurt 's ... Your mother said to me once : My Rose , she 'll be a mother o ’ children ! But her blood is a bit too hot !— I do n't know . Maybe she was right .She takes a large doll from one of the drawers .Do you see ? Things may go as they want to in this world , but a mother is not to be despised .— You and Kurt used to play with this doll . ‘ Twas you mainly that took care o ’ her , washed her , fed her , gave her clean linen , an ’ once — Flamm happened to come up — you put her to your breast .— You brought those flowers this morning , did n't you ? The forget-me-nots in the little dish yonder ? An ’ you put flowers on Kurt 's grave o ’ Sunday . Children an ’ graves — they 're women 's care .She has taken a little child 's linen shift from the drawer , she unfolds it , holding it by the sleeves , and speaks from behind it .Did n't you , Rosie ? An ’ I thank you for it , too . Your father , you see , he 's busy with his missionary meetin 's an ’ his Bible lessons an ’ such things . All people are sinners here , says he , an ’ he wants to make angels of ‘ em . It may be that he 's right , but I do n't understand those things . I 've learned one thing in this world , an ’ that is what it is to be a mother an ’ how a mother is blessed with sorrows .

sp.speaker: ROSE overwhelmed and moaning has sunk down beside MRS. FLAMM and
sp.p: kisses the latter 's hands again and again in gratitude and as a sign of confession .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Shows by a sudden gleam in her eyes that she understands the truth and has received the confession . But she continues to speak quietly .You see , lass , that 's what I 've learned . I 've learned that one thing which the world has forgotten . I do n't know very much about anything else . As much as most people , maybe , an ’ that 's not any real knowledge .She lays down the child 's shift carefully on her lap .Well , now you go home an ’ be of good courage ! I 'll be thinkin ’ things over for you . ‘ Tis well so far . I 'll ask you no more just now . You 're different now ... all 's different . An ’ I 'll be doubly careful . I do n't want to know anything , but I want you to depend on me . Little I care , anyhow , who the father is — if ‘ tis a councillor or a beggar . It 's we who have to bring the children into the world , an ’ no one can help us there . Three things you must think about — how about your father , and about August ... an ’ something more . But I have time enough ! I 'll think it all over an ’ I 'll feel that I 'm still good for something in this world .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Has arisen and passed again into a state of moral numbness .No , no , Mrs. Flamm , do n't do that ! You can n't ! Do n't take no interest in me ! I 've not deserved it of him nor of no one ! I know that ! I 've got to fight it through — alone ! There 's no help in others for me ; it 's ... no , I can n't tell you no clearer !... You 're as good to me as an angel ! Dear God , you 're much too good ! But it 's no use ! I can n't take your help . Good-bye ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Wait a little ! I can n't let you go this way . Who knows what you may be doin ’ ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , you can be reel quiet about that , Mrs. Flamm . I 'm not that desperate yet . If there 's need , I can work for my child . Heaven 's high an ’ the world is wide ! If it was just me , an ’ if it was n't for father an ’ if August did n't seem so pitiful ... an ’ then , a child ought to have a father !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Good . You just be resolute . You were always a brave girl . An ’ ‘ tis better if you can keep your courage up !— But , if I 've understood you rightly , I can n't see at all why you want to fight against the weddin ’ .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Becomes sullen , pale and fearful .What can I say ? I do n't hardly know ! An ’ I do n't want to fight against it no more . Only ... Streckmann ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Be open with me , you understand ? For my part you can go home now ! But come back to-morrow ! An ’ listen to this thing I say : Be glad ! A woman ought to be glad of her child ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ God knows that I am ! An ’ I will fight it all through ! Only — nobody can n't help me to do it !

div.stage: Exit quickly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Alone . She looks after ROSE , sighs , takes the child 's shift from her lap , unfolds it as before and says :Ah , lass ,' tis a good fortune that you have , not an evil ! There 's none that 's greater for a woman ! Hold it fast !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE THIRD ACT A fertile landscape . In the foreground , to the right , on a triangular piece of greensward slightly below the level of the fields , there stands an old pear tree , at the foot of which a spring empties into a primitive basin of stone . The middle distance is of meadow land . In the background a pool , bordered by reeds and dotted by water plants , lies in a grove of alder trees and bushes of hazelnut , willow and beech . The meadows extend on either side encircled by immemorial oaks , elms , beeches and birch trees . Between the foliage of the trees and bushes the church spires of distant villages are visible . To the left , behind the bushes , arise the thatched roofs of the field barns . It is a hot afternoon of early August . From afar is heard the hum of the threshing machine . BERND and AUGUST KEIL come from , the right . They are worn out from labour and from the heat . The men are clad only in their shirts , breeches , boots and caps . Each carries a hoe across his shoulder , a scythe in his hand , and carries at his belt a cowherd 's horn and whetstone .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: ‘ Tis hot an ’ to spare to-day . A man must rest a bit ! But a feelin ’ o ’ peace comes to you workin ’ on your own ground .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: The trouble is I 'm not used to mowin ’ .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You went an ’ did your share right bravely .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes , yes ! But how long can I do it ? All my limbs are twitchin ’ an ’ hurtin ’ me now .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You can rest content , my son . A man 's got to be used to that kind o ’ work . An ’ in your case ‘ tis only an exception . But , ‘ s I said , you could well go an ’ be a gard'ner .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: For the space of a day . On the second I 'd collapse . There 's no use ; I 'm but a broken reed . I went to the county physician again . ‘ Twas the same as always . He just shrugged his shoulders .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You 're well now an ’ in God 's hands . The most you might do is to put a few rusty nails in water an ’ drink the rinsings two or three times a week . That purifies the blood an ’ strengthens the heart .— I only hope the weather 'll keep on this way .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: The heat 's too terrible . When we were mowin ’ , I thought I heard thunder .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Kneeling down on the edge of the basin and drinking from the surface of the spring .Water is the best drink for all they say .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: How late is it ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: ‘ Tis about four o'clock , I 'm wonderin ’ what keeps Rose with our evenin ’ meal .He raises his scythe and looks at the blade . AUGUST does the same .Will you have to sharpen ? Mine will do a bit longer .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I can try it this way a while longer .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Throws himself on the grass under the pear tree .You 'd better come an ’ sit down by me . An ’ if , maybe , you got your Testament with you , we might refresh ourselves with the Good Word .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Sitting down exhausted and glad to be free .All I say is : Thanks and praise be to the Lord .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: D'you see , August , I said to you then : Let her be ! The lass will find her own way ! Now she 's come to her senses ! In the old days , before your time , often an ’ often I worried about her . A kind o ’ stubbornness used to come over her from time to time . An ’ ‘ twas always best to let her be !— Sometimes it seemed , as God lives , as if the lass was runnin ’ against a wall — a strong wall that nobody else could n't see , an ’ as if she had to grope her way around it first .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: What got into her that day ... I 'm thankin ’ God on my knees ... but that day I did n't know what to make of it ! Suddenly she — how that came about ...? No , I can n't see the rights of it to this day .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: An ’ how different did she act this time when we went down to the magistrate .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I 'm glad that it 's no longer Squire Flamm .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes , an ’ this time she did n't say a word an ’ in four or five minutes everythin ’ was straight . That 's the way she is . ‘ Tis the way o ’ women .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: D'you think it had somethin ’ to do with Streckmann ? He called out some words behind you that day , an ’ first he had talked to her .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: It may be so , an ’ it may not be so . I can n't tell you . Times is when one can n't get a word out o ’ her . ‘ Tis not a good thing . An ’ on that account I 'm glad that she 'll be the wife of a man who can influence her an ’ take that sullen way from her . You two are meant for one another . ‘ Tis well ! The girl needs to be led , an ’ you have a kind hand an ’ a gentle one .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: When I see that Streckmann , I feel as if I had to look upon the evil one hisself ....

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Maybe she thought as the feller meant mischief . He 's been a sinner from his childhood on ! Many a time his mother complained of it !... It may be ! ‘ Twould n't surprise no one in him .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: When I see that man , I do n't seem to be myself no longer . Hot an ’ cold shudders run down my back , an ’ I come near to accusin ’ our Heavenly Father ... because he did n't make me a Samson in strength . Such times , God forgive me , I have evil thoughts .The whizzing of Streckmann 's engine is heard .There he is !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Do n't take no notice of him .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I wo n't . An ’ when ‘ tis all over , I 'll shut myself up in my four walls an ’ we can lead a quiet life .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: A good , quiet life — God grant it !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: And I do n't want to know nothin ’ of the world no more ! The whole business fills me with horror ! I have taken such a disgust to the world and to men , that I ... Father , I do n't hardly know how to say it ... but when the bitterness o ’ things rises up into my throat — then I laugh ! Then I have a feelin ’ of peace in the thought of death ; and I rejoice in it like a child . A number of thirsty field labourers , an old woman and two young girls , all from the estate of the magistrate FLAMM , come hurriedly across the fields . They are HAHN , HEINZEL , GOLISCH , OLD MRS. GOLISCH , OLD KLEINERT , THE HEAD MAID SERVANT and her ASSISTANT . The men are clad in trousers , the women have their skirts gathered up , shawls over their breasts and manicoloured kerchiefs on their heads .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: Thirty years old , bronzed and vigorous .I 'm always the first at the fountain ! The rest o ’ ye c'n run all ye want to ! Ye can n't never ketch up with me !He kneels down and leans over the spring .Eh , but I 'd like to jump right in .

sp.speaker: THE ASSISTANT MAID
sp.p: Do n't ye dare ! We 've got a thirst too .To the HEAD MAID SERVANT .Have ye a bit of a cup with ye to dip up the water ?

sp.speaker: HEAD MAID SERVANT
sp.p: Hold on there ! I comes first .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: Pulls the two women back by the shoulders and thrusts himself between them up to the spring .First comes the men , then the women folks .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: There 's space enough here for us all . Eh , father Bernd ? Wish you a good meal .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Yes , yes . Only no meal 's been brought for us to eat yet . We 're waitin ’ for it — waitin ’ in vain .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: I ... I ... I 'm wet enough to be wrung out ! My tongue is lyin ’ in my mouth , dry as a piece o ’ charred wood .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Water !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Here ‘ tis , enough for us all ! They all drink greedily , some immediately from the surface of the mater , some out of their hollowed hands , others out of their hats or out of little cups and bottles . The sounds of swallowing and of deep relieved breathing are clearly audible .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: Getting up .Water 's a good thing but beer would be a better .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: An ’ a bit o ’ brandy would n't come amiss neither .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: August , you might be treatin ’ us to a quart .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: He 'd better invite us all to the weddin ’ .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: We 're all comin ’ to the weddin ’ . They says it 's to be soon .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: I 'm not comin ’ . What for ? To swill cold water ? I need n't go no farther than the spring for that . Or for the sake of a little coffee .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: An ’ prayin ’ an ’ singin ’ for dessert . An ’ mebbe , there 's no tellin ’ , the parson from Jenkau will come over an ’ see if we know the ten commandments .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: Or the seven beatitudes on top o ’ that ! That 'd be a fine state of affairs . I 've long forgot it all .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: You folks had better stop teasin ’ August . I 'm tellin ’ you now , if I had a girl of my own , I would n't be wantin ’ no better son-in-law . He knows his business ! You always know where to find him . The working men and women have scattered themselves at ease in a semicircle and are eating their evening meal ; coffee in tin pots and great wedges of bread from which they cut pieces with their clasp-knives .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: There comes Rosie Bernd around from behind the farm .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: Look an ’ see , will you , how that girl can jump .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: She can lift a sack o ’ wheat and drag it to the very top o ’ the barn . This very mornin ’ I saw her with a great heavy chest o ’ drawers on a wheelbarrow , trundlin ’ it over to the new house . That there girl has got sap an ’ strength . She 'll take care o ’ her household .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: If I could get along in the world like August in other respecks , my faith , I would n't a bit mind tryin ’ ; I 'd see what bein ’ pious can do for a man .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: You 've got to know how to run after good fortune ; then you 'll get hold of it .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: When you consider how he used to go around from village to village with a sack full o ’ tracts ; an ’ how , after that , he used to be writin ’ letters for people ... an ’ now , to-day , he 's got the finest bit o ’ property an ’ can marry the handsomest girl in the county .

sp.speaker: ROSE BERND approaches . In a basket she is carrying the evening meal
sp.p: for AUGUST and OLD BERND .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: A good afternoon to you .

sp.speaker: SEVERAL VOICES
sp.p: Good evenin ’ !— Good evenin ’ ! Many thanks !

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: You 're lettin ’ your sweetheart starve , Rosie .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Merrily unpacking the food .Do n't you worry ! He do n't starve so easy as that .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: You must be feedin ’ him well , Rosie , or he 'll put on no flesh .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: That 's true . He 'll be a sight too lean for you , lass .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Where have you been keepin ’ yourself so long ? We 've been waitin ’ this half hour .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: In a subdued but annoyed voice .An ’ now the whole crowd is here again ! An ’ we might have been through this long time .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Let him scold , lass , an ’ do n't mind it .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Who 's scoldin ’ ? There 's no one here to scold . August would n't do it in a lifetime .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Even so ! But that 's right : you should n't care nothin ’ about it .

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: ‘ Cause , if he do n't scold now , that 'll be comin ’ later .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'm not afraid o ’ that ever comin ’ .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: You 're mighty friendly , all of a sudden .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: We was always agreed with each other , was n't we , August ? What are you laughin ’ at ?She kisses him . Laughter is heard among the people .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: Well , well , and I thought as I might be climbin ’ into her window some day .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: If you did , you 'd be carrying home your bones in a handkerchief !

sp.speaker: THE HEAD MAID SERVANT
sp.p: Sarcastically .O Lordy , Lordy ! I 'd try it all the same . You can n't never tell .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Sombre but calm .Take care what you 're sayin ’ , woman .

lg.l: Hear what he says , I tell you ! Be careful of what you 're sayin ’ . Old
Bernd , he do n't take no jokes .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: She 's not sayin ’ anythin ’ special . Let her be .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Lighting his pipe .He may be lookin ’ real mild now , but when he lets go , you wo n't hardly believe it . I know how it used to be when he was manager of the estate ; the women folks did n't have much cause for laughin ’ then . He got the upper hand o ’ ten like you ; there was n't no gaddin ‘ about with fellers for them !

sp.speaker: HEAD MAID SERVANT
sp.p: Who 's gaddin ’ about with fellers , I 'd like to know !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: You 'd better be askin ’ the machinist , Streckmann ,

sp.speaker: HEAD MAID SERVANT
sp.p: Crimson .For all I care you can ask the Lord hisself !All present laugh .The machinist STRECKMANN appears . He is dusty and comes straight from the threshing machine . He shows the effects of liquor .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Who 's talkin ’ about the machinist Streckmann aroun ’ here ? He 's right here ! He 's standin ’ right here . Anybody wantin ’ to pick a quarrel with him ? Good day to you all ! Hope you 're havin ’ a pleasant meal .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Talk of the devil an ’ he appears .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: An ’ you 're the devil 's grandmother , I suppose .He takes off his cockade and wipes the sweat from his forehead .I tell you people I can n't keep up with this : this kind o ’ work uses a man up skin and bones !— Hello , August ! Good day to you , Rosie ! Well , father Bernd — Great God , can n't anybody answer ?

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: Let him be ! Some people 's better off than they can stand .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: The Lord lets his own people have an easy time . A feller like me works and works and can n't get ahead .He has assumed a reclining position and squeezed himself between HEINZEL and KLEINERT . He now hands his whisky bottle to HEINZEL .Let her go aroun ’ .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: You live the best life of us all , Streckmann ! What in Heaven 's name has you to complain about ? You drinks your drinks and makes three times over what we do — all for standin ’ by the machine a bit .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: What I want is work for my brain . I got a head on me . That 's what you bran-heads can n't understand . Of course ! What does an old woman know about that ! An ’ , anyhow — the trouble I got ....

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: Lord , Streckmann and trouble —

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: More than enough !— there 's somethin ’ that sticks into me , I can tell you — sticks into my belly and into my heart . I feel so rotten bad I 'd like to be doin ’ somethin ’ real crazy .To the ASSISTANT MAID .Lass , shall I lie down with you ?

sp.speaker: ASSISTANT MAID
sp.p: I 'll bang you over the head with a whetstone !

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: That 's just what 's troublin ’ him ; everythin ’ gets black before his eyes , he do n't see nothin ’ more , an ’ sudden like , he 's lyin ’ abed with a lass .

div.stage: Loud laughter .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yon can laugh , ye ragamuffins , laugh all ye want to ! It 's no laughin ’ matter with me , I can tell ye .Blustering :I 'll let the machine squeeze off one of my arms ! Or ye can run the piston through me if ye want to ! Kill me , for all I care .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: Or mebbe you 'd like to set a barn afire .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: By God ! There 's fire enough inside of me . August there , he 's a happy man ...

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Whether I 'm happy or whether I 'm unhappy , that do n't concern no one in this world .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: What am I doin ’ to you ? Ca n't you be sociable with a feller ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I 'll look for my society elsewhere .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Looks at him long with smouldering hatred ; represses his rage and grasps the whisky bottle which has been handed back to him .Give it to me ! A feller 's got to drown his sorrow !—To ROSE .You need n't be lookin ’ at me ; a bargain 's a bargain .He gets up .I 'm goin ’ !— I do n't want to come between you .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: You can go or you can stay for all I care .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Calling STRECKMANN back .Look here , Streckmann , what was that happened t'other day ? About three weeks ago at the threshin ’ machine ?...

div.stage: Men and women burst into laughter .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That 's all over . I do n't know nothin ’ about that .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: An ’ yet , you swore by all that was good and holy ....

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: You people stop your gossippin ’ .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: He need n't be talkin ’ so big all the time .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Comes back .And I tell you what I says , that I puts through . I 'll be damned if I do n't ! Let it go at that . I do n't say no more .

div.stage: Exit .
