sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH It 's done just as easy without talkin ’
sp.p: STRECKMANN

div.stage: Comes back , is about to speak out , but restrains himself . ] Never mind ! I do n't walk into no such trap ! But if you want to know exactly what it 's all about , ask August there or father Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What 's all this about ? What 's this we 're supposed to know ?

lg.l: ‘ Twas that time you went to the magistrate 's , ‘ twas that time ! An ’ did n't
Streckmann pass you on the road an ’ did n't he cry out somethin ’ after ye ?

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: It 's about time for you to be stoppin ’ .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: An ’ why , I 'd like to know ? That 's all nothin ’ but a joke ... People wonders if that there time you all agreed , or if Rosie was n't so willin ’ to join in !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: God Almighty forgive you all for your sins ! What I wants to ask you is this : Why can n't the whole crowd o ’ you leave us in peace ? Or is it that we ever did any harm to any o ’ ye ?

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: An ’ we 're not doin ’ any wrong neither .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ whether I was willin ’ on that day or not — you need n't give yourself no concern about that ! I 'm willin ’ now an ’ that settles it ,

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: That 's the right way , Rosie !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Who has hitherto been reading , with apparent absorption , in his New Testament , now closes the book and arises .Come , father , let 's go to work .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: That takes it out o ’ you more than pastin ’ prayer books together or stirrin ’ the paste in your pot !

sp.speaker: HEINZEL
sp.p: And how do you think he 'll feel after the weddin ’ ? A girl like Rosie — she makes demands !

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Also laughing .Gee ...! I almost said somethin ’ I ought n't to !—He steps back among the people .I 'll give you a riddle to guess . Shall I ? Still waters run deep ! ‘ Tis bad . You must n't taste blood — no , no ! The thirst only gets worse an ’ worse — that 's all .

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: What 's that ? Where did you get the taste o ’ blood ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I suppose he means the taste for whisky !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I 'm goin ’ my way ! Good-bye ! I 'm a good feller ! Good-bye , father Bernd ! Good-bye , August ! Good-bye , Rosie !To AUGUST .What 's wrong ?— August , do n't be showin ’ off . ‘ Tis all well ! I 'm willin ’ ! You 'll not see me again ! But you — you 've got reason enough to be grateful to me . You 've always been an underhanded kind o ’ crittur ! But I 've given my consent to let things be ! I 've given my consent an ’ everything can go smoothly .

div.stage: STRECKMANN goes .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: With violent energy .Let him talk , August ; pay no attention to him .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Flamm is comin ’ !He looks at his watch .‘ Tis over half an hour !

div.stage: The whistle of the engine is heard .

sp.speaker: HAHN
sp.p: During the general stir .Forward , Prussians ! It 's misery whistlin ’ for us ! The workingmen and the maids disappear swiftly with their scythes . ROSE , OLD BERND and AUGUST remain alone on the scene .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: All the evil on earth seems broken loose here ’ What 's all that Streckmann is sayin ’ ? Tell me , Rose , do you understand it ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , an ’ I 've got better things to be thinkin ’ of !She gives AUGUST a friendly nudge on the head .Is n't it so , August ? We have no time for nonsense ! We have to hurry these comin ’ six weeks .

div.stage: She gathers up the remnants of the meal in her basket .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Come over to us a bit later .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I must wash and iron and sew buttonholes . ‘ Tis almost time now .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: We 'll be comin ’ to our supper after seven .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Before he goes , earnestly :Do you care for me , Rosie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Yes , I do care for you .

sp.speaker: AUGUST disappears and ROSE is left alone . The hum of the threshing
sp.p: machine is heard as well as the muttering of thunder on the horizon . After ROSE has replaced bread , butter , the coffee pots and cups into her basket , she straightens herself up and seems to become aware of something in the distance which attracts her and holds her captive . With sudden , determination , she snatches up the head kerchief that has fallen to the ground and hurries off . Before she has disappeared from view , however , FLAMM becomes visible on the scene and calls to her .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Rose ! Wait there ! Confound it all !Rose stands still with her face turned away .You are to give me a drink ! I suppose I 'm worth a draught of water .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: There 's plenty of water here .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: I see . I 'm not blind . But I do n't care to drink like the beasts . Have you no cups in your basket ?ROSE pushes the cover of her basket aside .Well , then ! You even have a cup of Bunzlauer ware ! I like to drink out of that best of all .She hands him the cup , still with averted face .I beg your pardon . You might practise a little politeness ! I suppose you 'll have to force yourself to it this one more time .ROSE walks over to the spring , rinses the cup , fills it with water , sets it down next to the spring and then returns to her basket . She picks the latter up and waits with her back to FLAMM .No , Rosie — that wo n't do at all . You might get rid of some gaol bird in that fashion . I do n't know the habits of such persons very exactly . As things are , I 'm still the magistrate Flamm . Am I going to get a drink or am I not ? Well : One ... two ... three ... and ... there 's an end to this , I ’ beg for some decency ! No more nonsense !ROSE has returned to the spring , has picked up the cup and now holds it out to FLAMM , still refusing to look at him .So ! Higher , though , a little higher ! I can n't get at it yet !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But you must hold it .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: How can I drink this way ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Amused against her will , turns her face to him .Oh , but ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: That 's better already !— That 's good !—Apparently unintentionally and as if merely to hold the cup , he puts his own hands upon ROSE 'S which support it . His mouth at the rim he lowers himself more and more — until he kneels on one knee .So ! Thank you , Rosie ! Now you can let me go .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Making gentle efforts to disengage herself .Oh , no ! Do let me be , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Is that so ? You think , then , that I ought to let you be ? Now , when at last I 've succeeded in catching you ! No , lassie ,' tis not so easy as that . It wo n't do and you need n't ask it of me . You need n't wear yourself out ! You can n't escape me ! First of all , look me square in the eyes once more ! I have n't changed ! I know ; I know about — everything ! I 've had ‘ a talk with the magistrate Steckel about your having agreed to everything now . I thank God that I 'm no longer the official who attends to the matchmaking ! Another man takes care of the man-traps now . I even know the date of the funeral ... I 'll be ... I meant the wedding , of course . And in addition , I 've talked to myself , too . Rose , ‘ tis a hard nut ! I hope we wo n't break our teeth on it !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I dare not stand this way with you here .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You must . Whether you may or not — I do n't care ! In fact I do n't give a tinker 's damn ! If this thing is really decreed in the council of God , as the song has it — I want a dismissal in all due form : I refuse to be just coolly shunted off .— Rose , is there anything in the past for which I need to ask your forgiveness ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Touched , shakes her head with energy .Nothin ’ , nothin ’ at all , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: No ? Is that honest ?ROSE nods a hearty affirmation .Well , I 'm glad of that , at least ! I hoped it would be so . Then at least we can keep something that 's harmonious in our memories . Ah , Rose , it was a good , good time ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ you must go back to your wife ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: A good time ! And it rushes past ... past ! And what do we keep of it ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: You must be kind , very kind to your wife , Mr. Flamm . She 's an angel ; ‘ tis she that saved me !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Come , let 's sit down under the pear tree ! Very well . But why talk of it ? I 'm always kind to my wife . Our relations are the very friendliest . Come , Rose ! Tell me all about that . What d'you mean by that ? Saved ? What did she save you from , Rose ? I 'd naturally like to know that ! What was the matter with you ? Mother did drop all sorts of hints ; but I was no wiser for them .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Mr. Christopher ... Mr. Flamm ! I can n't sit down here . An ’ it do n't matter ! It can n't lead to anythin ’ . ‘ Tis all over an ’ past now — well — ‘ tis all dead an ’ gone . I know God will forgive me the sin . An ’ He wo n't lay it up against the poor , innocent child neither . He 's too merciful to do that !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Alluding to the hum of the threshing machine which grows louder and louder .That confounded buzzing all the time !— What did you say , Rose ? Sit down just a moment . I wo n't harm you ; I wo n't even touch you ! I give you my word , Rose . Have some confidence in me ! I want you to speak out — to tell what 's on your heart !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I do n't know ... there 's ... there 's just nothin ’ more to say ! When once I 'm married , you can go an ’ ask the good missis . Maybe she 'll tell you then what was the trouble with me . I have n't told August nothin ’ either . I know he 's good . I 'm not afraid o ’ that . He 's soft o ’ heart an ’ a good Christian man . An ’ now : Good-bye , Christie — keep well .— We 've a long life ahead of us now an ’ , maybe , we can be reel faithful an ’ do penance an ’ work hard an ’ pay off the debt .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Holding ROSE 'S hand fast in his .Rose , stay one moment . It 's all right and I must be satisfied . I 'm not coming to your wedding , God knows ! But even if I do n't come to your wedding , still I admit that you 're right .— But , oh , lass , I 've loved you so truly , so honestly .... I can never tell you how much ! And it 's been , upon my word , as far back as I can think .— You had crept into my heart even in the old days when you were a child and were always so honest ... so frank about a thousand little things — so straight and true , however things were . No sneakiness , no subterfuge — whatever the consequences . I 've known women enough in Tarant and in Eberswalde at the agricultural college and in the army , and I was usually lucky with them — ridiculously so . And yet I never knew true happiness except through you .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , Christie , I 've loved you too !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Why you 've been in love with me ever since you were a little thing ! Why you used to make eyes at me .... Do you believe you 'll ever think of it ? And think of the mad , old sinner Flamm ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: That I will . I have a pledge ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You mean the ring with the bit of stone ? And wo n't you come to our house some time ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , that can n't be . That would cut a body too sorely to the heart . That would n't be nothin ’ but double sufferin ’ an ’ misery ! There 's got to be an end to it all . I 'll bury myself in the house ! There 's work an ’ moil enough for two ! ‘ Tis a new life that 's beginnin ’ an ’ we must n't look back on the old life . There 's nothin ’ but sorrow an ’ heart 's need on this earth ; we has to wait for a better place .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And so this is to be our last farewell , Rose ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Father an ’ August will be wonderin ’ now .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And if the little fishes in the river were to stand on their tails in wonderment and the bitterns on the trees did the same — I would n't lose one second — now ! So it 's to be all , all over and done with ? And you wo n't even come to see mother ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Shaking her head .I can n't look her in the face no more ! Maybe some day ! Maybe in ten years or so ! Maybe all this 'll be conquered then . Good-bye , Mr. Christie ! Good-bye , Mr. Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: So be it . But , lass , I tell you , if it were n't for mother ... now ... even now ... I would n't fool around much ... I would n't give you much time ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Yes , if it was n't for that little word “ if ” ! If August was n't livin ’ , an ’ father was n't — who knows what I 'd do . I 'd like to go out into the wide world .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And I with you , Rose ! Well , then we know what 's in our hearts .— And now you might give me your hand once more ....He presses her hand and their glances melt hotly into each other in this last farewell .So it is . What was to be , must be ! I suppose we must leave each other now .

div.stage: He turns resolutely and walks away with firm steps and without looking back .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Looking after him , mastering herself , with tense volition :What must be , must be !— ‘ tis well now !—

div.stage: She put back the can into her basket and is about to walk in the opposite direction .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN appears
sp.p: STRECKMANN

div.stage: With pale , contorted face , creeping and basely hesitant in demeanour . ] Rose ! Rose Bernd ! D'you hear ? That was that rascally Flamm again ! If ever I gets my hand on him ... I 'll smash every bone in his carcase !— What 's up ? What did he want again ! But I 'm tellin ’ you this : things do n't go that way ! I wo n't bear it ! One man is as good as another ! I wo n't let nobody turn me off this way !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: What d'you say ? Who are you anyhow ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Who am I ? Damn it , you know that well enough !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Who are you ? Where did I ever see you ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Me ? Where you saw me ? You ? You can look for somebody else to play your monkey tricks on !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: What do you want ? What are you ? What business has you with me ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: What business ? What I wants ? Nothin ’ much , y'understand ? God ... do n't scream so !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'll call for all the world to come if you do n't get out o ’ my way this minute !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Think o ’ the cherry tree ! Think o ’ the crucifix ....

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Who are you ! Lies ! Lies ! What do you want with me ? Either you get away from here straightway ... or I 'll cry out for some one to come an ’ help me !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Girl , you 've lost your senses !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Then I wo n't have to drag ‘ em around with me no longer ! Who are you ! Lies ! You 've seen nothin ’ ! I 'll cry out ! I 'll shriek as long as I has breath in my body , if you do n't go this very second .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Frightened .I 'm goin ’ , Rosie . It 's all right .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But now ! This minute ! Y'understand !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Right away ! For all I care ! An ’ why not ?He makes a farcical gesture as though avoiding a shower of rain .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Half-mad with rage and scorn .There he runs ! The vile scoundrel ! When you see a fellow like that from behind , you see the best side o ’ him ! Fy , I says ! He 's all smooth an ’ spruce on the outside , an ’ his innards rotten as dirt . A body could die o ’ disgust !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Turns , pale and sinister .Ah ...! An ’ is that so indeed ! You do n't never mean it !... ‘ Tis not very appetisin ’ the way you makes it out . Why was you so hot after it , then ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I ? Hot after you ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Maybe you 've forgotten already ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Scoundrel !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Maybe I am .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Scoundrel ! Ruffian ! Why do you go sniffin ’ around me now ! Who are you ? What has I done ? You stuck to my heels ! You followed me an ’ baited me an ’ snapped at me ... Rascal ... worse'n a dog ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: ‘ Twas you that ran after me !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: What ...?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: You came to my house an ’ made things hot for me !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ you ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well , what ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ you ? An ’ you ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well , I do n't refuse a good thing that 's offered .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Streckmann ! You has to die some day ! D'you hear ? Think o ’ your last hour ! You has to stand before your Judge some day ! I ran to you in the awful terror o ’ my heart ! An ’ I begged you for the love o ’ God not to put nothin ’ between me an ’ August . I crept on my knees before you — an ’ you say , you , I ran after you ! What was it truly ? You committed a crime — a crime against me ! An ’ that 's worse'n a scoundrel 's trick ! ‘ Twas a crime — doubly and trebly ! An ’ the Lord 'll bring it home to you !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Listen to that ! I 'll take my chances !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Is that what you say ? You 'll take your chances in that court ? Then a person can spit in your face !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Think o ’ the cherry tree ! Think o ’ the crucifix !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ you swore to me that you 'd never mention it again ! You swore by all that 's holy . You put that hand o ’ yours on the cross , an ’ by the cross you swore — an ’ now you 're beginnin ’ to persecute me again ! What do you want ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I 'm as good as Flamm . An ’ I do n't want no more goin 's on between you an ’ him !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I 'll jump into his bed , scoundrel ! An ’ it would n't concern you that much !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Well , we 'll see what 'll be the end of all that !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: What ? ‘ Tis violence that you did to me ! You confused me ! You broke me down ! You pounced on me like a wild beast ! I know ! I tried to get out by the door ! An ’ you took hold an ’ you rent my bodice an ’ my skirt ! I bled ! I might ha ’ gotten out by the door ! Then you shot the latch ! That 's a crime , a crime ! An ’ I 'll denounce ....

sp.speaker: BERND and AUGUST appear on the scene . After them KLEINERT and
sp.p: GOLISCH and the other field hands .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Close to STRECKMANN .What 's all this ? What did you do to my lass ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Pulls BERND back and thrusts himself forward .‘ Tis my place , father . What did you do to Rosie ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Nothin ’ !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Coming forward again .What did you do to the lass ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Nothin ’ !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Approaching STRECKMANN once more .You 'll tell us now what you did to her !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Nothin ’ ! The devil ! I say nothin ’ !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You 'll either be tellin ’ us now what you did to her — or ...

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Or ? Well , what ? What about “ or ” ?— Hands off !... Take your hands from my throat ! !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Trying to separate them .Hold on , now .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Hands off , I tell you !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You 'll have to take the consequences now ! Either ...

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: What did you do to the girl ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Backing , in sudden fright , toward the pear tree , cries out :Help !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: What did you do to the girl ? Answer me that ! I got to know that !

div.stage: He has freed himself and faces STRECKMANN .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Lifts his arm and strikes AUGUST full in the face .There 's my answer ! That 's what I did !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Streckmann !

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Catch hold o ’ August ! He 's fallin ’ !

sp.speaker: HEAD MAID
sp.p: Supports the falling man .August !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Paying no attention to AUGUST , but addressing STRECKMANN :You 'll have to account for this ! It 'll be brought home to you !

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: What ? On account o ’ that there wench that 's common to anybody as wants her ....

div.stage: Withdraws .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What was that he said ...?

lg.stage: Who is helping the MAID , HAHN , GOLISCH and MRS. GOLISCH support AUGUST .
lg.l: His eye is out !

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: Father Bernd , August did n't fare so very well this time ....

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: ‘ Tis an evil wooin ’ that he has !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What ? How ? Christ In Heaven !He goes to him .August !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: My left eye hurts that bad !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Rose , bring some water !

sp.speaker: OLD MRS. GOLISCH
sp.p: ‘ Tis a misfortune .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Rose , fetch some water ! D'you hear me ?

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: That 'll mean a good year o ’ prison !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Suddenly awakening from a dazed condition .He says ... he says ... What 's the meanin ’ o ’ ... Did n't I get a doll o ’ Christmas ....

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: To ROSE .Are you asleep ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: There 's no tellin ’ what ... No , lass : it can n't be done ! Such things do n't come to good ! ... Mebbe a girl can n't do without a mother .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE FOURTH ACT The same room in FLAMM 'S house as in the second act . It is a Saturday afternoon toward the beginning of September . FLAMM is sitting over his accounts at the roller-top desk . Not far from the door to the hall stands STRECKMANN .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: According to this there is due you the sum of twelve pounds , ten shillings , sixpence .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What was wrong with the machine ? You stopped working one forenoon ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I had a summons to appear in the county court that day . There was n't nothin ’ wrong with the machine .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Was that in connection with the trouble about ... Keil ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes . An ’ besides that Bernd sued me for slanderin ’ his daughter .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Has taken money from a special pigeon hole and counts it out on the large table .Here are twelve pounds and eleven shillings . So you owe me sixpence .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Pockets the money and gives FLAMM a small coin .An ’ so I 'm to tell the head bailiff that by the end o ’ December you 'll be ready for me again .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Yes , I want you for two days . Say , by the beginning of December . I 'd like to empty the big barn at that time .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: By the beginnin ’ o ’ December . All right , Mr. Flamm . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Good-bye , Streckmann . Tell me , though , what 's going to be the outcome of that affair ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Stops and shrugs his shoulders .It is n't goin ’ to be much of an outcome for me !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I suppose I 'll have to suffer for it .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What consequences a little thing will sometimes have !— How did it happen that you quarreled ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: I can n't say as I can remember clearly . That day — I must ha ’ been off my head — but the truth is I just can n't get it straight how it did happen .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: The bookbinder is known to be a very peaceable man .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: An ’ yet he 's always quarrelin ’ with me ! But the thing 's just gone from me .— All I know is that they fell on me just like hungry wolves ! I thought they was tryin ’ to kill me right there ! If I had n't been thinkin ’ that , my hand would n't ha ’ slipped the way it did .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And the man 's eye could n't — be saved ?

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: No , an ’ it makes a feller feel sorry . But ... there 's nothin ’ to be done . The misfortune is n't on my conscience .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: A thing of that kind is bad enough in itself . And when the courts take a hand in it , that only makes it worse . I 'm especially sorry for the girl .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: Yes ; I 'm thin an ’ wasted with the misery of it . It 's gone straight to my heart . I tell you , your honour , I do n't know what it is to sleep no more . I have n't got nothin ’ against August really . But , as I said , I just can n't account for it .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You ought to go over and see Bernd some day . If you insulted his daughter and were n't in a clear state of mind , you could simply retract what you said .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN
sp.p: That 's none o ’ my business . That 's his'n . Of course , if he knew what 'll come out — he 'd take back his accusation . Somebody else ought to tell him . He 's not doin ’ the girl no service by it . That 's how things is . Good-bye , your honour .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Good-bye .

sp.speaker: STRECKMANN leaves the room
sp.p: FLAMMExcitedly , to himself .If one could only get at the throat of a creature like that !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM is wheeled in by a maid from FLAMM 'S den
sp.p: MRS. FLAMM What are you muttering about again ?—At a gesture from her the maid retires .— Did you have any annoyance ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Oh , yes ; a little .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Was n't that Streckmann ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: The handsome Streckmann . Yes , that was the handsome Streckmann .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: How is that affair getting on now , Christie ? Did you talk about Keil ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Scribbling .Oh , pshaw ! My head is full of figures .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Do I disturb you , Christie ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: No ; only you must keep quiet .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: If I can n't do anything else — you can be sure I can do that .

div.stage: Silence .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Bursting out .I 'll be damned and double damned ! There are times when one would like to take a gun and simply shoot down a scoundrel like that ! There 'd be no trouble about taking that on one 's conscience .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: But , Christie , you really frighten me .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: It is n't my fault ! I 'm frightened myself !— I tell you , mother , that man is so low , so rotten with evil ... I tell you ... at least he has spells when he 's that way ... that a man like myself , who is no saint either , feels as if his very bowels were turning in him ! There 's no end to that kind of corruption . A man may think he knows life inside out , that he 's digested some pretty tough bits himself — but things like that — crimes — I tell you , one never gets beyond the elements in that kind of knowledge !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: What has roused you so again ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Writing again .Oh , I 'm only speaking in general .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I thought it was somehow connected with Streckmann . Because , Christie , I can n't rid myself of the thought of that affair . And when it 's convenient to you some day , I 'd like to have a good talk with you about it !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: With me ? How does Streckmann concern me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Not Streckmann exactly — not the man . But surely old Bernd and Rose . As far as the girl is concerned , ‘ tis bitter earnest for her — the whole thing ! And if I were n't tied down here as I am , I would have gone over to see her long ago . She 's never seen here any more .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You ... you want to go and see Rose ? What do you want of her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: But , do n't you see , Christie — you understand that — she is n't exactly the first comer ! I ought to see about setting her affairs to rights a bit !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Ah well , mother ! Do what you think is your duty . I hardly think that you 'll accomplish much for the girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: How is that , Christie ? What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: One should n't mix up into other people 's affairs . All you get for your pains is ingratitude and worry .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Even so ! We can bear the worry , an ’ ingratitude — that 's what you expect in this world . An ’ as far as Rose Bernd is concerned , I always felt as if she were more than half my own child . You see , Christie , as far as I can think back — when father was still chief forester — her mother already came to wash for us . Afterward , in the churchyard , at our little Kurt 's grave — I see the girl standin ’ as clear as if it was to-day , even though I was myself more dead than alive . Except you an ’ me , I can tell you that , nobody was as inconsolable as the girl .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Do as you please , as far as I 'm concerned ! But what are your intentions exactly ? I can n't think what you 're after , child !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: First , I 'm going to be real curious now .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Oh , about nothing you can describe exactly ! You know , usually , I do n't interfere in your affairs . But now ... I 'd like real well to know ... what 's come over you this while past ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Over me ? I thought you were talking about Rose Bernd .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: But now I 'm talking about you , you see .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: You can spare yourself the trouble , mother . My affairs are no concern of yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You say that ! ‘ Tis easily said . But if a person sits still as I have to do and sees a man growing more an ’ more restless , an ’ unable to sleep o ’ nights , an ’ hears him sighin ’ an ’ sighin ’ , and that man happens to be your own husband — why , you have all kinds of thoughts come over you !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Now , mother , you 've gone off your head entirely . You seem to want to make me look utterly foolish ! I sigh ! Am I such an imbecile ? I 'm not a lovelorn swain .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: No , Christie , you can n't escape me that way !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Mother , what are you trying to do ? Do you want , simply , to be tiresome , to bore me ? Eh ? Or make the house too disagreeable to stay in ? Is that your intention ? If so , you 're going about it the best way possible .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I do n't care what you say ; you 're keeping something secret !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .Do you think so ?— Well , perhaps I am keeping something from you ! Suppose it is so , mother .... You know me .... You know my nature in that respect .... The whole world could turn upside down and not get that muchhe snaps his fingersout of me ! As for annoyance ... everyone has his share of it in this world ! Yesterday I had to dismiss one of the brewers ; day before yesterday I had to send a distiller to the devil . And , all in all , apart from such incidents , the kind of life one has to live here is really flat and unprofitable enough to make any decent individual as cross as two sticks .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Why do n't you seek company ? Drive in to town !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Oh , yes , to sit in the inn playing at cards with a crowd of Philistines or to be stilted with his honour , the prefect of the county ! God forbid ! I have enough of that nonsense ! It could n't tempt me out of the house ! If it were n't for the bit of hunting a man could do — if one could n't shoulder one 's gun occasionally , one would be tempted to run away to sea .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , you see ! There you are ! That 's what I say ! You 've just changed entirely ! Till two , three months ago , you was as merry as the day 's long ; you shot birds an ’ stuffed them , increased your botanical collection , hunted birds ’ eggs — and sang the livelong day ! ‘ Twas a joy to see you ! An ’ now , suddenly , you 're like another person .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: If only we had been able to keep Kurt !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: How would it be if we adopted a child ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: All of a sudden ? No , mother . I do n't care about it now . Before , you could n't make up your mind to it ; now I 've passed that stage too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: ‘ Tis easily said : Take a child into the house ! First of all it seemed to me like betraying Kurt ... yes , like a regular betrayal ... that 's what the very thought of It seemed to me . I felt — how shall I say it ?— as if we were putting the child away from us utterly — out of the house , out of his little room an ’ his little bed , an ’ , last of all , out of our hearts .— But the main thing was this : Where can you get a child in whom you can hope to have some joy ?— But let that rest where it is . Let 's go back to Rose once more !— Do you know how it is with her , Christopher ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Oh , well ! Of course ; why not ? Streckmann has cast a slur upon her conduct and old Bernd wo n't suffer that ! ‘ Tis folly , to be sure , to bring suit in such a matter .— Because it is the woman who has to bear the brunt of it in the end .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I wrote a couple of letters to Rose and asked the lass to come here . In her situation , Christopher , she may really not know what to do nor where to turn .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Why do you think so ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Because Streckmann is right !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Taken aback and with a show of stupidity .What , mother ? You must express yourself more clearly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Now , Christie , do n't let your temper get the better of you again ! I 've kept the truth from you till now because I know you 're a bit harsh in such matters . You remember the little maid that you put straight out o ’ the house , and the trunk-maker to whom you gave a beating ! Now this lass o ’ ours made a confession to me long ago — maybe eight weeks . An ’ we have to consider that ‘ tis not only Rose that 's to be considered now , but ... a second being ... the one that 's on the way . Did you understand me ? Did you ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: With self-repression .No ! Not entirely , mother , I must say frankly . I 've got a kind of a ... just to-day ... it comes over me ... the blood , you know ... it seems to go to my head suddenly , once in a while . It 's like a ... it 's horrible , too ... like an attack of dizziness ! I suppose I 'll have to ... at least , I think I 'll have to take the air a bit . But it 's nothing of importance , mother . So do n't worry .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Looking at him through her spectacles .And where do you want to go with your cartridge belt ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Nowhere ! What did I want to do with the cartridge belt ?He hurls the belt aside which he has involuntarily picked up .One learns nothing ... is kept in the dark about everything ! And then a point comes where one suddenly feels blind and stupid ... and a stranger ... an utter stranger in this world .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Suspiciously .Will you tell me , Christie , the meanin ’ of all this ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: It has n't any , mother — not the slightest ... none at all , in fact . And I 'm quite clear in my head again , too — quite ! Only now and then a feeling comes over me , a kind of terror , all of a sudden , I do n't know how ... and I feel as if there were no solid footing under me any longer , and as if I were going to crash through and break my neck .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: ‘ Tis strange things you are saying to-day , Christie .A knocking is heard at the door .Who 's knocking there ? Come in !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Still behind the scenes .‘ Tis only me , Mrs. Flamm .

sp.speaker: FLAMM withdraws rapidly into his den

lg.l: MRS. FLAMM
Oh , ‘ tis you , Mr. Keil . Just step right in .

sp.speaker: AUGUST KEIL appears on the scene . He is paler than formerly , more
sp.p: emaciated and wears dark glasses . His left eye is hidden by a black patch .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I have come , Mrs. Flamm , to bring Rose 's excuses to you . Good-day , Mrs. Flamm .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Good-day to you , Mr. Keil .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: My betrothed had to go to the county court to-day , or she would ha ’ come herself . But she 'll be comin ’ in this evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I 'm real pleased to get a chance to see you . How are you getting on ? Sit down .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: God 's ways are mysterious ! An ’ when His hand rests heavy on us , we must n't complain . On the contrary , we must rejoice . An ’ I tell you , Mrs. Flamm , that 's almost the way I 'm feelin ’ nowadays . I 'm content . The worse things gets , the gladder I am . ‘ Tis layin ’ up more an ’ more treasures in heaven .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Taking a deep and difficult breath .I trust you are right , Mr . Keil .— Did Rose get my letters ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: She gave them to me to read . An ’ I told her , it would n't do — that she 'd have to go to see you now .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I must tell you , Keil , I 'm surprised that , after all these recent happenin 's , she never once found her way here . She knows that she 'll find sympathy here .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: She 's been reel afraid o ’ people recently . An ’ , Mrs. Flamm , if you 'll permit me to say so , you must n't take it ill. First of all she had her hands full with tendin ’ to me . I was so in need o ’ care — an ’ she did a good work by me ! An ’ then , since that man slandered her so terrible , she scarce dared go out o ’ the room .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I do n't take offence , Keil . Oh , no ! But how is she otherwise ? An ’ what does she do ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: ‘ Tis hard to say , that 's certain . To-day , for instance , when she had to go to court at eleven o'clock — ‘ twas a regular dance she led us ! She talked so strange , Mrs. Flamm , ‘ twas enough to scare a body out o ’ his wits .— First of all she did n't want to be goin ’ at all ; next she thought she wanted to take me with her . In the end she was gone like a flash an ’ cried out to me that I was n't to follow . Times she kept weepin ’ all day !— Naturally , a man has his thoughts .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: What kind o ’ thoughts ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: About several things .— Firstly , this mishap that came to me ! She spoke of it to me many a time . That 's cut her straight to the heart ! An ’ about father Bernd an ’ that he has taken that business o ’ Streckmann so serious .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: We 're all alone here , Mr. Keil . Why should n't we speak openly for once . Did it never occur to you ... I mean about this Streckmann matter ... to you or , maybe to father Bernd — that there might be some truth in it ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I do n't let myself have no thoughts about that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: That 's right ! I do n't blame you for that in the least . There are times in life when one can n't do better than stick one 's head in the sand like an ostrich . But that is n't right for a father !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Well , Mrs. Flamm , as far as old Bernd goes , his mind is as far as the sky from any suspicion that somethin ’ might n't be quite right . His conviction 's as firm as a rock . He 'd let you chop off his hands for it . Nobody would n't believe how strictly he thinks about things o ’ that kind . His honour was there too an ’ tried to persuade him to withdraw his charge ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Excitedly .Who was there ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: His honour , Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: My husband ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes ! He talked to him a long time . You see , as for me — I 've lost an eye , to be sure — but I do n't care to have Streckmann punished . Vengeance is mine , saith the Lord . But father — he can n't be persuaded to think peaceably about this matter . Ask anythin ’ o ’ me , says he , but not that !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You say my husband went to see old Bernd ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes , that time he got the summons .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: What kind o ’ summons was that ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: To appear before the examining magistrate .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: With growing excitement .Who ? Old Bernd ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: No ; Mr. Flamm .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Was my husband examined too ? What did he have to do with the affair ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Yes , he was examined too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Deeply affected .Is that so ? That 's news to me ! I did n't know about that . Nor that Christie went to see old Bernd !... I wonder where my smellin ’ bottle is ?— No , August , you might as well go home now . I 'm a bit ... I do n't know what to call it ! An ’ any special advice I can n't give you , the way it all turns out . There 's something that 's gone through an ’ through me . Go home an ’ wait to see how everything goes . But if you love the lass truly , then ... look at me : I could tell you a tale ! If a body is made that way : whether ‘ tis a man that the women run after , or a woman that all the men are mad about — then there 's nothin ’ to do but just to suffer an ’ suffer and be patient !— I 've lived that way twelve long years .She pats her hand to her eyes and peers through her fingers .An ’ if I want to see things at all , I have to see them from behind my hands .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I can n't never believe that , Mrs. Flamm .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Whether you believe me or not . Life do n't ask us if we want to believe things . An ’ I feel exactly like you : I can n't hardly realise it either . But we have to see how we can reconcile ourselves to it — I made a promise to Rose ! ‘ Tis easy promisin ’ an ’ hard keepin ’ the promise sometimes in this world . But I 'll do the best in my power .— Good-bye — I can n't expect you to ... God must take pity on us . That 's all .

sp.speaker: AUGUST , deeply moved , grasps the hand which MRS. FLAMM offers him
sp.p: and withdraws in silence .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM leans her head far back and , lost in thought , looks up
sp.p: She sighs twice deeply and with difficulty . FLAMM enters , very pale , looks sidewise at his wife and begins to whistle softly . He opens the book case and pretends to be eagerly hunting for something .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Yes , yes ; there it is — you whistle everything down the wind ! But this ... this ... I would n't ha ’ thought you capable of .

sp.speaker: FLAMM swings around , falls silent , and looks straight at her . He
sp.p: lifts both hands slightly and shrugs his shoulders very high . Then , he relaxes all his muscles and gazes simply and without embarrassment — thoughtfully rather than shamefacedly — at the floor .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You men take these things very lightly ! What 's to happen now ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Repeating the same gesture but less pronouncedly .That 's what I do n't know .— I want to be quite calm now . I should like to tell you how that came about . It may be that you will be able to judge me less harshly then . If not ... why , then I should be very sorry for myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I do n't see how a body can fail to judge such recklessness harshly .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Recklessness ? I do n't think that it was mere recklessness . What would you rather have it be , mother — recklessness , or something more serious ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: To destroy the future of just this girl , for whom we have to bear all the responsibility ! We made her come to the house ! An ’ she an ’ her people had blind confidence in us ! ‘ Tis enough to make one perish o ’ shame ! It looks as if one had ... that ... in view !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Are you done , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Far from it !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Well , then I 'll have to wait a bit longer .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Christie , what did I tell you that day when you out with it an ’ said you wanted to marry me ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What was it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I 'm much too old for you . A woman can be sixteen years younger than her husband , but not three or four years older . I wish you had listened to me then !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Is n't it real idle to dish up those old stories now ? Have n't we something more important to do ?— I may be wrong , but it seems to me that we have , mother .— I 've had no notion until to-day of what Rose means to me . Otherwise I 'd have acted very differently , of course . Now it 's got to be seen if there 's anything that can be retrieved . And for that very reason , mother , I was going to beg you not to be petty , and I wanted first of all to try to see whether you could gain some comprehension of what really happened . Up to the moment when it was agreed that that tottery manikin was to marry Rose — our relations were strictly honourable . But when that marriage was determined on — it was all over .— It may be that my ideas are becoming confused . I had seen the girl grow up ... some of our love for little Kurt clung to her . First of all I wanted to protect her from misfortune , and finally , one day , all of a sudden , the way such things happen ... even old Plato has described that correctly in the passage in Phaedrus about the two horses :— the bad horse ran away with me and then ... then the sea burst in and the dykes crashed down .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: ‘ Tis a real interesting story that you 've told me , an ’ even tricked out with learned allusions . An ’ when you men do that — you think there 's no more to say . A poor woman can look out then to see how to get even ! Maybe you did it all just to make Rose happy , an ’ sacrificed yourself into the bargain ... There 's no excuse for such things !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Very well , mother . Then we 'll adjourn the session . Remember though , that when Kurt died , I could n't bear to see the girl around the house . Who kept her and persuaded her to come back ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Because I did n't want life to become so dead around us . I did n't keep her for my sake .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And I have said nothing for your sake .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Every tear is wasted that one might shed for you an ’ your kind . But you can spare me your speeches , Flamm . The MAID brings in the afternoon coffee .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Rose Bernd 's out in the kitchen .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Come , girl ! Wheel me out !To FLAMM .You can help shove me aside . Somewhere in the world there 'll be a little room for me ! I wo n't be in the way . You can call her in when I 'm gone .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Sternly , to the MAID .Tell the girl to wait for a moment .The MAID leaves the room .Mother , you have to say a word to her ! I can n't .... My hands are tied .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: An ’ what am I to say to her , Flamm ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Mother , you know that better than I ! You know very well ... you spoke of it yourself .... For heaven 's sake , do n't be petty at this moment ! She must n't go from our door in any such fashion !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I can n't clean her boots , Flamm !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And I do n't want you to ! It is n't a question of that ! But you sent for her yourself .— You can n't change so completely in a moment as to forget all compassion and sympathy . What did you say to me a while ago ? And if the lass goes to the devil ... you know I 'm not such a scoundrel that I 'd care to drag out my life any longer . It 's one thing or the other — do n't forget that !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , Christie ... you men are not worth it , to be sure . An ’ yet , in the end , what is a body to do ?— The heart bleeds ! ‘ Tis our own fault . Why does a woman deceive herself again an ’ again , when she 's old enough an ’ sensible enough to know better ! An ’ do n't deceive yourself about this thing either , Christie .... I 'm willin ’ ! I can do it ! I 'll talk to her ! Not for your sake , but because it 's right . But do n't imagine that I can make whole what you 've broken .— You men are like children in that respect ! The MAID comes back .

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: She do n't want to wait no more !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Send her in ! The MAID withdraws again .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Be sensible , mother ! On my word of honour ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: You need n't give it ! You need n't break it !

sp.speaker: FLAMM leaves the room . MRS. FLAMM sighs and picks up her crochet
sp.p: work again . Thereupon ROSE BERND enters .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Showily dressed in her Sunday clothes . Her features are peaked and there is a feverish gleam in her eyes .Good-day , madam .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Good-day ! Sit down . Well , Rose , I 've asked you to come here ... I suppose you 've kept in mind what we talked about that time . There 's many a thing that 's changed since then !... In many respects , anyhow ! But that made me want to talk to you all the more . That day , to be sure , you said I could n't help you , that you wanted to fight it all out alone ! An ’ to-day a good bit has grown clear to me — your strange behaviour that time , an ’ your unwillingness to let me help you .— But I do n't see how you 're goin ’ to get along all alone . Come , drink a cup o ’ coffee .ROSE sits down on the edge of a chair by the table .August was here to see me a while ago . If I had been in your shoes , lass , I 'd have risked it long ago an ’ told him the truth .Looking sharply at her .But now , the way things has gone — I can n't even advise you to do it ! Is n't that true ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , but why , madam ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: ‘ Tis true , the older a person gets , the less can she understand mankind an ’ their ways . We 've all come into the world the same way , but there 's no mention to be made o ’ that ! From the Emperor an ’ the archbishop down to the stable boy — they 've all gotten their bit o ’ life one way ... one way ... an ’ ‘ tis the one thing they can n't besmirch enough . An ’ if the stork but flies past the chimney-top — the confusion of people is great . Then they run away in every direction . A guest like that is never welcome !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , madam , all that would ha ’ been straightened up this long time , if it had n't ha ’ been for this criminal an ’ scoundrel here ... this liar ... this Streckmann ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: No , girl . I do n't understand that . How can you bear to say that the man lies ? ‘ Tis your shape that almost tells the story now !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: He lies ! He lies ! That 's all I know .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: But in what respect does he lie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: In every respeck an ’ in every way !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: I do n't believe you 've really thought it all out ! Do you remember who I am ? Think , lass , think ! In the first place you confessed it all to me , and furthermore , I know more than what you said : I know all that you did n't say .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Shivering with nervousness but obdurate .An ’ if you was to kill me , I could n't say what I do n't know .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Is that so ? Oh ! Is that your policy now ? I must say I did n't take you for a girl of that kind ! It comes over me unexpectedly ! I hope you talked a little plainer than that when you were questioned in court .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I said just the same thing there that I 'm tellin ’ you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Girl , come to your senses ! You 're talking dreadful folly ! People do n't lie that way before the Judge ! Listen to what I 'm tellin ’ you ! Drink a bit o ’ coffee , an ’ do n't be frightened ! Nobody 's pursuing you , an ’ I wo n't eat you up either !— You have n't acted very well toward me : no one could say that you had ! You might at least have told me the truth that day ; maybe an easier way out could ha ’ been found . ‘ Tis a hard matter now ! An ’ yet , we wo n't be idle , an ’ even to-day , maybe , some way o ’ savin ’ you can be found ! Some way it may be possible yet ! Well then !... An ’ especially ... this much is certain ... an ’ you can trust to that surely ... you sha n't , either of you , ever suffer any need in this world ! Even if your father abandons you and August , maybe , goes his own way , I 'll provide for you an ’ for your child .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I do n't hardly know what you mean , madam !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Well , girl , then I 'll tell you straight out ! If you do n't know that an ’ have forgotten it , then it 's simply because you have a bad conscience ! Then you 've been guilty of something else ! An ’ , if you has another secret , it 's connected with nobody but with Streckmann . Then , he 's the fellow that 's bringin ’ trouble upon you !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Violently .No , how can you think such a thing o ’ me ! You say that ... oh , for the good Lord 's sake ... how has I deserved it o ’ you !... If only my little Kurt ... my dear little fellow ...

div.stage: She wrings her hands hysterically in front of the child 's picture .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Rose , let that be , I beg o ’ you ! It may be that you 've deserved well o ’ me in other days . We 're not arguin ’ about that now ! But you 're so changed , so ... I can never understand how you 've come to change so !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Why did n't my little mother take me to herself ! She said she would when she died .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Come to your senses , lass . You 're alive . What is your trouble ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: It has nothin ’ to do with Streckmann ! That man has lied his soul black .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: What did he lie about ? Did he make his statements under oath ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oath or no oath ! I says he lies , lies ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: An ’ did you have to take an oath too ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I do n't know .— I 'm not such a wicked lass ... If that was true ,' twould be a bitter crime !... An ’ that August lost his eye ... it was n't I that was the cause o ’ it . The pains that poor man had to suffer ... they follows me day an ’ night . An ’ he might well despise me if they did n't . But you try an ’ work an ’ pray to save somethin ’ from the flames o ’ the world ... an ’ men comes an ’ they breaks your strength .

sp.speaker: FLAMM enters in intense excitement
sp.p: FLAMM Who is breaking your strength ? Look at mother here ! On the contrary , we want to save you !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: ‘ Tis too late now ! It can n't be done no more .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Nothin ’ !— I can n't wait no longer . Good-bye , I 'll go my ways .

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Here you stay ! Do n't move from this spot ! I was at the door and heard everything , and now I want to know the whole truth .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: But I 'm tellin ’ you the truth !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: About Streckmann too ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: There was n't nothin ’ between us . He lies !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Does he say that there was something between you ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I say nothin ’ but that he lies !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Did he swear to that lie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE is silent
sp.p: FLAMM

div.stage: Regards ROSE long and searchingly . Then :] Well , mother , think as charitably of me as you can . Try to forgive me as much as possible . I know with the utmost certainty that that matter does n't concern me in the least any longer ! I simply laugh at it ! I snap my fingers at it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: To ROSE .Did you deny everything ?

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: I spoke the truth in court , of course . Streckmann does n't lie at such times neither . Perjury is a penitentiary crime — a man does n't lie under such circumstances !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: An ’ did n't you tell the truth , girl ? You lied when you were under oath , maybe ?— Have n't you any idea what that means an ’ what you 've done ? How did you happen to do that ? How could you think o ’ such a thing ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Cries out brokenly .I was so ashamed !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: But Rose ...

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Every word is wasted ! Why did you lie to the judge ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I was ashamed , I tell ye !... I was ashamed !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: And I ? And mother ? And August ? Why did you cheat us all ? And you probably cheated Streckmann in the end too ? And I wonder with whom else you carried on !... Yes , oh , yes ; you have a very honest face . But you did right to be ashamed !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: He baited me an ’ he hunted me down like a dog !

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Laughing .Oh , well , that 's what you women make of us — dogs . This man to-day ; that man to-morrow ! ‘ Tis bitter enough to think ! You can do what you please now ; follow what ways you want to !— If I so much as raise a finger in this affair again , it 'll be to take a rope and beat it about my ass 's ears until I can n't see out of my eyes !

sp.speaker: ROSE stares at FLAMM in wide-eyed horror
sp.p: MRS. FLAMM What I said , Rose , stands for all that ! You two 'll always be provided for .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Whispering mechanically .I was so ashamed ! I was so ashamed !

sp.speaker: MRS. FLAMM
sp.p: Do you hear what I say , Rose ?—ROSE hurries out .The girl 's gone !— ‘ Tis enough to make one pray for an angel to come down ....

sp.speaker: FLAMM
sp.p: Stricken to the heart , breaks out in repressed sobbing .God forgive me , mother , but ... I can n't help it .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: FIFTH ACT The living room in old BERND 'S cottage . The room is fairly large ; it has grey walls and an old-fashioned whitewashed ceiling supported by visible beams . A door in the background leads to the kitchen , one at the left to the outer hall . To the right are two small windows . A yellow chest of drawers stands between the two windows ; upon it is set an unlit kerosene lamp ; a mirror hangs above it on the wall . In the left corner a great stove ; in the right a sofa , covered with oil-cloth , a table with a cloth on it and a hanging lamp above it . Over the sofa on the wall hangs a picture with the Biblical subject : “ Suffer little children to come unto me ” ; beneath it a photograph of BERND , showing him as a conscript , and several of himself and his wife . In the foreground , to the left , stands a china closet , filled with painted cups , glasses , etc . A Bible is lying on the chest of drawers ; over the door to the hall hangs a chromolithograph of “ Christ with the crown of thorns . ” Mull curtains hang in front of the windows . Each of four or five chairs of yellow wood has its own place . The whole room makes a neat but very chilly impression . Several Bibles and hymnals lie on the china closet . On the door-post of the door to the hall hangs a collecting-box . It is seven o'clock in the evening of the same day on which the events in Act Four have taken place . The door that leads to the hall as well as the kitchen door stands open . A gloomy dusk fills the house . Voices are heard outside , and a repeated knocking at the window . Thereupon a voice speaks through the window .

sp.speaker: THE VOICE
sp.p: Bernd ! Is n't there a soul at home ? Let 's be goin ’ to the back door ! A silence ensues . Soon , however , the back door opens and voices and steps are heard in the hall . In the door that leads to the hall appear KLEINERT and ROSE BERND . The latter is obviously exhausted and leans upon him .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Weak and faint .No one 's at home . ‘ Tis all dark .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: I can n't be leavin ’ you alone this way now !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ why not , Kleinert ? There 's nothin ’ the matter with me !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Somebody else can believe that — that there 's nothin ’ wrong ! I would n't ha ’ had to pick you up in that case !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Eh , but I 'd only gotten a bit dizzy . Truly ... ‘ tis better now . I really do n't need you no more .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: No , no , lass ; I can n't leave you this way !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , yes , father Kleinert ! I do thank you , but ‘ tis well ! There 's nothin ’ wrong with me ! I 'm on my feet an ’ strong again ! It comes over me that way sometimes ; but ‘ tis nothin ’ to worry over .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: But you lay half dead yonder behind the willow ! An ’ you writhed like a worm .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Kleinert , go your ways .... I 'll be lightin ’ a light ! An ’ I must light a fire , too ... go your ways ... the folks will be comin ’ to their supper !... Oh , no , Kleinert , Kleinert ! But I 'm that tired ! Oh , I 'm so terrible tired ! No one would n't believe how tired I am .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: An ’ then you want to be lightin ’ a fire here ? That 's nothin ’ for you ! Bed is the place where you ought to be !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Kleinert , go your ways , go ! If father , an ’ if August ... they must n't know nothin ’ ! For my sake , go ! Do n't do nothin ’ that 'll only harm me !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: I do n't want to do nothin ’ that 'll harm you !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: No , no , I know it ! You was always good to me !She has arisen from the chair at the right on which , she had sunk down , gets a candle from behind the oven and lights it .Oh , yes , yes , I 'm well off again .— There 's nothin ’ wrong .— You can be easy in your mind .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: You 're just sayin ’ that !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Because ‘ tis really so !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL comes in from the fields with bare arms and feet

lg.l: ROSE
An ’ there 's Marthel , too !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Rose , is that you ? Where have you been all day ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I dreamed I was at the court .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: No , no ; she was really at the court ! Take a bit o ’ care o ’ your sister , Marthel . Look after her at least till your fatter comes back . ‘ Tis n't well with the girl .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Marthel , hurry ! Light the fire , so 's we can start to put on the potatoes .— Where 's father ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: On August 's land .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ August ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: I do n't know where he is . He was out on the field to-day .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Have you got new potatoes ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: I have an apron full !

div.stage: Immediately behind the kitchen door she pours out the potatoes on the floor .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Fetch me a pan and a saucepan , so 's I can begin the peelin ’ . I can n't get nothin ’ for myself .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: D'you want me to be givin ’ a message anywhere ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: To whom ? To the grave-digger , maybe ?... No , no , godfather , not on my account . ‘ Tis a special bit o ’ ground where I 'll find rest .

sp.speaker: KLEINERT
sp.p: Well , good-bye !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Good-bye to you !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Cheerily .Come again , godfather !

sp.speaker: KLEINERT as usual with his pipe in his mouth , departs shaking his
sp.p: head .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Lighting the fire .Do n't you feel well , Rosie ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Oh , yes ; well enough !Softly wringing her hands , she speaks to the crucifix .Jesus , Mary , have mercy on me !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Rose !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: What 's the matter with you ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Nothin ’ . Bring me a pan an ’ the potatoes .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Has started the fire to burning and now brings ROSE an earthenware bowl of potatoes and a paring knife .Oh , but Rosie , I 'm that frightened ! You look so ...!

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: How does I look ? Tell me that ? How ? Has I got spots on my hands ? Is it branded over my eyes ? Everythin 's kind o ’ ghastly to me this day .Laughing a ghastly laugh .Lord ! I can n't see the face o ’ you ! Now I see one hand ! Now I see two eyes ! Just dots now ! Martha , maybe I 'm growin ’ blind !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Rosie , did somethin ’ happen to you ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: God protect you from what 's happened to me .... You 'd better be wishin ’ yourself an early death ! Because , even if a body dies to this world , they do say that he passes into rest . Then you do n't have to live an ’ draw breath no more .— How did it go with little Kurt Flamm ? I 've clean forgot ... I 'm dizzy ... I 'm forgettin ’ ... I 've forgotten everythin ’ ... life 's that hard ... If I could only keep on feelin ’ this way ... an ’ never wake up again ...! What 's the reason o ’ such things comin ’ to pass in this world ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Frightened .If only father would come home !

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Martha , come ! Listen to me ! You must n't tell father that I was here or that I am here ... Martha , sure you 'll promise me that , wo n't you ?... Many a thing I 've done for the love o ’ you ... Martha ! You have n't forgotten that , nor you must n't forget it , even if things grows dark around me now .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Will you drink a bit of coffee ? There 's a drop left in the oven .

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: An ’ do n't be frightened ! I 'll go upstairs in the room an ’ lie down a wee bit ... just a bit . Otherwise I 'm all right ... otherwise there 's nothin ’ that ails me .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: An ’ I 'm not to say nothin ’ to father ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Not a word !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: An ’ not to August neither ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: Not a syllable ! Lass , you 've never known your mother an ’ I 've raised you with fear an ’ heartache .— Many 's the night I 've watched through in terror because you was ill ! I was n't as old as you when I carried you about on my arm till I was near breakin ’ in two ! Here you was — at my breast ! An ’ if you go an ’ betray me now , ‘ tis all over between us !

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Rosie , ‘ tis nothin ’ bad is it ... nothin ’ dangerous , I mean ?

sp.speaker: ROSE
sp.p: I do n't believe it is ! Come , Martha , help me a bit , support me a bit !... A body is left too lonely in this world ... too deserted ! If only a body was n't so lonely here ... so lonely on this earth !ROSE and MARTHEL pass out through the hall door .For some moments the room remains empty . Then old BERND appears in the kitchen . He puts down his basket and the potato hoe and looks about him , earnestly and inquiringly . Meanwhile MARTHEL re-enters the living-room from the hall .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Is it you , father ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Is there no hot water ! You know I have to have my foot bath ! Is n't Rose here yet ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: She is n't here yet , father !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: What ? Has n't she come back from court yet ? That is n't possible hardly ! ‘ Tis eight o'clock . Was August here ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Not yet .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Not yet either ? Well , maybe she 's with him then .— Have you seen that great cloud , Marthel , that was comin ’ over from the mountain about six o'clock , maybe ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: Yes , father ; the world got all dark !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: There 'll come a day o ’ greater darkness than this ! Light the lamp on the table for me an ’ put the Good Book down next to it . The great thing is to be in readiness . Marthel , are you sure you keep thinkin ’ o ’ the life eternal , so that you can stand up before your Judge on that day ? Few is the souls that think of it here ! Just now as I was comin ’ home along the water 's edge , I heard some one cryin ’ out upon me from behind , as they often does . “ Bloodsucker ! ” cried he . An ’ was I a bloodsucker when I was overseer on the domain ? Nay , I did my duty ,— that was all ! But the powers of evil is strong ! If a man is underhanded , an ’ closes his eyes to evil , an ’ looks on quietly upon cheatin ’ — then his fellows likes him well .— But I leans upon the Lord Jesus . We human bein 's all need that support . ‘ Tis n't enough just to do good works ! Maybe if Rose had given more thought to that , maybe we 'd ha ’ been spared many a visitation an ’ a deal o ’ heaviness an ’ bitterness .A CONSTABLE appears in the doorway .Who 's comin ’ there ?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: I have a summons to serve , I must speak to your daughter .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: My oldest daughter ?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Reads from the document .To Rose Bernd .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: My daughter has n't come back from court yet . Can I give her the letter ?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: No ; I 've got to make a personal search , too . I 'll be back at eight in the mornin ’ .

lg.l: BERND
There 's August , too .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Is n't Rose here ?

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: No ; an ’ the sergeant here is askin ’ after her , too . I thought you an ’ she was together .

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: I has to make a search into one matter an ’ also to serve this paper .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Always an ’ forever this Streckmann business . ‘ Tis not only the loss of my eye — now we has these everlastin ’ troubles an ’ annoyances . It seems , God forgive me , to come to no end .

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE
sp.p: Good evenin ’ . To-morrow mornin ’ at eight !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Marthel , go into the kitchen a bit of a while .— Father , I 've got to speak with you . Go , Marthel ; go an ’ shut the door . But Marthel , did n't you see anythin ’ o ’ Rose ?

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: No , nothin ’ !Surreptitiously she beckons to him with her hand .I 'll tell you something August .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Close the door , lass . I have no time now .He himself closes the kitchen door .Father , you 'll have to withdraw your suit .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Anythin ’ but that , August . I can n't do that !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: ‘ Tis not Christian . Yon must withdraw .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I do n't believe that ‘ tis not Christian !— For why ? ‘ Tis a piece of infamy to cut off a girl 's honour that way . ‘ Tis a crime that needs to be punished .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I hardly know how to begin , father Bernd .... You 've been too hasty in this matter ....

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: My wife who 's in her grave demands that of me ! An ’ my honour demands it ... the honour o ’ my house and o ’ my lass . An ’ yours , too , if you come to think .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Father Bernd , father Bernd , how am I to speak to you if you 're so set on not makin ’ peace ? You 've spoke o ’ so many kinds of honour . But we 're not to seek our honour or glory in this world , but God 's only an ’ no other !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: ‘ Tis otherwise in this matter . Here woman 's honour is God 's too ! Or have you any complaint to make against Rose ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I 've said to you : I make no complaint !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Or is your own conscience troublin ’ you on her account ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: You know me in that respeck , father Bernd . Before I 'd depart from the straight an ’ narrow way ...

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Well , then . I know that ! I always knew that ! An ’ so justice can take its course .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Wiping the sweat from his forehead .If only we knew where Rose is !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Maybe she is n't back from the court at Striegau yet !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: An examination like that do n't take very long . She meant to be home by five o'clock .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Maybe she went to buy some things on the way . Was n't she to get several things yet ? I thought you were wantin ’ one thing or another .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: But she did n't take along any money . An ’ the things we was needin ’ for the shop — curtains for the windows an ’ the door — we intended to buy those together .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I was thinkin ’ that she 'd come with you !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I went to meet her on the road — more'n a mile , but I heard an ’ saw nothin ’ of her . Instead o ’ that , I met Streckmann .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I calls that meetin ’ the devil !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Ah , father , that man has a wife an ’ children too ! His sins are no fault o ’ theirs ! What good does it do me that he 's got to go to gaol ? If a man repents ... that 's all I asks !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: That bad man do n't know repentance !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: It looked very much as if he did .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Did you speak to him ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: He gave me no peace . He ran along next to me an ’ talked an ’ talked . There was n't a soul to be seen far an ’ wide ! In the end I felt sorry for him ; I could n't help it .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You answered him ! What did he say ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: He said you should withdraw your suit .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: I could n't rest quiet in my grave if I did ! ‘ Twould n't matter if it concerned me ! I can bear it ; I can laugh at it ! I 'm not only a man but a Christian ! But ‘ tis a different thing with my child ! How could I look you in the face if I let that shameful thing stick to her ! An ’ now , especially , after that terrible misfortune ! Look , August , that can n't be ! That must n't be !— Everybody 's always been at our heels , because we lived different from the rest o ’ the world ! Hypocrites they called us an ’ bigots , an ’ sneaks an ’ such names ! An ’ always they wanted to trump up somethin ’ against us ! What a feast this here thing would be to ‘ em ! An ’ besides ... How did I bring up the lass ? Industrious an ’ with the fear o ’ God in her heart so that if a Christian man marries her , he can set up a Christian household ! That 's the way ! That 's how I gives her out o ’ my care ! An ’ am I goin ’ to let that poison cling to her ? Rather would I be eatin ’ bread an ’ salt all my days than take a penny from you then !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Father Bernd , God 's ways is mysterious ! He can send us new trials daily ! No man has a right to be self-righteous ! An ’ even if I wanted to be , I could n't ! I can n't spare you the knowledge no longer , father . Our Rose has been but a weak human bein ’ like others .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: How do you mean that , August ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Father , do n't ask me no more ,

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Has sat down on a chair by the table in such a way that his face is turned to the wall . At AUGUST 'S last words he has looked at him with eyes , wide-open and estranged . Then he turns to the table , opens the Bible with trembling hands , and turns its leaves hither and thither in growing excitement . He ceases and looks at AUGUST again . Finally he folds his hands over the book and lets his head sink upon them while his body twitches convulsively . In this posture he remains for a while , Then he straightens himself up .No . I do n't understand you rightly ! Because , you see , if I did understand you rightly ... that 'd be really ... an ’ I would n't know ... my God , the room swims with me ... why , I 'd have to be deaf an ’ blind !— Nay , August , an ’ I 'm not deaf an ’ blind ! Do n't let Streckmann impose on you ! He 'll take any means to get out o ’ the trap that he 's in now . It 's comin ’ home to him , an ’ he wants to sneak out at any cost ! An ’ so he 's incitin ’ you against the lass . No , August , ... truly , August ... not on that bridge ... you must n't start for to cross that bridge !... Anybody can see through his villainy ! ... He 's laid traps enough for the lass . An ’ if one way do n't succeed , he 'll try another !... Now he 's hit on this here plan .— Maybe he 'll separate you two ! It 's happened in this world , more than once or twice that some devil with his evil schemes has tore asunder people that God meant for each other . They always grudged the girl her good fortune . Good : I 'm willin ’ ! I wo n't throw Rose after you ! We 've satisfied our hunger up to now ! But if you 'll heed my word : I 'll put my right hand in the fire for ....

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: But Mr. Flamm took oath .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Ten oaths against me ... twenty oaths against me !... Then he has sworn falsely an ’ damned hisself in this world an ’ in the world to come !

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Father Bernd ....

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Now wait a bit before ever you say another word ! Here I take the books ! Here I take my hat ! Here I take the collecting box o ’ the missions . An ’ all these things I puts together here . An ’ if that 's true what you 've been sayin ’ — if there 's so much in it as a grain o ’ truth — then I 'll go this minute to the pastor an ’ I 'll say : Your reverence , this is how things is : I can n't be a deacon no more ; I can n't take care o ’ the treasury for missions no more ! Good-bye ! And then nobody would see me no more ! No , no , no , for the love o ’ God ! But now go on ! Say your say ! But do n't torture me for nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I had the same thought , too . I want to sell my house an ’ my land ! Maybe one could find contentment somewhere else .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: In unspeakable astonishment .You want to sell your house an ’ your land , August ? How do all these strange things come about all of a sudden ! It 's enough ... A body might be tempted to make the sign o ’ the cross , even though we 're not Catholics .— Has the whole world gone mad ? Or is the Day o ’ Judgment at hand ? Or maybe , ‘ tis but my last hour that has come . Now answer me , August , how is it ? As you hope for a life to come , how is it ?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: However it is , father Bernd , I wo n't desert her .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: You can do about that as you please . That do n't concern me ! I do n't want to know if a man 'd like a wench o ’ that kind in his house or not . Not me ! I 'm not that kind of a man . Well now ...?

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I can n't say nothin ’ more than this — somethin ’ must ha ’ happened to her ! Whether ‘ twas with Flamm or with Streckmann ....

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: That makes two of ‘ em ...!

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: I can n't tell exactly ...!

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Well , then I 'll be goin ’ to the pastor ! Brush me off , August , clean me a bit ! I feel as if I had the itch on my body !He steps into the hall .At the same moment MARTHEL rushes out of the kitchen and speaks to AUGUST in intense terror .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: I believe a misfortune has happened to Rose ! She 's upstairs ! She 's been home this long time !

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: Returns , changed somewhat by a fright which he has felt .Somebody must be upstairs .

sp.speaker: AUGUST
sp.p: Marthel is just sayin ’ that Rose is there .

sp.speaker: MARTHEL
sp.p: I hear her . She 's comin ’ down the stairs .

sp.speaker: BERND
sp.p: God forgive me the sin ! I do n't want to see her . He sits down at the table , as before , holds his thumbs over his ears and bends his head deep over the Bible . ROSE appears in the door . She has her house skirt on and a loose bodice of cotton cloth . She keeps herself erect by sheer force of will . Her hair hangs down , partly loose , partly braided . There is in her face an expression of terrible , fatalistic calm and of bitter defiance .
