sp.p: Is that so ? Well , Mrs. Knobbe an ’ child stealin ’ — them two things do n't go together . Now if it 'd been mother , that would ha ’ been more likely . But not that Knobbe woman ! But tell me , Emil , what 's all this here business about ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Well , one person says one thing an ’ another says another . The Knobbe woman says that certain people has started a plot with detectives an ’ such like to get hold o ’ the brat . An ’ there ai n't no doubt o ’ this . It 's proved that the child was hers . C'n you maybe give me a tip as to where your brother-in-law 's been keepin ’ hisself the past few days ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You mean the butcher in Hangelsberg ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Naw , I don ’ mean the husband o ’ your sister , but the feller what 's brother o ’ your wife .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: It 's Bruno you mean ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Sure , that 's the feller .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How do I know ? I 'd sooner be watchin ’ if the dogs still plays on the curb . I do n't want to have no dealin 's with Bruno .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Listen to me , Paul . But do n't get mad . They knows at the police station that Bruno was seen in company o ’ the Polish girl what wanted to claim this here child , first right outside o ’ the door here an ’ then at a certain place on Shore street where the tanners sometimes looses their soakin ’ hides . An ’ now the girl 's jus ’ disappeared . I don ’ know nothin ’ o ’ the particulars , excep ’ that the police is huntin ’ for the girl .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Resolutely putting aside the long pipe which he had lit .I don ’ know , but I can n't take no enjoyment in it this mornin ’ . I don ’ know what 's gotten into me . I was as jolly as can be . An ’ now all of a sudden I feel so dam ’ mean I 'd like to go straight back to Hamburg an ’ hear an ’ see nothin ’ more !— Why d'you come aroun ’ with stories like that ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: I jus ’ thought I 'd tell you what happened while you an ’ your wife was away right here in your own house ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In my own house ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: That 's it ! Yessir ! They says that Selma pushed the perambulator with her little brother in here where the strange girl an ’ her friend came an ’ took him an ’ carried him off . But upstairs , in the actor 's place , they caught her .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: So up there the strange girl an ’ the Knobbe woman pretty near tore each other 's hair out over the child 's body .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What I 'd like to know is how all that concerns me ? Ai n't there trouble here over some girl most o ’ the time ? Let ‘ em go on ! I don ’ care ! That is to say , Emil , if there ai n't more to it than you 're tellin ’ me .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: That 's why I come to you ! There is more . The girl said in front o ’ witnesses more'n onct that that little crittur o ’ Knobbe 's was her own an ’ that she had expressly given it in board to your wife .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: First taken aback , then relieved . Laughing .She ai n't quite right in her upper story . That 's all .

lg.l: SPITTA
Good morning , Mr. John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , Mr. Spitta .To QUAQUARO , who is still loitering in the door .It 's all right , Emil . I 'll take notice o ’ what you says an ’ act accordin ’ .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO exit
sp.p: JOHN Now jus ’ look at a feller like that , Mr. Spitta . He 's more'n half a gaol bird an ’ yet he knows how to make hisself a favourite with the district commissioner at headquarters ! An ’ then he goes aroun ’ pokin ’ his nose into honest folks ’ affairs .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Has Miss Walburga Hassenreuter been asking after me , Mr. John ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not up to this time ; not that I knows of !He opens the door to the hall .Selma ! Excuse me a minute , will you ? Selma ! I gotta know what that there girl c'n tell me .

sp.speaker: SELMA KNOBBE enters
sp.p: SELMA

div.stage: Still at the door . ] What d'you want ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You shut the door a minute an ’ come in ! An ’ now tell me , girl , what 's all this that happened in this room about your little dead brother and the strange girl ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Who has , obviously , a bad conscience , gradually comes forward watchfully . She now answers glibly and volubly .I pushed the perambulator over into the room here . Your wife was n't in an ’ so I thinks that maybe here there 'd be more quiet , ‘ cause my little brother , you know , he was sick anyhow an ’ cryin ’ all the time . An ’ then , all of a sudden , a gentleman an ’ a lady an ’ another woman all comes in here , an ’ they picked the little feller right outa the carridge an ’ put clean clothes on him an ’ carried him off .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: An ’ then the lady said as how it was her child an ’ how she 'd given it in board with mother , with my old woman ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Lies .Naw , not a bit . I 'd know about that if it was so .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Bangs his fist on the table .Well , damn it all , it 'd be a idjit 's trick to have said that .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Permit me , but she did say that . I take it you 're talking of the incident with the two women that took place upstairs at manager Hassenreuter 's ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Did you see that ? Was you there when the Knobbe woman an ’ the other one was disputin ’ about the little crittur ?

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Yes , certainly . I was present throughout .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: I tell you all I knows . An ’ I could n't say no more if officer Schierke or the tall police lieutenant hisself was to examine me for hours an ’ hours . I don ’ know nothin ’ . An ’ what I don ’ know I can n't tell .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The lieutenant examined you ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: They wanted to take mama to the lock-up because people went an ’ lied . They said that our little baby was starved to death .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Aha ! ‘ s that so ? Well , Selma , s'pose you go over there an ’ cook a little coffee .

sp.speaker: SELMA goes over to the stove where she prepares coffee for JOHN
sp.p: JOHN himself goes up to his working table , takes up the compass . Then he draws lines , using a piece of rail as a ruler .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Conquering his diffidence and shame .I really hoped to meet your wife here , Mr. John . Someone told me that your wife has been in the habit of lending out small sums to students against security . And I am somewhat embarrassed .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Maybe that 's so . But that 's mother 's business , Mr. Spitta .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: To be quite frank with you , if I do n't get hold of some money by to-night , the few books and other possessions I have will be attached for rent by my landlady and I 'll be put into the street .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I thought your father was a preacher .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: So he is . But for that very reason and because I do n't want to become a preacher , too , he and I had a terrible quarrel last night . I wo n't ever accept a farthing from him any more .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Busy over his drawing .Then it 'll serve him right if you starve or break your neck .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Men like myself do n't starve , Mr. John . But if , by any chance , I were to go to the dogs — I should n't greatly care .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No one would n't believe how many half-starved nincompoops there is among you stoodents . But none o ’ you wants to put your hand to some reel work .—The distant sound of thunder is heard . JOHN looks out through the window .— Sultry day . It 's thunderin ’ now .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Yon can n't say that of me , Mr. John , that I have n't been willing to do real work . I 've given lessons , I 've addressed envelopes for business houses ! I 've been through everything and in all these attempts I 've not only toiled away the days but also the nights . And at the same time I 've ground away at my studies like anything !

lg.l: Man alive , go to Hamburg an ’ let ‘ em give you a job as a bricklayer . When
I was your age I was makin ’ as much as twelve crowns a day in Hamburg .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: That may be . But I 'm a brain worker .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I know that kind .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Is that so ? I do n't think you do know that kind , Mr. John . I beg you not to forget that your Socialist leaders — your Bebels and your Liebknechts — are brain workers too .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right . Come on , then ! Let 's have some breakfast first . Things look mighty different after a man 's had a good bite o ’ breakfast . I s'pose you ai n't had any yet , Mr. Spitta ?

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: No , frankly , not to-day .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , then the first thing is to get somethin ’ warm down your throat .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: There 's time enough for that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ know . You 're lookin ’ pretty well done up . An ’ I passed the night on the train too .To SELMA , who has brought in a little linen bag filed with rolls .Hurry an ’ bring another cup over here .He has seated himself at his ease on the sofa , dips a roll into the coffee and begins to eat and drink .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Who has not sat down yet .It 's really pleasanter to pass a summer night in the open if one can n't sleep anyhow . And I did n't sleep for one minute .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I 'd like to see the feller what c'n sleep when he 's outa cash . When a man 's down in the world he has most company outa doors too .He suddenly stops chewing .— Come here , Selma , an ’ tell me exackly just how it was with that there girl an ’ the child that she took outa our room here .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: I don ’ know what to do . Everybody axes we that . Mama keeps axin ’ me about it all day long ; if I seen Bruno Mechelke ; if I know who it was that stole the costumes from the actor 's loft up there ! If it goes on that way ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Energetically .Girl , why did n't you cry out when the gentleman and the young lady took your little brother outa his carridge ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: I did n't think nothin ’ ‘ d happen to him excep ’ that he 'd get some clean clothes .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Grasps SELMA by the wrist .Well , you come along with me now . We 'll go over an ’ see your mother .

sp.speaker: JOHN and SELMA leave the room . As soon as they are gone SPITTA
sp.p: begins to eat ravenously . Soon thereafter WALBURGA appears . She is in great haste and strongly excited .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Are you alone ?

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: For the moment , yes . Good morning , Walburga .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Am I too late ? It was only by the greatest cunning , by the greatest determination , by the most ruthless disregard of everything that I succeeded in getting away from home . My younger sister tried to bar the door . Even the servant girl ! But I told mama that if they would n't let me out through the door , they might just as well bar the window , else I 'd reach the street through it , although it 's three stories high . I flew . I 'm more dead than alive . But I am prepared for anything . How was it with your father , Erich ?

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: We have parted . He thought that I was going out to eat husks with the swine as the Prodigal Son did , and told me not to take it into my mind ever again to cross the threshold of my father 's house in my future capacity as acrobat or bareback rider , as he was pleased to express it . His door was not open to such scum ! Well , I 'll fight it down ! Only I 'm sorry for my poor , dear mother .— You can n't imagine with what abysmal hatred a man of his kind considers the theatre and everything connected with it . The heaviest curse is not strong enough to express his feelings . An actor is , to his mind , a priori , the worst , most contemptible scamp imaginable .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: I 've found out , too , how papa discovered our secret .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: My father gave him your picture .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: O Erich , if you knew with what awful , with what horrible names papa overwhelmed me in his rage . And I had to be silent through it all . I might have said something that would have silenced all his lofty moral discourses and made him quite helpless before me . I was almost on the point of saying it , too . But I felt so ashamed for him ! My tongue refused to form the words ! I could n't say it , Erich ! Finally mama had to intervene . He struck me ! For eight or nine hours he locked me in a dark alcove — to break my stubbornness , as he put it , Erich . Well , he wo n't succeed ! He wo n't break it !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Taking WALBURGA into his arms .You dear , brave girl ! I am beginning to see now what I possess in having your love , what a treasure you are !Passionately .And how beautiful you look , Walburga !

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Do n't ! Do n't !— I trust you , Erich ; that 's all .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: And you shall not be disappointed , dearest . You see , a man like me in whom everything is still in a ferment , who feels that he was born to achieve something great and significant but something which , for the present , he can make sufficiently clear neither to himself nor to the world — such a man has , at twenty , every man 's hand against his and is a burden and a laughing-stock to all the world . But believe me : it will not always be so ! The germs of the future lie in us ! The soil is being loosened even now by the budding shoots ! Unseen to-day , we are the harvest of the future ! We are the future ! And the time will come when all this great and beautiful world will be ours !

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Ah , go on , Erich ! What you say heals my heart .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Walburga , I did more , last night ! I flung straight out into my father 's face , just as I felt it , my accusation of the crime committed against my sister . And that made the break definite and unbridgeable . He said stubbornly : He had no knowledge of such a daughter as I was describing . Such a daughter had no existence in his soul , and it seemed to him that his son would also soon cease to exist there . O these Christians ! O these servants of the good shepherd who took the lost lamb with double tenderness into his arms ! O thou good Shepherd , how have your words been perverted ; How have your eternal truths been falsified into their exact contrary . But to-day when I sat amidst the flash of lightning and the roll of thunder in the Tiergarten and certain Berlin hyaenas were prowling about me , I felt the crushed and restless soul of my sister close beside me . How many nights , in her poor life , may she not have sat shelterless on such benches , perhaps on this very bench in the Tiergarten , in order to consider in her loneliness , her degradation , her outcast estate , how , two thousand years after the birth of Christ , this most Christian world is drenched with Christianity and with the love of its fellow-men ! But whatever she thought , this is what I think ; the poor harlot , the wretched sinner who is yet above the righteous , who is weighed down by the sins of the world , the poor outcast and her terrible accusation shall never die in my soul ! And into this flame of our goals we must cast all the wretchedness , all the lamentations of the oppressed and the disinherited ! Thus shall my sister stay truly alive , Walburga , and effect noble ends before the face of God through the ethical impulse that lends wings to my soul , and that will be more powerful than all the evil , heartless parson 's morality in the world .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: You were in the Tiergarten all night , Erich ? Is that the reason why your hands are so icy cold , and why you look so utterly worn out ? Erich , you must take my purse ! No , please , you must ! Oh , I assure you what is mine is yours ! If you do n't feel that , you do n't love me . Erich , you 're suffering ! If you do n't take my few pennies , I 'll refuse all nourishment at home ! By heaven , I 'll do it , I 'll do it , unless you 're sensible about that !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Chokes down his rising tears and sits down .I 'm nervous ; I 'm overwrought .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Puts her purse into his pocket .And you see , Erich , this is the real reason why I asked you to meet me here . To add to all my misfortunes I received yesterday this summons from the court .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Regards a document which she hands to him .Look here ? What 's behind this , Walburga ?

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: I 'm quite sure that it must have some connection with the stolen goods upstairs in the loft . But it does disquiet me terribly . If papa were to discover this ... oh , what would I do then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN enters , carrying the child in her arms . She is dressed for
sp.p: the street , and looks dusty and harassed .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Frightened , suspicious .Well , what d'you want here ? Is Paul home yet ? I jus ’ went down in the street a little with the baby .

div.stage: She carries the child behind the partition .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Erich , do mention the summons to Mrs. John !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Why , Paul 's at home . There 's his things !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Miss Hassenreuter wanted very much to talk to you . She received a summons to appear in court . It 's probably about those things that were stolen from the loft . You know .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Emerging from behind the partition .What 's that ? You reelly got a summons , Miss Walburga ? Well , then you better look out ! I ai n't jokin ’ . An ’ maybe you 're thinkin ’ o ’ the black man !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: What you 're saying there is quite incomprehensible , Mrs. John .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Taking up her domestic tasks .Did you hear that ‘ way out in the Lauben settlement , beyond the Halle Gate , the lightenin ’ struck a man an ’ a woman an ’ a little girl o ’ seven this mornin ’ . It was right under a tall poplar tree .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: No , Mrs. John , we did n't hear that .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: The rain 's splashin ’ down again . One hears a shower of rain beginning to fall .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Nervously .Come , Erich , let 's get out into the open anyhow .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Speaking louder and louder in her incoherent terror .An ’ I tell you another thing : I was talking to the woman what was struck by lightenin ’ jus ’ a short time before . An ’ she says — now listen to me , Mr. Spitta — if you takes a dead child what 's lyin ’ in its carridge an ’ pushes it out into the sun ... but it 's gotta be summer an ’ midday ... it 'll draw breath , it 'll cry , it 'll come back to life !— You do n't believe that , eh ? But I seen that with my own eyes !

div.stage: She circles about the room in a strange fashion , apparently becoming quite oblivious of the presence of the two young people .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Look , here , Mrs. John is positively uncanny ! Let 's go !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Speaking still louder .You don ’ believe that , that it 'll come to life again , eh ? I tell you , its mother c'n come an ’ take it . But it 's gotta be nursed right off .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Good-bye , Mrs. John .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: In strange excitement accompanies the two young people to the door . Speaking still more loudly .You don ’ believe that ! But it 's the solemn truth , Mr. Spitta !

sp.speaker: SPITTA and WALBURGA leave the room
sp.p: MRS. JOHNStill holding the door in her hand calls out after them .Anybody that don ’ believe that don ’ know nothin ’ o ’ the whole secret that I discovered . The foreman-mason JOHN appears in the door and enters at once .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why , there you are , mother ! I 'm glad to see you . What 's that there secret you 're talkin ’ about ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: As though awakening , grasps her head .Me ?— Did I say somethin ’ about a secret ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That you did unless I 'm hard o ’ hearin ’ . An ’ it 's reelly you unless it 's a ghost .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Surprised and frightened .Why d'you think I might be a ghost ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Pats his wife good-naturedly on the back .Come now , Jette , do n't bite me . I 'm reel glad , that I am , that you 're here again with the little kid !He goes behind the partition .But it 's lookin ’ a little measly .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: The milk did n't agree with him . An ’ that 's because out there in the country the cows is already gettin ’ green fodder . I got milk here from the dairy company that comes from dry fed cows .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Reappears in the main room .That 's what I 'm sayin ’ . Why did you have to go an ’ take the child on the train an ’ outa town . The city is healthier . That 's my notion .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I 'm goin ’ to stay at home now , Paul .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: In Hamburg everythin ’ is settled , too . To-day at noon I 'm goin ’ to meet Karl an ’ then he 'll tell me when I c'n start workin ’ for the new boss !— Look here : I brought somethin ’ with me , too .

div.stage: He takes a small child 's rattle from his breeches pocket and shakes it .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That 's somethin ’ to bring a bit o ’ life into the place , ‘ cause it 's pretty quiet inside in Berlin here ! Listen how the kid 's crowin ’ .The child is heard making happy little noises .I tell you , mother , when a little kid goes on that way — there ai n't nothin ’ I 'd take for it !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Have you seen anybody yet ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: No !— Leastways only Quaquaro early this mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: In timid suspense .Well ...?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Oh , never mind ! Nothin ! There was nothin ’ to it .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: As before .What did he say ? JOHN What d'you think he said ? But if you 're bound to know — ‘ tai n't no use talkin ’ o ’ such things Sunday mornin ’ — he axed me after Bruno again .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Pale and speaking hastily .What do they say Bruno has done again ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nothin ’ . Here , come'n drink a little coffee , Jette , an ’ don ’ get excited ! It ai n't your fault that you got a brother like that . We do n't has to concern ourselves about other people .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I 'd like to know what an old fool like that what spies aroun ’ all day long has always gotta be talkin ’ about Bruno .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jette , don ’ bother me about Bruno — You see ... aw , what 's the use ... might as well keep still !... But if I was goin ’ to tell you the truth , I 'd say that it would n't surprise me if some day Bruno 'd come to a pretty bad end right out in the yard o ’ the gaol , too — a quick end .MRS. JOHN sits down heavily beside the table . She grows grey in the face and breathes with difficulty .Maybe not ! Maybe not ! Do n't take it to heart so right off !— How 's the sister ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I don ’ know .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why , I thought you was out there visitin ’ her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Looks at him absently .Where was I ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , you see , Jette , that 's the way it is with you women ! You 're jus ’ shakin ’ , but oh no — you don ’ want to go to no doctor ! An ’ it 'll end maybe , by your havin ’ to take to your bed . That 's what comes o ’ neglectin ’ nature .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Throwing her arms about JOHN 'S neck .Paul , you 're goin ’ to leave me ! For God 's sake , tell me right out that it 's so ! Don ’ fool me aroun ’ an ’ cheat me ! Tell me right out !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: What 's the matter with you to-day , Henrietta ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Pulling herself together .Don ’ attend to my fool talk . I ai n't had no rest all night — that 's it . An ’ then I got up reel early , an ’ anyhow , it ai n't nothin ’ but that I 'm a bit weak yet .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then you better lie down flat on your back an ’ rest a little .MRS. JOHN throws herself on the sofa and stares at the ceiling .Maybe you 'd better comb yourself a bit afterwards , Jette !— It musta been mighty dusty on the train for you to be jus ’ covered all over with sand the way you are !MRS. JOHN does not answer but continues staring at the ceiling .I must go an ’ bring that there little feller into the light a bit .

div.stage: He goes behind the partition .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: How long has we been married , Paul ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Plays with the rattle behind the partition . Then answers :That was in eighteen hundred and seventy-two , jus ’ as I came back from the war .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Then you came to father , did n't you ? An ’ you assoomed a grand position an ’ you had the Iron Cross on the left side o ’ your chest .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Appears , swinging the rattle and carrying the child on its pillow . He speaks merrily .That 's so , mother . An ’ I got it yet . If you want to see it , I 'll pin it on .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Still stretched out on the sofa .An ’ then you came to me an ’ you said that I was n't to be so busy all the time ... goin ’ up an ’ down , runnin ’ upstairs an ’ downstairs ... that I was to be a bit more easy-goin ’ .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: An ’ I 'm still sayin ’ that same thing to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: An ’ then you tickled me with your moustache an ’ kissed me right behind my left ear ! An ’ then ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Then it did n't take long for us to agree , eh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Yes , an ’ I laughed an ’ , bit by bit , I looked at myself in every one o ’ your brass buttons . I was lookin ’ different then ! An ’ then you said ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well , mother , you 're a great one for rememberin ’ things , I must say !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: An ’ then you said : When we has a boy , an ’ that 'll be soon , he c'n follow the flag into the field too “ with God for King an ’ country . ”

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Sings to the child , playing with the rattle .“ To heaven he turns his glances bold Whence gaze the hero sires of old : The Rhine , the Rhine , the German Rhine ! ” ... Well , an ’ now that I has a little feller like that I ai n't half so keen on sendin ’ him to the war to be food for powder .

div.stage: He retires with the child behind the partition .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Still staring at the ceiling .Paul , Paul ! Seems as if all that was a hundred years ago !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Reappears from behind the partition without the child .Not as long ago as all that .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Look here , what d'you think ? How would it be if you was to take me an ’ the child an ’ go to America ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Now listen here , Jette ! What 's gotten into you , anyhow ? What is it ? Looks as if there was nothin ’ but ghosts aroun ’ me here ! You know I has a good easy temper ! When the workmen heave bricks at each other , I do n't even get excited . An ’ what do they say ? Paul has a comfortable nature . But now : what 's this here ? The sun 's shinin ’ ; it 's bright daylight ! I can n't see nothin ’ ; that 's a fac ’ . But somethin 's titterin ’ an ’ whisperin ’ an ’ creepin ’ aroun ’ in here . Only when I stretches out my hand I can n't lay hold on nothin ’ ! Now I wants to know what there is to this here story about the strange girl what came to the room . Is it true ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You heard , Paul , that the young lady did n't come back no more . An ’ that shows you , do n't it ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I hear what you 're sayin ’ . But your lips is fair blue an ’ your eyes look as if somebody was tormentin ’ you .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Suddenly changing her attitudeYes . Why do you leave me alone year in an ’ year out , Paul ? I sits here like in a cave an ’ I ai n't got a soul to who I c'n say what I 'm thinkin ’ . Many a time I 've sat here an ’ axed myself why I works an ’ works , why I skimps an ’ saves to get together a few crowns , an ’ find good investments for your earnin 's an ’ try to add to ‘ em . Why ? Was all that to go to strangers ? Paul , it 's you who 's been the ruin o ’ me !She lays her head on the table and bursts out in sobs .Softly and with feline stealth BRUNO MECHELKE enters the room at this moment . He has on his Sunday duds , a sprig of lilac in his hat and a great bunch of it in his hand . JOHN drums with his fingers on the window and does not observe him .

lg.stage: Has gradually realised BRUNO 'S presence as though he were a ghost .
lg.l: Bruno , is that you ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Who has recognised JOHN in a flash , softly .Sure , it 's me , Jette .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Where d'you come from ? What d'you want ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: I been dancin ’ all night , Jette ! You c'n see , can n't you , that I 'm dam ’ jolly ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Has been staring steadily at BRUNO . A dangerous pallor has overspread his face . He now goes slowly to a small cupboard , takes out an old army revolver and loads it . MRS. JOHN does not observe this .You ! Listen ! I 'll tell you somethin ’ — somethin ’ you forgot , maybe . There ai n't no reason on God 's earth why I should n't pull this here trigger ! You scoundrel ! You ai n't fit to be among human bein 's ! I told you ... las ’ fall it was ... that I 'd shoot you down if I ever laid eyes on you in my home again ! Now go ... or I 'll ... shoot . Y'understan ’ ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Aw , I ai n't scared o ’ your jelly squirter .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Who observes that JOHN , losing control of himself , is slowly approaching BRUNO with the weapon and raising it .Then kill me too , Paul . ‘ Cause he 's my brother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Looks at her long , seems to awaken and change his mind .All right .He replaces the revolver carefully in the cupboard .You 're right , anyhow , Jette ! It 's hell , Jette , that your name 's got to be on the tongue of a crittur like that . All right . The powder 'd be too good , too . This here little pistol 's tasted the blood o ’ two French cavalry men ! Heroes they was ! An ’ I do n't want it to drink no dirt .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: I ain ’ doubtin ’ that there 's dirt in your head ! An ’ if it had n't been that you board with my sister here I 'd ha ’ let the light into you long ago , you dirt eater , so you 'd ha ’ bled for weeks .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With tense restraint .Tell me again , Jette , that it 's your brother .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Go , Paul , will you ? I 'll get him away all right ! You know 's well as I that I can n't help it now that Bruno 's my own brother .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right . Then I 'm one too many here . You c'n bill an ’ coo .He is dressed for the street as it is and hence proceeds to go . Close by BRUNO he stands still .You scamp ! You worried your father into his grave . Your sister might better ha ’ let you starve behind some fence rather'n raise you an ’ litter the earth with another criminal like you . I 'll be back in half an hour ! But I wo n't be alone . I 'll have the sergeant with me !JOHN leaves by the outer door , putting on his slouch hat .So soon as JOHN has disappeared BRUNO turns and spits out after him toward the door .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: If I ever gets hold o ’ you !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Why d'you come , Bruno ? Tell me , what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Tin 's what you gotta give me . Or I 'll go to hell .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Locks and latches the outer door .Wait till I close the door ! Now , what 's the matter ? Where d'you come from ? Where has you been ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Oh , I danced about half the night an ’ then , about sunrise , I went out into the country for a bit .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Did Quaquaro see you comin ’ in , Bruno ? Then you better look out that you ai n't walked into no trap .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: No danger . I crossed the yard an ’ then went through the cellar o ’ my friend what deals in junk an ’ after that up through the loft .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well , an ’ what happened ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Don ’ fool aroun ’ , Jette . I gotta have railroad fare . I gotta take to my heels or I 'll go straight to hell .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: An ’ what did you do with that there girl ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Oh , I found a way , Jette !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Oh , I managed to make her a little more accommodatin ’ all right !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: An ’ is it a sure thing that she wo n't come back now ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Sure . I don ’ believe that she 'll come again ! But that was n't no easy piece of work , Jette . But I tell you ... gimme somethin ’ to drink — quick !... I tell you , you made me thirsty with your damned business — thirsty , an ’ hot as hell .

div.stage: He drains a jug full of water .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: People saw you outside the door with the girl .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: I had to make a engagement with Arthur . She did n't want to have nothin ’ to do with me . But Arthur , he came dancin ’ along in his fine clothes an ’ he managed to drag her along to a bar . She swallowed the bait right down when he told her as how her intended was waitin ’ for her there .He trills out , capering about convulsively .“ All we does in life 's to go Up an ’ down an ’ to an ’ fro From a tap-room to a show ! ”

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well , an ’ then ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Then she wanted to get away ‘ cause Arthur said that her intended had gone off ! Then I wanted to go along with her a little bit an ’ Arthur an ’ Adolph , they came along . Next we dropped in the ladies ’ entrance at Kalinich 's an ’ what with tastin ’ a lot o ’ toddy an ’ other liquors she got good an ’ tipsy . An ’ then she staid all night with a woman what 's Arthur 's sweetheart . All next day there was always two or three of us boys after her , did n't let her go , an ’ played all kinds o ’ tricks , an ’ things got jollier an ’ jollier .

div.stage: The church bells of the Sunday morning services begin to ring .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Goes on .But the money 's gone . I needs crowns an ’ pennies , Jette .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Rummaging for money .How much has you got to have ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Listening to the bells .What ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Money !

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: The old bag o ’ bones in the junk shop downstairs was thinkin ’ as how I 'd better get across the Russian frontier ! Listen , Jette , how the bells is ringin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Why do you has to get acrost the frontier ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Take a wet towel , Jette , an ’ put a little vinegar on it . I been bothered with this here dam ’ nosebleed all night .

div.stage: He presses his handkerchief to his nose .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Breathing convulsively , brings a towel .Who was it scratched your wrist into shreds that way ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Listening to the bells .Half past three o'clock this mornin ’ she could ha ’ heard them bells yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: O Jesus , my Saviour ! That ai n't true ! That can n't noways be possible ! I did n't tell you nothin ’ like that , Bruno ! Bruno , I has to sit down . Oh !She sits down .That 's what our father foretold to me on his dyin ’ bed .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: It ai n't so easy jokin ’ with me . If you go to see Minna , jus ’ tell her that I got the trick o ’ that kind o ’ thing an ’ that them goin 's on with Karl an ’ with Fritz has to stop .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: But , Bruno , if they was to catch you !

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Well , then I has to swing , an ’ out at the Charity hospital they got another stiff to dissect .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Giving him money .Oh , that ai n't true . What did you do , Bruno ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: You 're a crazy old crittur , Jette .—He puts his hand on her not without a tremor of emotion .You always says as how I ai n't good for nothin ’ . But when things can n't go on no more , then you needs me , Jette .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well , but how ? Did you threaten the girl that she was n't to let herself be seen no more ? That 's what you ought to ha ’ done , Bruno ! An ’ did you ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: I danced with her half the night . An ’ then we went out on the street . Well , a gentleman came along , y'understan ’ ? Well , when I told him that I had some little business o ’ my own to transact with the lady an ’ pulled my brass-knuckles outa my breeches , o ’ course he took to his heels .— Then I says to her , says I : Do n't you be scared . If you 're peaceable an ’ don ’ make no outcry an ’ don ’ come no more to my sister axin ’ after the child — well , we c'n make a reel friendly bargain . So she toddled along with me a ways .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well , an ’ then ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Well , she did n't want to ! An ’ all of a sudden she went for my throat that I thought it 'd be the end o ’ me then an ’ there ! Like a dawg she went for me hot an ’ heavy ! An ’ then ... then I got a little bit excited too — an ’ then , well ... that 's how it come ...

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Sunk in horror .What time d'you say it was ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: It must ha ’ been somewhere between three an ’ four . The moon had a big ring aroun ’ it . Out on the square there was a dam ’ cur behind the planks what got up an ’ howled . Then it began to drip an ’ soon a thunderstorm came up .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Changed and with sudden self-mastery .It 's all right . Go on . She don ’ deserve no better .

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Good-bye . I s'pose we ai n't goin ’ to see each other for years an ’ years .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Where you goin ’ to ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: First of all I gotta lie flat on my back for a couple o ’ hours . I 'm goin ’ to Fritz 's . He 's got a room for rent in the old police station right acrost from the Fisher 's Bridge . I 'm safe there all right . If there 's anythin ’ of a outcry you c'n lemme know .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Don ’ you want to take a peek at the child onct more ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: Trembling .Naw !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: BRUNO
sp.p: No , Jette , not in this here life ! Good-bye , Jette . Hol ’ on a minute : Here I got a horseshoe .He puts a horseshoe on the table .I found it . That 'll bring you good luck . I don ’ need it . Stealthily as he has come , BRUNO MECHELKE also disappears . MRS. JOHN , her eyes wide with horror , stares at the spot where he stood . Then she totters backward a few paces , presses her hands , clenched convulsively as if in prayer , against her mouth , and collapses , still trying in vain to stammer out a prayerful appeal to heaven .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I ai n't no murderer ! I ai n't no murderer ! I did n't want that to happen !

div.head: FIFTH ACT

sp.speaker: JOHN 'S room . MRS. JOHN is asleep on the sofa . WALBURGA and SPITTA
sp.p: enter from the outer hall . The loud playing of a military band is heard from the street .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: No one is here .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Oh , yes , there is , Erich . Mrs. John ! She 's asleep here .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Approaching the sofa together with WALBURGA .Is she asleep ? So she is ! I do n't understand how anyone can sleep amidst this noise . The music of the band trails off into silence .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Oh , Erich , sh ! I have a perfect horror of the woman . Can you understand anyhow why policemen are guarding the entrance downstairs and why they wo n't let us go out into the street ? I 'm so awfully afraid that , maybe , they 'll arrest us and take us along to the station .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Oh , but there 's not the slightest danger , Walburga ! You 're seeing ghosts by broad daylight .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: When the plain clothes man came up to you and looked at us and you asked him who he was and he showed his badge under his coat , I assure you , at that moment , the stairs and the hall suddenly began to go around with me .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: They 're looking for a criminal , Walburga . It is a so-called raid that is going on here , a kind of man hunt such as the criminal police is at times obliged to undertake .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: And you can believe me , too , Erich , that I heard papa 's voice . He was talking quite loudly to some one .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: You are nervous . You may have been mistaken .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Frightened at MRS. JOHN , who is speaking in her sleep .Listen to her : do !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Great drops of sweat are standing on her forehead . Come here ! Just look at the rusty old horseshoe that she is clasping with both hands .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Listens and starts with fright again .Papa !

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: I do n't understand you . Let him come , Walburga . The essential thing is that one knows what one wants and that one has a clean conscience . I am ready . I long for the explanation to come about . A loud knocking is heard at the door .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Firmly .Come in !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER enters , more out of breath than usual . An
sp.p: expression of relief comes over her face as she catches sight of her daughter .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Thank God ! There you are , children !Trembling , WALBURGA throws herself into her mother 's arms .Girlie , but what a fright you 've given your old mother .

div.stage: A pause in which only the breathing of MRS. HASSENREUTER is heard .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Forgive me , mama : I could n't act differently .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Oh , no ! One does n't write letters containing such thoughts to one 's own mother . And especially not to a mother like me . If your soul is in pain you know very well that you can always count on me for help and counsel . I 'm not a monster , and I was young myself once . But to threaten to drown yourself ... and things like that ... no , that 's all wrong . You should n't have done that . Surely you agree with me , Mr. Spitta . And now this very minute ... heavens , how you both look !... this very minute you must both come home with me !— What 's the matter with Mrs. John ?

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Oh yes , help us ! Do n't forsake us ! Take us with you , mama ! Oh , I 'm so glad that you 're here ! I was just paralysed with fright !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Very well , then . Come along . That would be the last straw if one had to be prepared for such desperate follies from you , Mr. Spitta , or from this child ! At your age one should have courage . If everything does n't go quite smoothly you have no right to think of expedients by which one has nothing to gain and everything to lose . We live but once , after all .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Oh , I have courage ! And I 'm not thinking of putting an end to myself as one who is weary and defeated ... unless Walburga is refused to me . In that case , to be sure , my determination is firm . It does n't in the least undermine my belief in myself or in my future that I am poor for the present and have to take my dinner occasionally in the people 's kitchen . And I am sure Walburga is equally convinced that a day must come that will indemnify us for all the dark and difficult hours of the present .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Life is long ; and you 're almost children to-day . It 's not so very bad for a student to have to take an occasional meal in the people 's kitchen . It would be much worse , however , for Walburga as a married woman . And I hope for the sake of you both that you 'll wait till something in the nature of a hearthstone of your own with the necessary wood and coal can be founded . In the meantime I 've succeeded in persuading papa to a kind of truce . It was n't easy and it might have been impossible had not this morning 's mail brought the news of his definitive appointment as manager of the theatre at Strassburg .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Joyously .Oh , mama , mama ! That is a ray of sunshine , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Sits up with a start .Bruno !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Apologising .Oh , we 've wakened you , Mrs. John .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Is Bruno gone ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Who ? Who 's Bruno ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Why , Bruno ! Don ’ you know Bruno ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Ah , yes , yes ! That 's the name of your brother .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Was I asleep ?

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Fast asleep . But you cried out aloud in your sleep just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Did you see , Mr. Spitta , how them boys out in the yard threw stones at my little Adelbert 's wee grave ? But I got after ‘ em , eh ? An ’ they was n't no bad slaps neither what I dealt out .

lg.l: It seems that you 've been dreaming of your first little boy who died ,
Mrs. John .
No , no ; all that 's fac ’ ! I ai n't been dreamin ’ . An ’ then I took little
Adelbert an ’ I went with him to the registrar 's office .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: But if your little boy 's no longer alive ... how could you ...

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Aw , when a little child is onct born , it do n't matter if it 's dead ... it 's still right inside o ’ its mother . Did you hear that dawg howlin ’ behind the board fence ? An ’ the moon had a big ring aroun ’ it ! Bruno , you ain ’ doin ’ right !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Shaking MRS. JOHN .Wake up , my good woman ! Wake up , Mrs. John ! You are ill ! Your husband ought to take you to see a physician .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Bruno , you ain ’ doin ’ right !The bells are ringing again .Ai n't them the bells ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: The service is over , Mrs. John .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Wholly awake now , stares about her .Why does I wake up ? Why did n't you take an ax when I was asleep an ’ knock me over the head with it ?— What did I say ? Sh ! Only do n't tell a livin ’ soul a word , Mrs. Hassenreuter .She jumps up and arranges her hair by the help of many hairpins .Manager HASSENREUTER appears in the doorway .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Starting at the sight of his family .“ Behold , behold , Timotheus , Here are the cranes of Ibicus ! ” Did n't you tell me there was a shipping agent 's office in the neighbourhood , Mrs . John ?—To WALBURGA .Ah , yes , my child ! While , with the frivolousness of youth you have been thinking of your pleasure and nothing but your pleasure , your papa has been running about for three whole hours again purely on business .—To SPITTA .You would n't be in such a hurry to establish a family , young man , if you had the least suspicion how hard it is — a struggle from day to day — to get even the wretched , mouldy necessary bit of daily bread for one 's wife and child ! I trust it will never be your fate to be suddenly hurled one day , quite penniless , into the underworld of Berlin and be obliged to struggle for a naked livelihood for yourself and those dear to you , breast to breast with others equally desperate , in subterranean holes and passages ! But you may all congratulate me ! A week from now we will be in Strassburg .MRS. HASSENREUTER , WALBURGA and SPITTA all press his hand .Everything else will be adjusted .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: You have fought an heroic battle for us during these past years , papa . And you did it without stooping to anything unworthy .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: It was a fight like that of drowning men who struggle for planks in the water . My noble costumes , made to body forth the dreams of poets , in what dens of vice , on what reeking bodies have they not passed their nights — odi profanum vulgus — only that a few pennies of rental might clatter in my cashbox ! But let us turn to more cheerful thoughts . The freight waggon , alias the cart of Thespis is at the door in order to effect the removal of our Penates to happier fields —Suddenly turning to SPITTA .My excellent Spitta , I demand your word of honour that , in your so-called despair , you two do not commit some irreparable folly . In return I promise to lend my ear to any utterances of yours characterised by a modicum of good sense .— Finally : I 've come to you , Mrs. John , firstly because the officers bar all the exits and will permit no one to go out ; and secondly because I would like exceedingly to know why a man like myself , at the very moment when his triumphant flag is fluttering in the wind again , should have become the object of a malicious newspaper report !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Dear Harro , Mrs. John does n't understand you .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Aha ! Then let us begin ab ovo . I have letters herehe shows a bundle of themone , two , three , five — about a dozen ! In these letters unknown but malicious individuals congratulate me upon an event which is said to have taken place in my storage loft . I would pay no attention to these communications were they not confirmed by a news item in the papers according to which a newborn infant is said to have been found in the loft of a costumer in the suburbs ... a costumer , forsooth ! I would have said nothing , I repeat , if this item had not perplexed me . Undoubtedly there is a case of mistaken identity involved here . In spite of that , I do n't like to have the report stick to me . Especially since this cub of a reporter speaks of the costumer as being a bankrupt manager of barn stormers . Read it , mama : “ The Stork Visits Costumer . ” I 'll box that fellow 's ears ! This evening my appointment at Strassburg is to be made public in the papers and at the same time I am to be offered as a kind of comic dessert urbi et orbi . As if it were not obvious that of all curses that of being made ridiculous is the worst !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You say there 's policemen at the door downstairs , sir ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Yes , and their watch is so close that the funeral procession of Mrs. Knobbe 's baby has been brought to a standstill . They wo n't even let the little coffin and the horrid fellow from the burial society who is carrying it go out to the carriage .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What child 's funeral was that ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Do n't you know ? It 's the little son of Mrs. Knobbe which was brought up to me in so mysterious a way by two women and died almost under my very eyes , probably of exhaustion . A propos ...

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: The Knobbe woman 's child is dead ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: A propos , Mrs. John , I was going to say that you ought really to know how the affair of those two half-crazy women who got hold of the child finally ended ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well now , tell me , ai n't it like the very finger of God that they did n't take my little Adelbert an ’ that he did n't die ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Just why ? I do n't understand the logic of that . On the other hand , I have been asking myself whether the confused speeches of the Polish girl , the theft committed in my loft , and the milk bottle which Quaquaro brought down in a boot — whether all these things had not something to do with the notice in the papers .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: No , there ai n't no connection between them things . Has you seen Paul , sir ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Paul ? Ah yes ; that 's your husband . Yes , yes . Indeed I saw him in conversation with detective Puppe , who visited me too in connection with the theft .

lg.l: JOHN
Well , Jette , was n't I right ? This here thing 's happened soon enough !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What 's happened ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: D'you want me to go an ’ earn the thousand crowns ’ reward what 's offered accordin ’ to placards on the news pillars by the chief o ’ police 's office for denouncin ’ the criminal ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: How 's that ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Do n't you know that all this manoeuverin ’ o ’ police an ’ detectives is started on account o ’ Bruno ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: How so ? Where ? What is it ? What 's been started ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: The funeral 's been stopped an ’ two o ’ the mourners — queer customers they is , too — has been taken prisoner . Yes , sir ! That 's the pass things has come to , Mr. Hassenreuter . I 'm a man , sir , what 's tied to a women as has a brother what 's bein ’ pursued by the criminal police an ’ by detectives because he killed a woman not far from the river under a lilac bush .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: But my dear Mr. John : God forbid that that be true !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: That 's a lie ! My brother don ’ do nothin ’ like that .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Aw , don ’ he though , Jette ? Mr. Hassenreuter , I was sayin ’ the other day what kind of a brother that is !He notices the bunch of lilacs and takes it from the table .Look at this here ! That there monster 's been in my home ! If he comes back I 'll be the first one that 'll take him , bound hand an ’ foot , an ’ deliver him up to justice !

div.stage: He searches through the whole room .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You c'n tell dam ’ fools there 's such a thing as justice . There ai n't no justice , not even in heaven . There was n't a soul here . An ’ that bit o ’ lilac I brought along from Hangelsberg where a big bush of it grows behind your sister 's house .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jette , you was n't at my sister 's at all . Quaquaro jus ’ told me that ! They proved that at headquarters . You was seen in the park by the river ...

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Lies !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: An ’ ‘ way out in the suburbs where you passed the night in a arbour !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What ? D'you come into your own house to tear everythin ’ into bits ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: All right ! I ai n't sorry that things has come to this . There ai n't no more secrets between us here . I foretold all that .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Tense with interest .Did that Polish girl who fought like a lioness for Mrs. Knobbe 's baby the other day ever show herself again ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: She 's the very one . She 's the one what they pulled out o ’ the water this morning . An ’ I has to say it without bitin ’ my tongue off : Bruno Mechelke took that girl 's life .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Quickly .Then she was probably his mistress ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Ask mother ! I don ’ know about that ! That 's what I was scared of ; that 's the reason I rather did n't come home at all no more , that my own wife was loaded down with a crowd like that an ’ did n't have the strength to shake it off .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Come , children !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why so ? You jus ’ stay !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You don ’ has to go an ’ open the windows an ’ cry out everythin ’ for all the world to hear ! It 's bad enough if fate 's brought a misfortune like that on us . Go on ! Make a noise about it if you want to . But you wo n't see me very soon again .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: And you mean to say that that ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: That 's jus ’ what I 'll do ! Jus ’ that ! I 'll call in anybody as wants to know — outa the street , offa the hall , the carpenter outa the yard , the boys an ’ the girls what takes their confirmation lessons — I 'll call ‘ em all an ’ I 'll tell ‘ em what a woman got into on account o ’ her fool love for her brother !

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: And so that good-looking girl who laid claim to the child is actually dead to-day ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Maybe she was good-lookin ’ . I don ’ know nothin ’ about that , whether she was pretty or ugly . But it 's a fac ’ that she 's lyin ’ in the morgue this day .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I c'n tell you what she was ! She was a common , low wench ! She had dealin 's with a Tyrolese feller that did n't want to have nothin ’ more to do with her an ’ she had a child by him . An ’ she 'd ha ’ liked to kill that child while it was in her own womb . Then she came to fetch it with that Kielbacke what 's been in prison eighteen months as a professional baby-killer . Whether she had any dealin 's with Bruno , I don ’ know ! Maybe so an ’ maybe not ! An ’ anyhow , I don ’ see how it concerns me what Bruno 's gone an ’ done .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: So you did know the girl in question , Mrs. John ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: How so ? I did n't know her a bit ! I 'm only sayin ’ what everybody as knows says about that there girl .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: You 're an honourable woman : you 're an honourable man , Mr. John . This matter with your wayward brother is terrible enough as a fact , but it ought not seriously to undermine your married life . Stay honest and ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Not a bit of it ! I do n't stay with such people ; not anywhere near ‘ em .He brings his fist down on the table , taps at the walls , stamps on the floor .Listen to the crackin ’ ! Listen , how the plasterin ’ comes rumblin ’ down behind the wall-paper ! Everything rotten here , everythin 's worm eaten ! Everythin 's undermined by varmint an ’ by rats an ’ by mice .He see-saws on a loose plank in the floor .Every thin ’ totters ! Any minute the whole business might crash down into the cellar .—He opens the door .Selma ! Selma ! I 'm goin ’ to pull outa here before the whole thing just falls together into a heap o ’ rubbish !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: What do you want o ’ Selma ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Selma is goin ’ to take that child an ’ I 'll go with ‘ em on the train an ’ take it out to my sister .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You 'll hear from me if you try that ! Oh , you jus ’ try it !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Is my child to be brought up in surroundin 's like this , an ’ maybe some day be driven over the roofs with Bruno an ’ maybe end in the penitentiary ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Cries out at him .That ai n't your child at all ! Y'understan ’ ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: ‘ S that so ? Well , we 'll see if an honest man can n't be master o ’ his own child what 's got a mother that 's gone crazy an ’ is in the hands of a crowd o ’ murderers . I 'd like to see who 's in the right there an ’ who 's the stronger . Selma !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I 'll scream ! I 'll tear open the windows ! Mrs. Hassenreuter , they wants to rob a mother o ’ her child ! That 's my right that I 'm the mother o ’ my child ! Ai n't that my right ? Ai n't that so , Mrs. Hassenreuter ? They 're surroundin ’ me ! They wants to rob me o ’ my rights ! Ai n't it goin ’ to belong to me what I picked up like refuse , what was lyin ’ on rags half-dead , an ’ I had to rub it an ’ knead it all I could before it began to breathe an ’ come to life slowly ? If it was n't for me , it would ha ’ been covered with earth these three weeks !

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Mr. John , to play the part of an arbitrator between married people is not ordinarily my function . It 's too thankless a task and one 's experiences are , as a rule , too unhappy . But you should not permit your feeling of honour , justly wounded as , no doubt , it is , to hurry you into acts that are rash . For , after all , your wife is not responsible for her brother 's act . Let her have the child ! Do n't increase the misery of it all by such hardness toward your wife as must hurt her most cruelly and unnecessarily .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Paul , that child 's like as if it was cut outa my own flesh ! I bought that child with my blood . It ai n't enough that all the world 's after me an ’ wants to take it away from me ; now you gotta join ‘ em an ’ do the same ! That 's the thanks a person gets ! Why , it 's like a pack o ’ hungry wolves aroun ’ me . You c'n kill me ! But you can n't touch my baby !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: I comes home , Mr. Hassenreuter , only this mornin ’ . I comes home with all my tools on the train , jolly as c'n be . I broke off all my connections in Hamburg . Even if you don ’ earn so much , says I to myself , you 'd rather be with your family , an ’ take up your child in your arms a little , or maybe take it on your knee a little ! That was about the way I was thinkin ’ !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Paul ! Here , Paul !She goes close up to him .You c'n tear my heart out if you want to !

div.stage: She stares long at him , then runs behind the partition , whence her loud weeping is heard .

sp.speaker: SELMA enters from the hall . She is dressed in mourning garments and
sp.p: carries a little wreath in her hand .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: What is I to do ? You called me , Mr. John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Put on your cloak , Selma . Ax your mother if you c'n go an ’ take a trip with me to Hangelsberg . You 'll earn a bit o ’ money doin ’ it . All you gotta do is to take my child on your arm an ’ come along with me .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: No , I ain ’ goin ’ to touch that child no more .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: No ; I 'm afraid , Mr. John ! I 'm that scared at the way mama an ’ the police lieutenant screamed at me .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Appears .Why did they scream at you ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Crying vociferously .Officer Schierke even slapped my face .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Well , I 'll see about that ... he oughta try that again .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: I can n't tell why that Polish girl took my little brother away . If I 'd known that my little brother was goin ’ to die , I 'd ha ’ jumped at her throat first . Now little Gundofried 's coffin stands on the stairs . I believe mama has convulsions an ’ is lyin ’ down in Quaquaro 's alcove . An ’ me they wants to take to the charity organisation , Mrs. John .

div.stage: She weeps .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Then you c'n be reel happy . They can n't treat you worse'n you was treated at home .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: An ’ I gotta go to court ! An ’ maybe they 'll take me to gaol !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: On account o ’ what ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Because they says I took the child what the Polish girl had up in the loft an ’ carried it down to you .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: So a child actually was born up there .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: In whose loft ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Why , where them actors lives ! It ai n't none o ’ my business ! How is I to know anythin ’ about it ? All I c'n say is ...

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You better hurry on about your business now , Selma ! You got a clean conscience ! You don ’ has to care for what people jabber .

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: An ’ I don ’ want to betray nothin ’ neither , Mrs. John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Grasps SELMA , who is about to run away , and holds her fast .Naw , you ai n't goin ’ ! Here you stays ! The truth ! “ I don ’ want to betray nothin ’ , ” you says . You heard that , too , Mrs. Hassenreuter ? An ’ Mr. Spitta an ’ the young lady here heard it too . The truth ! You ai n't goin ’ to leave this here spot before I don ’ know the rights o ’ this matter about Bruno an ’ his mistress , an ’ if you people did away with that child !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Paul , I swear before God that I ai n't done away with it !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Well ...? Out with what you know , girl ! I been seein ’ for a long time that there 's been some secret scheming between you an ’ my wife . There ai n't no use no more in all that winkin ’ an ’ noddin ’ . Is that child dead or alive ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: No , that child is alive all right .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: The one , you mean , that you carried down here under your apron or in some such way ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: If it 's dead you c'n be sure that you an ’ Bruno 'll both be made a head shorter'n you are !

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: I 'm tellin ’ you the child is alive .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: But you said at first that you had n't brought down any child at all .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: An ’ you pretend to know nothin ’ o ’ that whole business , mother ?MRS. JOHN stares at him ; SELMA gazes helplessly and confusedly at MRS. JOHN .Mother , you got rid o ’ the child o ’ Bruno an ’ that Polish wench an ’ then , when people came after it , you went an ’ substitooted that little crittur o ’ Knobbe 's .

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Very pale and conquering her repugnance .Tell me , Mrs. John , what happened on that day when I so foolishly took flight up into the loft at papa 's coming ? I 'll explain that to you later , papa . On that occasion , as became clear to me later , I saw the Polish girl twice : first with Mrs. John and then with her brother .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: You , Walburga ?

sp.speaker: WALBURGA
sp.p: Yes , papa . Alice Ruetterbusch was with you that day , and I had made an engagement to meet Erich here . He came to see you finally but failed to meet me because I kept hidden .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: I can n't say that I have any recollection of that .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: To her husband .The girl has really passed more than one sleepless night on account of this matter .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Well , Mrs. John , if you are inclined to attach any weight to the opinion of a former jurist who exchanged the law for an artistic career only after having been plucked in his bar examination — in that case let me assure you that , under the circumstances , ruthless frankness will prove your best defense .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Jette , where did you put that there child ? The head detective told me — I jus ’ remember it now — that they 're still huntin ’ aroun ’ for the child o ’ the dead woman ! Jette , for God 's sake , do n't you have ‘ em suspect you o ’ layin ’ hands on that there newborn child jus ’ to get the proofs o ’ your brother 's rascality outa the world !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Me lay hands on little Adelbert , Paul ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Nobody ai n't talkin ’ o ’ Adelbert here .To SELMA .I 'll knock your head off for you if you don ’ tell me this minute what 's become o ’ the child o ’ Bruno an ’ the Polish girl !

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Why , it 's behind your own partition , Mr. John !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Where is it , Jette ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: I ai n't goin ’ to tell that . The child begins to cry .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: To SELMA .The truth ! Or I 'll turn you over to the police , y'understan ’ ? See this rope ? I 'll tie you hand and foot !

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Involuntarily , in the extremity of her fear .It 's cryin ’ now ! You know that child well enough . Mr. John .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Me ?

div.stage: Utterly at sea he looks first at SELMA , then at HASSENREUTER . Suddenly a suspicion flashes upon him as he turns his gaze upon his wife . He believes that he is beginning to understand and wavers .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Do n't you let a low down lie like that take you in , Paul ! It 's all invented by the fine mother that girl has outa spite ! Paul , why d'you look at me so ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: That 's low of you , mother John , that you wants to make me out so bad now . Then I wo n't be careful neither not to let nothin ’ out ! You know all right that I carried the young lady 's child down here an ’ put it in the nice , clean bed . I c'n swear to that ! I c'n take my oath on that !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Lies ! Lies ! You says that my child ai n't my child !

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Why , you ai n't had no child at all , Mrs. John !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Embraces her husband 's knees .Oh , that ai n't true at all !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: You leave me alone , Henrietta ! Don ’ dirty me with your hands !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Paul , I could n't do no different . I had to do that , I was deceived myself an ’ then I told you about it in my letter to Hamburg an ’ then you was so happy an ’ I could n't disappoint you an ’ I thought : it 's gotta be ! We c'n has a child this way too an ’ then ...

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With ominous calmness .Lemme think it over , Jette .He goes to the chest of drawers , opens a drawer and flings the baby linen and baby dresses that he finds therein into the middle of the room .C'n anybody understan ’ how week after week , an ’ month after month , all day long an ’ half the nights she could ha ’ worked on this trash till her fingers was bloody ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Gathers up the linen and the dresses in insane haste and hides them carefully in the table drawer and elsewhere .Paul , don ’ do that ! You c'n do anythin ’ else ! It 's like tearin ’ the last rag offa my naked body !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Stops , grasps his forehead and sinks into a chair .If that 's true , mother , I 'll be too ashamed to show my face again .

div.stage: He seems to sink into himself , crosses his arms over his head and hides his face .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Mrs. John , how could you permit yourself to be forced into a course of so much error and deception ? You 've entangled yourself in the most frightful way ! Come , children ! Unhappily there is nothing more for us to do here .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Gets up .You might as well take me along with you , sir .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Go on ! Go on ! I don ’ need you !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Turning to her , coldly .So you bargained for that there kid someway an ’ when its mother wanted it back you got Bruno to kill her ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: You ai n't no husband o ’ mine ! How could that be ! You been bought by the police ! You took money to give me up to my death ! Go on , Paul , you ai n't human even ! You got poison in your eyes an ’ teeth like wolves ’ ! Go on an ’ whistle so they 'll come an ’ take me ! Go on , I says ! Now I see the kind o ’ man you is an ’ I 'll despise you to the day o ’ judgment !

div.stage: She is about to run from the room when policeman SCHIERKE and QUAQUARO appear .

sp.speaker: SCHIERKE
sp.p: Hold on ! Nobody can n't get outa this room .

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: Come right in , Emil ! You c'n come in reel quiet , officer . Everything in order here an ’ all right .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Do n't get excited , Paul ! This here don ’ concern you !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With rising rage .Did you laugh , Emil ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Man alive , why should I ? Only Mr. Schierke is to take that there little one to the orphan house in a cab .

sp.speaker: SCHIERKE
sp.p: Yessir ! That 's right . Where is the child ?

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: How is I to know where all the brats offa junk heaps that witches use in their doin 's gets to in the end ? Watch the chimney ! Maybe it flew outa there on a broomstick .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHN
sp.p: Paul !— Now it ai n't to live ! No , outa spite ! Now it don ’ has to live ! Now it 's gotta go down under the ground with me !

div.stage: With lightning-like rapidity she has run behind the partition and reappears at once with the child and makes for the door . HASSENREUTER and SPITTA throw themselves in front of the desperate woman , intent on saving the child .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Stop ! I 'll interfere now ! I have the right to do so at this point ! Whomever the little boy may belong to — so much the worse if its mother has been murdered — it was born on my premises ! Forward , Spitta ! Fight for it , my boy ! Here your propensities come properly into play ! Go on ! Careful ! That 's it ! Bravo ! Be as careful as though it were the Christ child ! Bravo ! That 's it ! You yourself are at liberty , Mrs. John . We do n't restrain you . You must only leave us the little boy .

lg.l: SCHIERKE
Here you stays !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: The woman is desperate . Stop her ! Hold her !

sp.speaker: JOHN
sp.p: With a sudden change .Look out for mother ! Mother ! Stop her ! Catch hold o ’ her ! Mother ! Mother !

sp.speaker: SELMA , SCHIERKE and JOHN hurry after MRS. JOHN . SPITTA ,
sp.p: HASSENREUTER , MRS. HASSENREUTER and WALBURGA busy themselves about the child , which lies on the table .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Carefully wrapping the infant .The horrible woman may be desperate for all I care ! But for that reason she need n't destroy the child .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: But , dearest papa , is n't it quite evident that the woman has pinned her love , silly to the point of madness as it is , to this very infant ? Thoughtless and harsh words may actually drive the unhappy creature to her death .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: I used no harsh words , mama .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: An unmistakable feeling assures me that the child has only now lost its mother .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: That 's true . Its father ai n't aroun ’ an ’ don ’ want to have nothin ’ to do with it . He got married yesterday to the widow of a man who owned a merry-go-roun ’ ! Its mother was no better'n she should be ! An ’ if Mrs. Kielbacke was to take care of it , it 'd die like ten outa every dozen what she boards . The way things has come aroun ’ now — it 'll have to die too .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Unless our Father above who sees all things has differently determined .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: D'you mean Paul , the mason ? Not now ! No sir ! I knows him ! He 's a ticklish customer where his honour is concerned .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Just look how the child lies there ! It 's incomprehensible ! Fine linen — even lace ! Neat and sweet as a doll ! It makes one 's heart ache to think how suddenly it has become an utterly forlorn and forsaken orphan .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Where I judge in Israel ...

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: You would erect a monument to Mrs. John ! It may well be that many an element of the heroic , much that is hiddenly meritorious , lurks in these obscure fates and struggles . But not even Kohlhaas of Kohlhaasenbrueck with his mad passion for justice could fight his way through ! Let us use practical Christianity ! Perhaps we could permanently befriend the child .

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: You better keep your hands offa that !

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: QUAQUARO
sp.p: Unless you 're crazy to get rid o ’ money an ’ are anxious for all the worries an ’ the troubles you 'll have with the public charities an ’ the police an ’ the courts .

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: For such things I have no time to spare , I confess .

sp.speaker: SPITTA
sp.p: Wo n't you admit that a genuinely tragic fatality has been active here ?

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Tragedy is not confined to any class of society . I always told you that !

sp.speaker: SELMA , breathless , opens the outer door

lg.l: SELMA
Mr. John ! Mr. John ! Oh , Mr. John !

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Mr. John is n't here . What do you want , Selma ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Mr. John , you 're to come out on the street !

sp.speaker: HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Quiet , quiet now ! What is the matter ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Breathlessly .Your wife ... your wife ... The whole street 's crowded ... ‘ buses an ’ tram-cars ... nobody can n't get through ... her arms is stretched out ... your wife 's lyin ’ on her face down there .

sp.speaker: MRS. HASSENREUTER
sp.p: Why , what has happened ?

sp.speaker: SELMA
sp.p: Lord ! Lord God in Heaven ! Mrs. John has killed herself .
